Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had book projects cancelled. Numerous writing projects discussed pre-pandemic and in early stages were all cancelled. My only income is advance payments from book deals agreed before the pandemic. I am constantly seeking new projects and submitting work but currently have nothing agreed which would lead me to earn this year.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have had to homeschool two children. My husband works in the NHS so has been largely absent the past two years. I have had to fit my work into a small number of hours and lost my work space as I had to give it to the children to work in for the first year or so. I have been in a state of stress and anxiety almost constantly. My fall in earnings has been crushing and demoralising. I don't qualify for any form of financial relief. It is still incredibly hard to find work.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Couldn't travel to do speaker events.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write, lower work-related stress
Contractual_changes: Don't know because I haven't read the contracts for journal articles which I've signed. In fact, I don't remember signing them, but I must have.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Salary cut at work, and second book came out during the early weeks of the pandemic, severely limiting sales.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress. Limited opportunities to do events, to write.
Issues_Survey: None, other than I would expect copywriter to be listed as a role in and of itself alongside author/journalist. Given the amount of copywriters who are also authors I employ, it seems to be the case that many writers see advertising as a more viable writing career than literature of any description.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: m
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Importance_Other_Name: Short Film Programmer for a film festival
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I usually work from July-October on a film festival, programming the short films and writing copy for the festival programme itself. In 2020 the event was held entirely online and much of the programming work was done by the core team. I contributed some content, but for considerably lower pay. The SOA's contingency grant and SEISS payments helped keep my head above water - without them I would have struggled to pay my rent.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Production of audio dramas was able to continue during lockdown, with many actors recording from home. This allowed me to carry on working through much of the year, and I used the time to work on other projects. In the months before the pandemic I had been struggling to find work, low on funds and suffering badly with depression. Though it was a worrying time for us all, writing provided a distraction, an income and a way to pass the time. There were other times when I wasn't as productive and when the jobs became more sparse, but ironically that seems to have happened more since restrictions began to ease.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I had been contracted early in the first lockdown to write an as-yet untitled audiobook. This project stalled before the story was developed, but when we returned to it at the tail end of 2021 I came up with an entirely new story concept. Though I'd been paid for signing the contract in 2020, I believed it was my right to request a new contract referring specifically to the project we were now working on, and the producer agreed.
Contractual_changes: A company that I've written scripts for has changed their contracts so that writers can no longer invoice for the second half of payment on delivery of a manuscript, but when that script has been fully approved. This has drawn the process out considerably. "Full approval" often means the script editor, producer, director, company boss, and usually - if it's a licensed series - BBC approval. Once this has been achieved there is a 30 day waiting period from invoice to payment.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I’m tired. All the time. It’s exhausting.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No opportunities for paid events
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lockdown impacted publication of two books, no in person events or visits
Issues_Survey: Gender form needs looking at. 'Trans-gender' is not a gender, and should not be hyphenated

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My earnings have changed, but not sure how attributable that is to Covid. The main problem for me with Covid has been access to research materials, and in particular the British Library and the National Archives.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Yes, there has been a lot of anxiety through Covid, both for myself and in thinking about those I love - in particular my late teenage children, whose generation has suffered greatly from the restrictions placed upon it.
Issues_Survey: No, but I didn't think the survey was particularly well designed and as a consequence, with regard to the remuneration questions, I don't think you will have received useful or accurate information about my earnings

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Author events cancelled, in-person workshops and book signings cancelled, lower publisher advances due to cited lower sales despite those sales occurring during three pandemic lockdowns. Bills have risen and I have had less income with which to cover them.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am working harder than I ever have in my twelve years as a publisher author, writing more books to try to make up for the shortfall in my earnings and not even breaking even. I am driven by panic because my profession is becoming unsustainable as a sole profession.
Contractual_changes: Acceptance advances are no longer being paid on acceptance of initial draft but after the first substantial edit. This, due to publisher delays, can add between four and six months to the date I can expect to be paid which is crippling financially.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I would normally do a couple of workshop events (library, school) or a week's residential course at a literature centre, but have done no paid events at all.  Nor have I had any paying clients for editorial/writing tutoring/coaching
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lost touch with the hope of being read, being seen or heard - feels as if I've shrunk into a dry seed and don't know how to regrow. Previous plans seem unimportant and unlikely to be 'worthy' of publisher or agent acceptance. Health (physical and mental) has been worse, a lot of anxiety about how to keep going in terms of food, heat, power, and above all of there being something to look to in the future which might be positive.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: BBC contracts usually ask a writer to waive their moral right so they can (they say) edit and alter material; purely because I dislike the idea of waiving any right, I have often asked for that clause to be removed or rephrased.
Contractual_changes: I have not signed any contracts in the past year or so.
Issues_Survey: You dont have a 'don't know' box to tick; and the assumptions/questions about sources of income are all rather 'at the professional level', whereas many of us (inc. me) scrub about in the less grand parts of the landscape of writing, where things are less organised and less certain. It may be a career, but there is no 'career path' for most of us. This disorganised aspect of earning from one's words is never really considered.. how one has to rely on tax credits, grants, small earnings for broadcast repeats, just to keep alive, let alone undertake 'a career'. As you should know, there are tides in the lives of all creative artists, long periods of being out of favour etc (esp for older women). Those, while hard to assess, are part of the wider picture of who gets paid for what and why.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Now that my ‘day-job’ is 100% remote I have more time to be able to write. I also secured my book deal three months before the pandemic began.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of face to face meetings with editor and agent. No promotional events.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Royalties did decrease but there's no hard evidence this had anything to do with Covid-19

I've been solely responsible for homeschooling my child during lockdown so I've had no time to chase my publisher for earnings, or to do the advertising my publisher can/will not do. I also haven't had time to research new places to sell work. Anthology publications have been repeatedly pushed back due to paper shortages and staff availability
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Homeschooling and my partner working from home have entirely destroyed my time/space to write. Post-Covid symptoms have left me in too much pain to focus, depression from losing people in the pandemic has quashed my desire to write.   My publisher has been even less responsive during the pandemic than before. I have not had the time to research where I can find help with getting payments from my publisher (they will not release my sale figures or last years earnings so I don't know if the Society of Authors would accept me even if I could afford it).  My publisher declared that they would no longer be paying on the twice yearly terms detailed in our contract and switched to once yearly, leaving me in financial hardship. They've now missed the once yearly date but as I have no earnings I have no way to afford help to obtain my earnings.
self_publishing_comments: Published a short story on Ko-Fi as a PDF, took about an hour, barely advertised it but made more in a day than I was paid on a whole novel in the previous year.
Contractual_changes: Total disregard of contracts by publisher--payment schedule changed, never paid, refused requests for information regarding my work, failed to send contractual author copies or sent damaged/misprinted copies.
Contract_clauses: Requirement to buy back unsold print copies after five years but publisher has ignored questions about how many would be printed
Issues_Survey: Becoming a writer was the biggest financial mistake of my life, I am far worse off now than I have ever been previously

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Fewer travel costs, less spent on holidays and entertaining outside the home.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I work mainly at home in my  office so writing itself hasn’t been directly affected. But on the downside I’ve been able to do much less professional networking, promoting and research outside the home. I’ve missed that, and it’s certainly affected quality of life.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: - Erosion of literary copyright is a growing danger

year: - authors receiving a diminishing share of the publishing cake
- the major publishers’ growing tendency to demand all rights (except translation)
- the pathetically inadequate level of ebook royalties

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not been able to promote books by doing talks and book signings
Contractual_changes: Initial payment of advance has gone from being paid at the time of signing the contract, to submission of manuscript.

Importance_Other_Name: Graphic Design for other writers' literary projects
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Before the pandemic I was working part time as a bookseller (£9,000 per year) and as a freelance writer, editor and designer (between £2,000 and £4,000), with a position on a leading literary magazine. I'd just published a joint-edited anthology with a well-known publisher in Scotland, and was on track to publish my own collection of fiction with another new small publisher. When the pandemic hit, my bookseller job put me on furlough, my anthology publisher ran into a rough patch (as did everyone), and my prospective collection publisher folded. When my bookseller job opened up again, prior to any vaccine roll-out, the health and safety provisions were all but non-existent, and for the sake of physical and mental health, I quit. (While this was a decision I made myself, I do consider it a knock-on effect of the pandemic, as I would have stayed on had management taken the new challenges of operating under a pandemic seriously.)  In 2021, my collection of fiction found a home with a publisher in the USA - in retrospect, I should have waited to place it with a more stable publisher closer to home who knew how to market the book to a local audience, especially as the publisher has stated that as a result of COVID damaging their own financial stability, they plan to wrap everything up and close shop by the end of 2022. I've been lucky in other ways, though - the anthology was partly funded by Creative Scotland, which meant I was able to apply for their COVID support grants, and my position on the magazine board as designer and editor has provided some regular work. However, compared to 2019, I'm now fully freelance, and entering 2021 have no income currently lined up for the coming year, writing or otherwise. I'm putting myself out there to secure work, and hoping my publisher lucks into a lucrative marketing strategy, but it's feeling very unlikely!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The knock-on effects of the pandemic on previously stable or hopeful aspects of my professional life have massively reduced my productivity, and ramped up my background stress-levels. I've lost my stable part-time income to cover basic outgoings, so much of the time I could be writing, I'm spending designing and editing for the literary projects of my peers, or hustling for work. Meanwhile, what felt like a rising trajectory as editor and writer has been scuppered. After losing what felt like a good relationship with a local publisher when they folded, I panicked and sold my debut collection to the first publisher to show interest. Being based in the USA and (to put it politely) with too much on their own plate to dedicate themselves to any of their authors in a meaningful and supportive way, this was in retrospect a mistake. COVID pushed them to their limit, and they now plan to wrap everything up by the end of 2022, locking me into a five-year contract with a publisher who won't exist within a year and a half of publishing my book. It's not ideal.  I've also been trying to write a satirical dystopian sci-fi for the last six years, with key themes being global inequality, insular ideas of nationality, mass delusion, scientific scepticism, food inequality and governmental corruption. All of this was relevant before the pandemic hit, but experiencing it dialed up to apocalyptic levels in real-time really sucked the life out of the project. I'm still intending to finish the book, because I've never finished anything this length before, and I think there's merit in reaching the finish line, but the last two years have been a slog, and my heart isn't in it any more. That, combined with my collection being a minor flop due to poor publisher support, has really damaged my confidence in knowing what the heck I'm doing with my professional life, as far as writing is concerned.
self_publishing_comments: Before I secured a publisher, I put out a zine of some fiction and poetry that wasn't included in my collection. I've a professional background of printing and design so putting it together and getting it produced wasn't difficult for me, but distribution's been tricky during COVID and I've still to make back the money I spent in production.
Contract_clauses: I signed a five year contract with a publisher who decided a year after publication to start closing up shop. That feels pretty problematic to me.
Issues_Survey: As someone earning the majority of my income from literary-adjacent work - design and editorial - the initial segment was a little difficult to navigate. It's not writing, but I do make money from writing, just not enough to confidently answer questions on income which don't allow for a jack-of-all-trades portfolio career that includes roles that exclusively feed into the literary sector without being literary themselves. I understand why the survey is the way it is though! I just also know *so many* people who have a writing career, *and* a writing-adjacent career that is neither journalistic or academic - and journalism and academia have very high barriers to entry, whether financial or social connections. A broader understanding of how people find their way to writing as a career would have made the earlier part of the survey easier to navigate.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I wrote and sold more books - not necessarily because of COVID, that's just what's happened in the last two years so it's hard to split out.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I did find it hard suddenly having my house full. Instead of having it to myself to work in peace, I had two teenagers and a young adult child living with us and my husband working from home. But I shut myself in my office and largely got on with it and at least we forced them into doing some of the housework and most of the cooking which saved me time.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Issues_Survey: I was asked to rank my earnings in the first sections but many of the categories offered, I don't earn anything in at all - there was no way of indicating that.

self_publishing_comments: Self publishing is a route to nowhere, but it feeds an entire ecosystem of service providers. The accessibility of technology for writers to self-publish is creating an overwhelming volume of work, much of which finds only limited markets. This has undermined the value of work that might involve risk for traditional publishers.  There is a woeful polarity between the gargantuan sales at the top of the tree and the mess at our industry’s roots. Here is where most writers cannot survive as authors, and yet the self-publishing/writing ecosystem helps them to thrive and encourages them to convince themselves that a big break is just a matter of time. This is good for the ecosystem of advisers, editors, proof readers, designers, printers, runners of workshops and creative writing courses etc. But it may not be sustainable long term. At the top of the tree, the enormous amounts of money poured into marketing celebrity works and cookbooks for the obese, is shameful.
Contractual_changes: I have not seen any new contract since 2019 so cannot answer this.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Projects stopped, project development stopped.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have no idea how I have survived, but I have.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As a retired couple, we have probably saved by not travelling and this was balanced by reduced investment income.

Importance_Other_Name: Please note: I don't do nos 3-7
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of income from school visits, attendance at festivals etc, compounded by costs for these being tax deductible, so I'm paying more tax Some of my books are out of print, and Covid has impacted on how quickly they can be brought back into print - after personnel delays over revamping the covers, at the moment my publisher is waiting for paper supplies
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I'm less productive -  I miss meeting with other people to stimulate me (no, Zoom isn't the same) and with fellow writers. I've not been able to meet up with my agent for two years, because she's shielding. I have had less writing time because of the demands of other people who are less busy than they used to be (and I've offended some by insisting I won't answer the phone in the morning because I need to work). I'm also supporting my composer husband morally - he's extremely stressed by Covid and is unable to work, which naturally upsets him. I'm not sure if I'm stressed or anxious, exactly, but I am more strung-up, and I'm definitely in mourning for a life I was happy in, and won't get back, between Brexit and Covid - for example, I don't see us travelling abroad any time soon. All this impacts on my professional life.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: It was a contract for appearing at a local writing festival, and was designed with music festivals in mind - the venue wanted to take a large % of merchandise, even though due to covid it was not selling books, but would only let me set up a table in the foyer to sell for myself. It also had a gagging clause - no appearances within three months either side of the festival - which I had already broken with a book launch and which I found totally unreasonable, given that I was a local author unable to travel off the islands due to covid - this was my only venue. I asked the SoA to comment on the provisions, and wrote myself to the organisers - who agreed that the contract was a one size fits all aimed at bands, and unsuitable for this festival. They sent me a new version with those clauses crossed out.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had no school visits.

year: My publisher closed at the start of COVID which led to 25 plus books going out of print.
Another publisher stepped in and took about 12 on which led to my being paid advances which bumped up my earnings which would otherwise have been decimated.
Performance rights for plays stopped. One organisation who tours my plays decided to fund virtual alternatives. Once again this led to an artificial bumping up of my earnings.
Main_income: I feel I have been very fortunate. It could have been desparate but in my situation with another regular income and the circumstances described above I wasn't unduly affected.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I get a lot of my income from going into schools to do Creative Writing / Storytelling workshops and book signings - this stopped almost completely during COVID and has not yet resumed.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've just been stuck in the house and we have been reliant on my wife's earnings from the NHS which has been very demoralizing and stressful.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It's difficult to say, as I only started freelancing full-time right before the start of the pandemic. My earnings in 2021/22 have been significantly higher than 2020/21, but that could be due to a number of factors.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's genuinely hard to say. I was making less money, but enough to cover all of my expenses (my cost of living is quite low) without dipping into savings, so I wasn't overly stressed. I was basically kept afloat by a group of supportive editors who continued to give me work. These were primarily contacts established pre-pandemic.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: First Major TV hit 2 months prior to pandemic. Pandemic equals loss of reputation. Could not even secure an agent during pandemic, even after record viewing figures.  Stress, anxiety, pre-existing mental health condition exacerbated. Family developed severe physical conditions.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I left the WGGB when they approved a deal for myself and Co-writer to split 80% of the union minimum for TV, thus resulting in me making a loss on a prime time drama.   The WGGB model is beyond broken and the union are not serious about professional writing.  Most IP sales I’ve made in the last year refer to an accepted minimum for the complete rights - usually under £1,000. My agent testified that in the UK, this is fairly standard. Compared to other territories, this is an absurd figure.
Issues_Survey: This survey covers unrelated industries and I fail to see what meaningful data can be gathered as result. Also, your layout has so many faults it cannot be completed on mobile.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: We have lost about 40% of our income from examination marking due to cancellation of all exams.  There has been no government support for us.
Issues_Survey: I am upset about the fact that I get "receipts" for my books when they are sold abroad or when the publsihers has 'sales".  In some cases a £25 book sells for les than £10 and thus I get a tiny amount.  Why should I subsidise sales on the part of the publisher?  And cheaper prices overseas?

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Delays to projects

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The main problem was difficulty working because of having school-age children at home during lockdowns and having to help with schoolwork and, especially, problems with IT (Teams). I had enough work available, just less time to work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Apart from not being able to work much when there's a lockdown, it's unaffected as yet
Contract_clauses: I don't like being asked to indemnify the publisher against costs potentially incurred from claims that the text has caused harm etc even if the claims are not substantiated. I have asked for this to be changed but more recently they have stopped changing it. I don't have time to spend ages investigating and pursuing this.
Issues_Survey: I apologise that I only have time to be quite general and don't know about things like royalties. I usually work for fixed fees as is the norm in children's NF. If I am offered royalties, it's on top of a fixed fee/advance that I consider an OK payment, and so I'm not really bothered what the percentage is and don't have time to negotiate on it, I just accept it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Overall no difference. Savings on travel have been swallowed up by additional expenses due to having to access material remotely
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The inability to promote my work in person has meant that my novels have had little or no publicity. I cannot afford to pay one of the media companies or Amazon to do this for me
self_publishing_comments: I have published one academic work and three novels. I find this preferable to the very negative experiences I have had of trying to find a publisher and/or an agent but, as previously said, publiicity has been almost impossible due to Covid. My academic work has had a certain exposure through networking but the novels remain almost unknown

Rather, it coincided with new clients and additional work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have worked from a home office for years, so the COVID-19 pandemic had little direct impact. I have, however, attended fewer in-person events.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I have successfully renegotiated terms of contracts including payment amounts, payment timescales, royalty rates, no-poach/no-compete clauses, copyright assignations, and follow-up rights. I did not rely on model contracts or advice.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Harder to sell original scripts and get new commissions as a result of the 18 month pause in production. Many production companies have a development backlog which still needs to work through the system, so they are less likely to buy new material.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As writing was one of the few creative outlets available for people in the dramatic sphere during lockdown, it meant many actors, directors, designers, producers had time to write ‘that screenplay’. Consequently there is now a glut of original scripts on the market, so it is much harder for professional writers to get materials read and sold - particularly as there was already a backlog of scripts in development anyway.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: Less enthusiasm for production companies to pay a decent rate for treatments/ideas. They often want a free ‘shopping trip’ to try and set something up with a broadcaster or studio, rather than paying upfront for the right to represent the material.
Contract_clauses: How long is this bloody questionnaire? I’m losing patience.
Issues_Survey: Too targeted at novelists rather than other kinds of writers.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings usually received from examination marking as exams were cancelled. Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Although I have been more productive, publishers cite Covid backlogs as why they are not looking at any new cold submissions/proposals. The contract that I did have I was able to submit early as was able to use lockdown to focus on the workload.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Tried to retain moral right to be recognised as author, none referred to.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I was told 'take it or leave it' and as the publishers no longer assigned any rights, I couldn't retain moral rights on their own. I gave in rather than lose the work.
Contractual_changes: The publishers are more often just giving a flat rate, not allowing moral rights, and even the number of free author copies has been reduced - usually to only one copy.
Contract_clauses: I was uncomfortable about a clause saying that I was liable if the editors decided more than 10% of the work needed changes, then I would be charged the editors fees. Also in the past the publishers have provided and paid for picture research and copyrights, but this was also down to me.
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: E book and audiobook sales have soared, but I also have half a dozen more titles out over the period, so the pandemic effect is only part of it. No effect from pandemic on household income in any other way, though costs are down slightly.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no effect on stress, which isn't high anyway
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No, I forced up royalties on an audibook contract from 20% to 25%, and this will affect all subsequent titles with this publisher.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I prefer not to, in this case.
Contractual_changes: None in the last year, but previous to that (and when a journalist) magazines and websites tried contractual grabs, which (in some cases with the help of the Author's Society) I fought against.
Contract_clauses: i don't like giving indemnities, particularly against libel or offence (I don't mind plagiarism, as that is in my control). If a publisher has read the book and thinks it is not libelous or offensive, we should share the blame and costs of defence equally.  I have managed to get (long ago) changes in such clauses as to indemnify only 'after all appeals are exhausted'.
Issues_Survey: pretty straightforward.

In common with most people world-wide, isolation and lack of stimulation outside working hours is stressful and leads to lower productivity and creativity during work.

Contractual_changes: My area is ELT. It is clear that now, ELT publishers generally are very reluctant to offer royalty-based payments and instead have moved to fixed payments for what they term 'content' (people who used to be called authors are now content providers). This has not directly affected me since almost all my contracts were agreed before 2010, roughly when this shift began. Although it has not affected me, it certainly has affected many colleagues and the profession in general.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income through 2020-21 was propped up by furlough payments claimed by the management consultancy of which I'm a co-director. The firm's only project was terminated at the start of lockdown in March 2020, as the charity for which I was working was forced to furlough its own staff, and ultimately to let many people go (a large proportion of the charity's income came from use of its building as a conference venue, bookshop and cafe, none of which could continue as usual during the pandemic).  My husband ceased taking his small salary from the company, whilst not being furloughed and continuing to market the business. I was furloughed, and increased the amount of time spent on freelance work as a copywriter for websites.  Fortunately there was plenty of work on offer there, though the rate of return was very low, meaning very long hours for less than minimum wage.  I was fortunate enough than one of my books started to sell well from Jan 2021, though I did not see any return from that until the end of August 2021. The pandemic also meant that I spent more time on writing, and completed another book more quickly than I probably would have otherwise. That's why, despite the loss of income from other sources, I've said that it's had a positive impact on my professional life as a writer.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I experienced some anxiety around making ends meet. And I was initially anxious that my book, published in autumn 2020 alongside a slew of others that had been delayed from the spring, would simply disappear without a trace. I was very fortunate that that didn't happen, and the positive news about sales from Jan 2021 onwards is probably a big reason for my more optimistic outlook about my writing career. I know how easy it would have been for things to go very differently.  I've also appreciated the ability to catch up with people on Zoom rather than having to travel, and I feel I've been able to participate in events I would not otherwise have been able to - e.g. Virtual Noir at the Bar (online readings in place of the Manchester-based event), online book launches from other authors, etc.
Contractual_changes: No new contracts during this time, so I'm unable to comment

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It's a complex picture. Earnings have decreased because of cancelled events during the pandemic such as school visits, festival appearances etc. However, because my latest book sold less than the previous - due to a mixture of factors including cancellation of promotional events AND the closure of bookshops - my publisher then rejected the next one, citing these lower sales. Then it becomes a vicious circle - I'm not doing festivals this year because I don't have a new book to promote, nor do I have income from foreign sales. So although the immediate impact of the pandemic was cushioned by a very welcome grant from ACE, the real effect will only be seen this financial year, and perhaps the next one. Hopefully things will start to improve after that, if I can afford to keep writing meanwhile.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Although the pandemic did lead to increased productivity, it led to the breakdown of my relationship with my main publisher when they rejected the final part of a trilogy, citing lower sales of book 2 which were impacted by the pandemic. This led to a crisis of confidence and decreased presence on social media, increased anxiety and stress.   However, with the support of my agent, I have continued to write, exploring new directions, and have written a new series which has secured two contracts so far in the UK and EU. I have also explored new writing directions thanks to a grant from Arts Council England. This in turn has led to renewed confidence and resilience.   I'm about to start doing public events again. After a gap of two years, I am both excited and anxious about this, and hope they will go well and restore some of the satisfactions of this career - I miss speaking to an audience.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: My agent negotiated certain changes around audiobook licenses in the EU, and delivery dates etc.
Contractual_changes: I changed publisher in the last year, and the new publisher had a different contract, so the changes are related to that, rather than being the same publisher creating changes.   With regard to my first publisher, I had one two-book contract followed by a single book contract, with slightly less favourable terms, but I didn't feel confident enough to challenge it.
Issues_Survey: I'm really grateful you are carrying out this survey and continue to champion writers. I am constantly amazed by how many people think writers all earn much more than they tend to.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I left my paid job as it was not covid-secure and went freelance, so i don't get holiday/sick pay and pension benefits any more
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have no doubt that my enforced periods of time at home and being socially restricted, particularly during lockdowns, actually allowed me to focus more and therefore research and write my book (a commissioned autobiography) far quicker than I could have done had my day-to-day life been 'normal', that is, as busy as pre-lockdowns.
Issues_Survey: Yes, I thought the advance was designed as a form of pay while committed to writing my book, so was surprised when I realised the amount cones out of the first sales of my book, so it's not a payment really!

self_publishing_comments: No access to distribution portals. House full of unsold books. Critics not interested in my work. No one knows me. Not on anyone's radar. No sales and advertising/marketing expertise. Too poor to pay for marketing or sales agents...or bribe media reviewers, editors
Issues_Survey: Must I murder someone to get my work noticed?

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The impact of Covid on my income has mostly been dealing with a combination of an (unrelated) hospitalisation and the extra workload caused by working as a lecturer during lockdown.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The work demands caused by Covid slowed down my efforts to develop a book project.
Contractual_changes: Not signed a contract for a book this year.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Although my reported earnings for 2020-21 are slightly higher than the year before, they are distorted by two things: a book advance of £3750 in 20/21 and a royalty payment of £2300, which was on sales from 19/20 but was held up for several months. The main impact on my earnings has been in writing programme notes for concerts, which in 19/20 made up a large part of my earnings as a writer, but which in 20/21 almost completely dried up as live music came to a stop. This was offset a little by the sums mentioned above, and by a shift on my part towards some online teaching. This was made possible by the online environment of the pandemic but is something I hope to continue.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Both negative and positive. The opportunity to teach online has been a big plus, and the regular meetings with my (private) students have been extremely rewarding. Once the shock of home schooling my two children wore off I was able to maintain my productivity (fewer social engagements etc helped in this respect). Overall the pandemic has forced me to make decisions about what I think is valuable in my life - health, family, homelife, etc. - that have been beneficial to my mental health, and have built layers of resilience and resourcefulness that were not there before.  On the negative side, I miss the opportunities for contact with peers and colleagues that came with concert attendance (I work mostly as a music critic). I worry that I have lost ground in this respect and am not as up to date or as well-connected as I once was. I also miss live music per se; as a CEV shielder I have been cautious about attending events even when I have been able to. This has forced me to write more from the position of what I know already, rather than what I have newly encountered. This has been OK so far – I have reasonably good resources of knowledge, I think – but it is not a sustainable situation and I worry what happens when those reserves run out.
Made writing the current novel much harder because of my raised anxiety levels
Contractual_changes: Publishers now want large print and audio rights as part of their contract
Contract_clauses: Yes. One publisher has banned me from writing works for other publishers with strong contemporary heroines.
Issues_Survey: Some of the questions have exposed my ignorance - I had to guess about %s for ebooks and paperbacks!

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Little stimulation, not allowed to travel, overworked in academic main job

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Initially, for the first couple of months, there was less writing work available, which reduced my income. Then I claimed the SEISS grant, which was helpful.   Then I started to write about COVID-19 and more non-COVID writing also became available. From then the inflow of work (and income) has been relatively steady.   I used to sometimes work from cafes but have since switched to only working from home, which has saved me money.   I also do some tutoring on the side and used to travel to my clients' houses but since the pandemic began, I switched to online tutoring only, which has saved me travel costs. Although there was more competition for tutoring work due to people losing their jobs, so I wasn't able to take on much tutoring work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am definitely more anxious and working from home all the time has meant decreased productivity some of the time. Yet I am a lot less effected than others and have been grateful that the transition to working from home has been much easier for me than other people I know.   I also developed COVID-19 in January 2022 and have had some lasting symptoms (Long COVID, I think) such as headaches, body pain and fatigue, which has also impacted my work.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I tried to ask New Scientist Magazine if I can claim ALCS royalties for my articles for them even though they told me I don't own the copyright for my own writing. They declined despite me explaining to them that it's the Copyright Licensing Agency who would pay the money and it wouldn't cost them a dime.
Issues_Survey: Anything involving books, audiovisuals etc is not relevant for me. I write for magazines, journals and online websites (such as e-magazines).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: COVID-19 has made little change to my , save for the week in St Thomas's Hospital with pneumonia and another chest infection, and the two weeks it took to completely recover.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity. Decreased time and ability to take my books to the commercial outlet that I have, less than a mile from my home.
self_publishing_comments: It's a ill-organised world. There are some outfits that are doing all they can to fool the writer into thinking they will give the writer a wonderful service, charging the writer anything up to £7500, printing a few copies of the work, perhaps setting up a sales session at a bookshop and then doing no more.  I'm a member of the Writers' Guild of Great Britain and we've spent a considerable amount of time examining the self-publishing pirates, giving self-published writers advice, and publishing our own guide for Self-Publishing.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: It's some years ago. Two cases: 1. Publisher sold out to another publisher who altered the title and had another writer update (?) the work; 2. I was working on a project commissioned by a publisher but without advance payment. The publisher then became enormously bankrupt. The book was, therefore, never published. At the same time, I received no payments for continued sales of some other books he'd published and I'd written.
Contractual_changes: None, I'm afraid. Because I have had  only self-published works.
Issues_Survey: It's been part sobering, when I come to terms with how my writing career hangs by a thread. But it's also driven hope. ALCS (and the WGGB) are working well on behalf of writers. Many thanks for that.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity. No stress or anxiety.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: in 2020-2021 I saw a big increase in my salary from book sales... But this year, there has been a drop as the publisher has increasing issues with their supply chain, particularly in the US as a direct result of the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: increased productivity, and some increase in sales, although that is now balancing out, see above.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Reduced opportunities to travel to countries I write for, to research relevant educational needs;  reduced likelihood of curriculum change which in turn reduces new publishing opportunities; reduced opportunities to network and meet with colleagues.  But on the whole it has had relatively little impact on my well-being.
Contractual_changes: Publishers expect writers to do more work than they did previously in terms of picture research etc. They are more likely to want copyright assigned. They are less likely to do development work in-house and so authors have less of a one-to-one long-term relationship with publishing team.  In general, with some exceptions, authors are valued less.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I went freelance <6mos before the pandemic so don't have much to compare it to.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The closure of publications (meaning more freelances) and shrinking of budgets has been bad. On the other hand I've found more appetite for lifestyle-y, feature-y stories of the kind I write to balance out the pandemic-heavy news cycle.
Issues_Survey: My biggest concern as a freelance writer is how to make this a sustainable career into the future. I've been able to make it work for 2.5 years but at significant personal cost and it seems to be getting tougher and tougher, with more writers competing over smaller (and fewer) budgets. There seems to be an assumption that this is a young person's game, but newspapers and magazines don't seem to be looking to bring writers on staff to develop. The churn is high. I've now been a working writer/journalist for 12 years and I'm worried about where I go next.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income from events and school visits has dropped by at least 80% during the pandemic. This has been offset in the short term by receiving advances for two books during that time. This is a very unusual situation for me.

Contractual_changes: Not sure if this counts as a change as such, but I found the present staff at Pen&Sword to be surprisingly ignorant over the content of their own contracts and importance of certain clauses.
Contract_clauses: With Pen&Sword, the chief clause - 9(a) - entitled me to royalty rates counted against the retail price. A second clause, however - 9(h) - specified on occasions when a fifty percent discount occurred, rates would be calculated against the net. I was not informed in advance that (h) would be applicable for the vast majority of sales, including those made on Amazon.

Member_NUJ: Subsidiary rights in a translation contract (myself as translator)
Audio_RadioNonFiction: In translation contract, payment strictly on the basis of target language word count.
Audiovisuals: Licence requested “in any media in all forms now known or developed hereafter in the English language throughout the world”. As it was only a short translation, I signed, but would have preferred a less expansive licence.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I haven't been able to travel and visit conventions, which has limited my outreach to new readers but cut my travel expenses so my company could pay me more. It also gave me a lot more time to write, as I hadn't realised how much time and energy (and money) is spent on conventions.  Over the past two years I haven't been socialising often with existing friends or making new friends, and haven't returned to most of my recreational activities (ie gym classes) or hobbies. This has meant even more time to work, for better and worse.  I also haven't been able to proceed with the final stages of a series of surgeries that has disrupted my schedule for the past few years, giving me more time to work but also making it more difficult to work due to associated poor mental health.  Some fluctuations aside, my sales have remained broadly the same but I had more time and mental space to devote to starting a new pen name in a different genre, which has already proven much more lucrative.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Strangely, the pandemic has meant much more productive time, as well as time to think about what I most value, which has driven my motivation to work. More consistent book releases have greatly improved my income. On the other hand, the mental health toll has been intense.  Greatly increased anxiety and stress has also been hard to cope with, as I've been following Covid news and scientific literature since February 2020. As the pandemic unfolded, I felt responsible for reading up and sharing knowledge that wasn't discussed often (eg the importance of masks, and aerosol transmission vs fomites), with friends who don't have the luxury of my free time and research experience.  It also led to a sharp crash in my mental health when my unidentified ADHD spiralled out of control due to losing all my external hobbies, which were coping structures. This eventually triggered my diagnosis and treatment, and hopefully will mean a long-term shift from unsustainable treadmill-style work into slow, consistent work for the long term in my career.  With all my free time, I also had a chance to finally write and release what became one of my favourite books of all time, which sold so poorly that I realised my then-genre had become a bad fit for me. I was able to pivot to starting a new pen name in a different, much more lucrative genre.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: A foreign publisher had a contract referencing a rights reversion if they hadn't produced the translated work by the agreed-upon date, but there was no specific agreed-upon date in the contract, so I asked for that to be included.   At another foreign publisher I also negotiated a slightly higher royalty rate in exchange for no upfront advance, and a tiered second higher royalty rate after a certain number of units sold.
self_publishing_comments: Fiction self-publishing has been my primary income source since 2013. My income figures provided earlier are from my personal tax return and not my corporate tax return, so the costs incurred are not accounted for; roughly 20% of my company's gross income goes to costs (audio narration, editing, proofing, cover art, marketing, software subscriptions, convention/swag costs in normal times) and another 20% to corporate taxes, leaving 60% profit for my personal income, but I prefer this business structure to self-employment.  I don't think of marketing time etc as unpaid time, though the description may be apt since most "marketing time" (especially by self-publishing authors) is spent incredibly inefficiently. I know which roles within my business I'm best at, and I focus on genres and a publishing model that complements those strengths (for example, one that doesn't demand social media presence or require extensive time spent on marketing/Facebook ads/the like).  Self-published print channels make up a vanishingly tiny amount of my income, in both foreign and English, and my genre is not popular in bookstores or libraries. Most of my income comes from KDP Select or Audible sales, with the rest flat Amazon ebook sales.
Contractual_changes: I have only begun signing contracts with other parties (foreign language publishers) in this time frame.
Issues_Survey: FYI: the gender question structure is not best practice, so data integrity may be poor; my answer illustrates why.  Best practice is 1) gender: male/female/nonbinary/other; 2) is this the same gender you were assigned at birth? yes/no; it also includes explaining why the latter is relevant and necessary--similar to collecting gender info, for equalities/economic monitoring?  This is because trans status is a separate category from gender; transgender is not a gender in itself. A trans man would need to tick both transgender and male and can't, so they may have chosen one or the other or "prefer not to answer" when they would otherwise actually be happy to share this information. A nonbinary trans man like me gives an entire paragraph answer :)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Huge loss of household earnings, tho expenses kept rising fromworking more often at home. I earned thousands previously editing articles about events that were then Covid-canceled, so no articles available to edit. Freelance travel wrting, for which i normally earned 6000 to 8000 per year disappeared completely. Partner's cafe had to close so he lost all income. Had to take out 20,000 pound interest-based loan still trying to pay that back.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased assignments, decreased movtivation, loss of inspiration, loss of stimulation, much more stress and enxiety and too much time sitting on the sofa depressed worrying about money.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: they wanted me to accept liability for errors made even after their team edited pieces. I either struck that clause or decided not to accept the work. There is a distrubing tend of places asking freelancers to hold liability insurance for even the lowest paid jobs. I refuse these jobs.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: in the contract phase. i refuse tosign a moral rights clause and in one case lost the job. in another managed to have the clause removed.
Contractual_changes: MUCH lower pay; much more protection for the publisher at the expense of the writer; much lower levels of protection for the writer; much longer time frames for payment. In one case, I am still owed 3,000 but the publisher has gone radio silent.
Contract_clauses: One client insisted on the liability/indemnity clause while verbally sayign not to worry abotu it because he couldn;t see me beingin trouble for something that he then went on to edit himself. It still felt uncomfortable. If it wasn;t an issue, why was the clause included? "Oh that's standard."
Issues_Survey: I'd like to see a webinar on getting nefarious clauses removed from contracts. I'd like to see a webinar/advice on chasing payments from no-good publishers!

year: I work for a big publisher and I know that although I get an advance and  royalties most other academics sign contracts without any advance ! This amounts to vanity publishing in my opinion and drives down fees for writers such as myself who are not paid a salary by a university .

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: increased stress, greater time between books, uncertain whether i'll get a deal in future
self_publishing_comments: I managed to limit the costs, but the marketing time is significant and my skills at it are such it's not a commercially viable option for me - however for consistency of publication it's been useful I believe.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: high savings in travel costs. Saving approximately £400 per month by not travelling in to the workplace.  Productivity has increased due to extra time spent working - I have been able to manage three projects at a time this year rather than just one.  this has not changed my work as a writer however, as the extra work has not yet converted into writing output.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity - had time to research my next outputs.

year: reduced stress - much less stress and anxiety from not going in to the office and having distractions. Able to focus on my work much more and have necessary meetings online.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Hardly any personal impact.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of social contact and restrictions on external events makes everything harder.  This has negatively affected my productivity.
self_publishing_comments: I publish material quite regularly on a website and write bulletins for clients, but it tends to pay off in terms of generating enquiries for consultancy work.
Contract_clauses: Where I was unhappy I have always negotiated with the publisher and managed to agree a sensible solution.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost two editorial jobs with events companies, one earning me £3,200 pa and the other £16,200 pa. I was able to claim two of the three SEISS payments on offer. I work from home anyway, so while I incurred fewer travel costs for personal travel, work travel costs were less affected.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: COVID decreased face-to-face pitching which reduced work opportunities and increased isolation.

year: Zooms increased - massively - but more for training purposes and low-level networking.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Very little impact:  I don't do much else anyway.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Cabin fever, more stress.
self_publishing_comments: Decreased interest from commercial publishers but vastly more freedom about what I write and publish.  It costs money and has often earned it back - and I've also sold self-published books abroad.  I don't much market.
Contractual_changes: Need to self publish for mental well being.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Practical problems of research, closure of libraries and historical archives

Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Initially, I lost 5 months of work which was devastating as I was not entitled to furlough or any other form of support. I adapted my business model and am now working for a global corporation writing training materials, thought leadership pieces and research papers. This has increased my earnings from writing. I saved considerable amounts of money by working from home as I did not have to pay for travel (approx £5,000 a year) and I was significantly more productive without the travel time.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have been able to pivot my business to focus more on writing activities, both fiction and non-fiction. This has increased the amount of time I spend writing and coaching others writers. My productivity has also increased as I am better able to manage my social anxiety and workload. However, my mental health has been severely impacted by prolonged periods of shielding and the inability to meet up with other creative people to share ideas and support. I now pay for counselling and relaxation classes to support my recovery. Also, I had a writing project go badly wrong because a co-writer tried to publish my work without permission, something I can only put down to the stress of lockdown as he is now undergoing psychiatric assessment. This has left me with a 4 year project in ruins and a legal battle which is likely to cost thousands if I want to protect my work.
self_publishing_comments: This has been self-publishing on my website and social media as a way of marketing my business. It is extremely time consuming and takes me away from the business of writing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Increased because of extensive web content demand
Earnings from library and book club appearances stopped entirely during the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As I moved into digital publication, the pandemic simultaneously forced mainstream publishers to take digital more seriously. My small digital publisher had to work harder and spend more to have the same impact and to remain competitive in terms of sales. On a personal level I found the pandemic extremely stressful, especially as I am CEV, and this affected my output, particularly at the beginning of the pandemic, when there was so much uncertainty.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I asked for changes to a boilerplate contract.
Contractual_changes: The digital publisher I've recently signed with pays a greater percentage royalty on  the net sums earned.  They also take a greater percentage than I'd previous experienced from audio rights, and they initially wanted audio, dramatic and audio/visual rights -- though I had those  last two removed from the contract.
Issues_Survey: Other writing colleagues have commented that advances are reducing dramatically (I am not paid an advance by the digital publisher, but I am paid royalties quarterly, which is a far more equitable arrangement). Publishers are also breaking down these tiny payments into three tranches, and to add insult to injury, are delaying publication by up to 18 months.

Importance_Other_Name: Sorry but there's a glitch in the survey program as I'm unable to rate the the aections you've included.
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It hasn't. My work depends on projects arising when they are needed.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity. Decreased distractions from day job. Much reduced commuting. Massively decreased stress.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: travel costs saved, heating and lighting etc increased
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: more time to help others write, through zoom, that has inspired me

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: loss of opportunity to attend events
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no significant impact

Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: 1. A travel client went bust at the beginning of the pandemic. I was too reliant on them so relied on family support then SEISS as soon it came online.   2. Found a business that was investing in its website during the lull in business. From utter panic and fear, rebuilt business.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It was a shock to the system but my personal and professional resilience shone through. I think the bottom of the bottom of the market has collapsed - writers are taking slave rates - but those of us who can provide high quality copy will always have a comfortable income, albeit lower than a few years ago.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Main other work is as Background Artist in Films.  For six months 2020 there was none. Progression was slow thereafter.  Income was shored up (eventually) with the now scrapped SEISS grant. My wife who teaches in a drama  school found her income and schedule greatly affected. She received NO government help,  having moved from full time self employment into full time teaching in 2017 and then opting back into self employment in Oct 2019, as Covid was just breaking out.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress initially.  Developed Covid in December 2019. Long covid in summer 2020 made concentration and therfore writing very difficult.  2021 until now, very prolific on present project.
Issues_Survey: A box is needed where the  answer would be either NONE or NOT APPLICABLE (NA)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had savings on travel costs in tax year 2020/2021 and received more orders from customers.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I had more time for writing articles because several journeys to customers overseas had to be cancelled.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
self_publishing_comments: I make very little money but it keeps my work in the public domain and under my control.
Contractual_changes: Very bad contracts, very low rates offered. I published with a DIY publisher on a 50-50 rate, didn't sell masses but made enough. They sold up to a bigger publisher. Barely selling much more, on a very poor rate that I can't change.
Contract_clauses: My publisher being bought out and being shunted to a much shittier royalty rate. I should have been paid off.
Issues_Survey: Some of the questions weren't relevant, eg I don't write for TV but I do write for web.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Lack of work.  Lecturing.  Writing with other writers. Tours, travel etc although money saved does not equate to any advantage.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: The 'legal advice' question is a bit vague.  I consider my agent advising me to sign a contract as being legal advice about the contract - i.e. he has looked at it and thinks it's fine. So I picked the 'as a matter of course' option, though that makes it sound as if we have discussions about it. We don't.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Household earnings were impacted as my partner was on furlough, plus some of my travel writing was curtailed a little.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Probably increased productivity, but also increased stress and anxiety like most of the population.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I negotiated a better royalty rate for various formats, plus included a limited rights use (5-year reversion clause).
Contractual_changes: I've found contracts to be more negotiable.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel, but additional electricity bills [heating etc] from teaching from home online. More time to freelance write.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am currently off work with stress/depression, partly as a result of covid lockdown and teaching online.
self_publishing_comments: I have been a publisher in one form or another since 1980. Designing a book from a manuscript document is now a short process, as is on-demand digital printing or photocopying & stapling. Using social media and email lists it is easy to sell short runs of poetry.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less money around for non-essentials

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have been unable to teach as much. Some of my teaching has been on-line. I am  employed infrequently when more specialist teaching is required. I used to teach daily. Now I teach no more than a few hours per term.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am a retired primary teacher but was called back to teach specialist maths to Year 6 pupils on a daily basis .  Apart from not being employed on a regular basis, not at all.
Issues_Survey: None. To clarify I was part of a team of teachers that put together the 'Teach it, Solve it' series of books for BEAM. I signed away my rights on the completion of the series (as did all members of the group) I was given a one off payment. It was later, after I retired, that ACLS contacted me with regards the series and told me of the earnings made by the book. I can only assume that BEAM signed back the rights to the teachers. Had it not been for the contact of ALCS, who actively sought me, I would never have known of any remuneration.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No real impact. Salary has not gone up. Book royalties and editorial income has stayed about the same.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I spend more time at home, and it is dififcult to travel, which I used to do. Thus better carbon footprint, but less interesting life!
Contractual_changes: None. The contrascts are very similar. Additional pressure to reduce percentage of royalties, but I resist as an established author. I suspect new authors would get a less favourable deal.
Issues_Survey: Yes. You need to allow a not applicable to some of the drop down, ranking lists as most of these do not apply to me.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Unable to go into schools. Didn't earn for over a year.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity. Forced me to look at alternative sources of income - teaching writing.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Working from home at own cost ref energy bills, ICT costs, , printing / stationery etc  No 'perks' from travel expenses, hotel stays/meals, refreshments/food provided at training / meeting venues at employer expense, etc
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of stimulation / cross fertilisation with colleagues at F2F events.
Contractual_changes: none, retired, not writing any new books
Issues_Survey: As a retired author of 3 text books published many years ago, a lot was not relevant to my circumstances

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Significant loss of magazine work

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Opportunities to earn have reduced through institutions being closed and offline resources unavailable. No opportunity to hold events.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Instead of being the only household member working 'from' home (ie based at home but getting research/writing done elsewhere with few distractions) there have been 3 adults based at home: myself, one full-time office worker, and one full-time student with additional support needs (for which ony limited support has been available). Other people's routines and work needs have dominated and rendered my work patterns impossible to maintain. This is a terraced house and neighbours' struggles with home schooling have been all too audible - though I have nothing but sympathy for the parents. Every day has been derailed and it has been impossible to complete any writing for most of the time, due to the constant interruptions and lack of alternative places to work.
Contractual_changes: None - the majority of academic writing assumes that you are willing to put in the time for free so it is ony a token payment anyway.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety or stress which at first had impacted by ability to write (first lockdown); slight increase in productivity afterwards

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Made me focus on what writing I could do while in lockdown. Also new opportunities to do online journalism training, where previously I would have had to travel to London
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More interest and optimism about writing, less anxiety/stress
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Again, in relation to the images I provide with my copy. Some editors try to claim copyright as part of their contract, and I refuse

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As above, it has limited opportunities to earn.
Contractual_changes: No idea.  (I leave all this to my agent.)
Issues_Survey: Only that a lot of it went way over my head.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic has impacted my earnings through school visits - they are mostly virtual now, which doesn't command as high a fee, meaning that I am earning less.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The anxiety and stress has impacted my concentration, meaning that I am struggling to be as productive as I used to.
Contractual_changes: I have only been published since 2019, so I have not experienced any changes.

Contractual_changes: Nothing in particular, except that I was surprised when under contract to write two books which originally were to be published hard cover and softback, once it was agreed to publish them open access, no longer to have access to the $800 fee for each book that I would have received if they were not being published open access. I queried with the publishers what justified this difference in treatment given that the work involved for the author was the same, but until now have had no substantive response on this.
