Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Only local bookshop closed and shop made little effort to sell online.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I had time to write and to learn how to self-publish.
self_publishing_comments: Compared with the local publisher and his bookshop where I have previously put my books, self-publishing sells far more books and provides about four times as much pre-tax income.  I have spent years corresponding with publishers and have found most of them to be stingy, incompetent and better avoided. Several have gone bankrupt n me since my first book was published in 1976.
Contractual_changes: I had one publisher who offered 5% of net receipts (as stated by the publisher) instead of the usual 10% or cover price. The results were not impressive.
Contract_clauses: I no longer sign contracts, having abandoned attempts to earn money from conventional publishers.
Issues_Survey: It seems to me, after reluctantly and in desperation turning to self-publishing (with Amazon), that publishers have been ripping off writers for decades.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I'm unable to register, despite qualifying, in a non writing field.   (my professional qualification was completed online, but the professional bodies don't recognise online training).
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Workshops shifted online, making them far more accessible (eg a London based session for a competition was opened to all entrants).  And I joined a semi professional playreading group that met weekly online, which provided excellent developmental training.
self_publishing_comments: I'm in a writing group that has a website where we upload stories, and I submitted twice to BBC Upload, which isn't quite self publishing, but it's accessing a platform.
Contractual_changes: I've not had professional contracts since 2014.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Slightly reduced sales of textbooks

All my lecturing work was cancelled during the pandemic (this represented a huge proportion of my earnings) while many of my expenses remained the same.  I was unable to hold events to promote a self publishing venture I had already committed to, which resulted in a substantial loss. My publishers (who relied heavily on sales to libraries and author self promotion) saw a fall in book sales and dropped me, so I am now without a publisher. The TV series for which I had acted as consultant had to suspend filming and was ultimately cancelled. I wasted time preparing lectures and courses which were commissioned, then cancelled as restrctions came and went in a way which rendered any forward planning a complete joke.  Essentially the COVID 19 pandemic has wrecked the successful career I spent a decade building up.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The COVID-19 pandemic has cost me most of my work. This resulted in frustration, financial problems and anxiety. Many in society continue to be anxious with the result that there are still fewer lecturing opportunities available. Book shops continue to avoid hosting events and signings. Lingering societal anxiety and restrictions continue to impact on what work is available, making it hard to build back up... and after two years, contacts built up with some organisations have been lost. Things are far from back to normal from the earning point of view. As I writer I found that the enforced solitary confinement of lockdown had an advese effect on my mental wellbeing and my ability to create. It is no exaggeration to say that my professional life has come close to being destroyed, probably less by COVID-19 than by the lunacy and hysteria which has surrounded it.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I hoped to nclude an obligation to publish a pb version, in addition to an e-book, but this was not accepted.
self_publishing_comments: I had planned to promote the book with personal appearances, lectures and signings in the relevant area of the country, but the pandemic put paid to that. This makes costs much harder to recoup. Publishers always expect authors to put in unpaid time doing marketing etc. so self and traditiona publishing are little different in that respect.
Contractual_changes: The difficulty with your questions is the 'have you ever' aspect, which then offers only binary choices - I have had contracts with seven different publishers, all of which are slightly different.
Issues_Survey: Please see previous response - authors' working lives are complicated, often involving many different contractual obligations with publishers, TV production companies, academic and leisure organisations etc. It was often impossibe to answer the questions with complete accuracy, because the survey seems to assume that working mainly as an author, means you will not derive income from e.g. appearances within a filming project...

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My debut novel was scheduled for April 2020, so all of my live events (signings, launches) were cancelled, which really affected the sales and attention. The pandemic increased my workload so I had much less time to write.

Issues_Survey: some of the questions are hard to answer  - the 'place things in order' ones i cold not do,  because the items didn't move

MR_dispute_grounds_addition: The CEO of an interested party (an arms-length government agency in England) demanded to view and edit parts of one of my academic books which at the time was  with the publisher but unpublished - I was opposed to the publishers sending the relevant chapter of my finished manuscript - the publishers took the view that as I had submitted the manuscript to them it was within their rights to send a copy to the head of the agency and did so against my wishes.

year: The agency demanded some changes which I complied with and the publisher sent the revisions to the agency. The agency demanded more changes at which point I showed the publisher how and why the agency was incorrectly interpreting what I had written At this point the publisher refused to send any further material and proceeded to published the book on the delayed timetable (about 6 months later than promised).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Publications I wrote for closed, publications that didn't close had page numbers reduced and had to cut back on commissions, writing projects were delayed
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Severely reduced income leading to stress and worry about my personal future and future of the publishing industry

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Unaffected
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Inability to find appropriate employment following redundancy and requirement to relocate
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress, anxiety, isolation, impact on health
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I had more time and fewer distractions or other things to do.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I asked for 12 free copies of my next book instead of the 6 I was offered and they said yes!
Issues_Survey: In the past 6 or 7 years two of my books have been bought up by US publishers, one large (Springer Nature), one small (OR). Both proceeded to ignore my communication completely and cut me out of royalties and statements. The Society of Authors has persuaded Springer Nature to acknowledge me now.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decrease in productivity - in general, due to obvious problems and a kind of lethargy - waiting for things to return to normal. Lack of contact with real people. Time was lost in the first lock up supporting my family with young children  Difficulty accessing research sources and information. SCONUL shut down and didn't reopen until Nov 2021. Libraries and archives were closed, various pictures sources were unobtainable as they were also closed. generally, everything was more difficult as access was difficult.   Example Without knowing how long it would be until the library opened again - I put a topic to one side, planning to return to it, only to have to abandon it at a later date   Stressful time - I missed a deadline with a publisher -
Contractual_changes: None - I've just been writing and finishing a book

year: although - the eBook was mentioned only after the contract was signed and no actual confirmation in writing of the royalty as yet.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: loss of consulting income
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Advance on royalties were increased through negotiation and given that I had competitive offers through my agent.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I already had a contract to be RLF fellow before Covid for two years 2020/22. I then had to take the first year as sick leave as i had cancer.

year: I already had a publishing contract for a ghost written memoir for which I received only half the advance as the editor was made redundant Dec 2020.
My earnings from manuscript appraisals dropped.
Exeter novel prize (I am a judge) increased as more entries (poss due to lockdown). No royalties.
I had some very difficult months (on UC) and then some good months and i'm not sure if this is due to covid or just the stage in my life
Main_income: Difficult to day as it coincided with my cancer diagnosis and treatment
Broadcasting: I have done my first ghost writing and my name will not be attributed - it was a one off payment

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More people are reading ebooks and I have continued existing series and written most of a new one during the pandemic. I also started offering editing services more widely, as my usual tutoring work in schools wasn't available, and that has been successful.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Overall I'd say positive because my sales have increased and I am finding new readers. I had events cancelled in 2020 but I don't tend to run many anyway. I'm as productive as I was before the pandemic, I think, and I have a new source of income from editing. There are stressors, of course, but I think it's probably easier for writers than for most professions - I now see two of my writer friends regularly using Zoom and also coach another writer.
self_publishing_comments: Self-publishing is brilliant but it requires time to learn how to advertise, promote, understand the market, learn about covers etc, in order to achieve a good return on the time spent writing. However, I can write what I like, and as many books as I like. I'm in the process of investigating getting my rights back on the one series which is in a publishing arrangement for its ebooks, as after an initial flurry of activity, the publisher hasn't done much to promote them.
Contractual_changes: None as I write for myself
Issues_Survey: Lots of the markets you asked me to rank at the start of the survey don't apply to me and there's no way to indicate that.

year: I think you should ask more about self-publishing as it's a growing field.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My main employment has not been affected that much. My books sold less during the early part of the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I had to cancel some travel to research more travel books. Not sure if I will do that now.
Issues_Survey: I self publish through kdp and Ingram spark. They operate monopolies in their respective areas so can do as they please.  I feel very vulnerable to this. Difficulty in understanding the VAT treatment of Ingram and lack of explanation from them holds me back from writing and distributing to brick and mortar bookstores.

Importance_Other_Name: Payment for public talks related to my writing
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less of speaking at public meetings which would also lead to purchase of books
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Realistically not THAT important as I retired a few years ago but received some income from talking, for example, in 2018/9 but now nothing.
self_publishing_comments: I don't really do that . All I do is use my own website which includes reference to my books and articles
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Not sure but about the title of the book relating to my own conception of an historcal incident. However, they basically assented and added a subtitle.  Ironically they were probably correct and led to less purchase than I thought
Contractual_changes: Not particularly this year but the circumstances of the publisher was worse than that undertaken by previous editor, there for deacdes and left and suddenly died.  How someone who is not dedicated to the topic can be editor is bonkers.
Contract_clauses: Not really. I was not conifned to subjitting a revised drat by x dates. This has been positive!
Issues_Survey: Fine but you might ask about the issues around people who have become ill / outside usual writing criteria. Also no attention given, I think, to whether someone is with an agent or not. Never managed that though pu8blishing many books and many many articles.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Book sales are down so royalties are down and one series that seemed poised to suddenly fly from sales at the very start of 2020 then stalled and may not recover in a very competitive ELT market. Other series were launched as pandemic hit so whether they have been affected isn’t as clear, but I know as an industry, book sales were affected. So going forward, my income might be affected more substantially. Writing fees also being driven down by publishers knowing there are lots of writers who want the work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity.  Increased competition and more ruthless pricing from publishers.  Accelerated move to digital in educational publishing though that has affected me less as a children’s writer than writers of educational materials for adults, as children still need to attend school and have course books even if their lessons are online or hybrid.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I always get non compete clauses taken out or made limited and specific. Also check for other freebies such as promotion or promotional material, wording relating to new versions or additions, etc.  I have started using the Society of Authors this year because I had a project from China which has since fallen through.  But before that, I did it based on my own knowledge and what seemed fair for the fees (I worked in publishing before becoming a writer).
Contract_clauses: I worry about the indemnity clauses because of high potential values but they are non negotiable
Issues_Survey: When I do get royalties they are at a low percentage as they are usually part of a fee + low royalty package.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It took me 2 years to secure my second book deal because of the pandemic. Bad timing as editors were furloughed and response times extended. I lost my cleaning jobs or had reduced hours because employers didn't have the money (plus couldn't go into households during lockdowns). Tough times. And then when I got a deal, the advance was an appalling £1500 - which seems an industry standard now for smaller authors.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress, but mainly due to my 4 teenage sons. I found it EXTREMELY DIFFICULT to work during lockdowns with 4 boys trying to do online learning at home. Been very worried about their mental health and that's impacted mine. Research has been hard as I couldn't visit places. Lost income through cancelled W.I. talks and other paid appearances.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I requested an escalator royalty that I'd had with previous publisher. Tried to get better terms, especially as I'm on 7.5% for paperback and I had 10% last time. Then I asked for separate accounting for the 2 book deal they offered. They wouldn't budge so I decided to just sign 1 book deal with them. Joint accounting NEVER benefits the author - only the publisher, and this makes me so cross
Contract_clauses: Refused to sign joint accounting. It is problematic.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: less people buying books for courses
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: not applicable
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Trying to get recognition of a publication after 18 years
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Additional work stress, lack of motivation, lack of possible face to face opportunities

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I haven't been able to sell through bookshops while they've been closed. Online sales have been good and I've only been able to sell on courses when I've been able to teach
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Small details and royalties per country and being able to sell through my website.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: textbooks not sold/ordered in same way globally thorugh pandemic
Contractual_changes: percentage of royaltis in new edition have gone down, supposedly to accommodate extra marketing and research by publisher to gain market share in longer term. No guarantee of course but no real choice.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: none
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: more working from home
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased anxiety to a great degree, influencing my ability to write
Contract_clauses: The amount of free copies has dropped from 12 copies to 3. Also gone from 3 copies to no copies for authors in an edited collection
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: At the beginning of the pandemic, projects went on hold. Later on, they came back but I had children at home and so had to subcontract work worth around £10,000 to other writers.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Extra stress from having children at home rather than at school over the course of two lockdowns. Plus now one of my children has Covid and so is off school.  I've always had childcare to cover my working hours, and it is important to have that - without it and with children at home it's harder to make progress with work.
Contractual_changes: I've always resisted having a contract from a title that I regularly freelance for since when I was offered a contract it included a copyright grab. Having resisted it all went away for several years but now there's discussion once more of having a contract, so I imagine this is going to come up again. But as yet it hasn't.
Issues_Survey: There were questions where I was asked to order forms of writing in terms of priority. Only one or two applied to me at all.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No conference visits = less opportunity to network
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Increased royalty rates.

year: Removed clauses we considered unnecessary.
Specified the format that we would deliver.
Required fee for delivering camera ready copy.
Relaxed the deadline.
Required publisher to seek copyright permissions.
Required publisher to register copyright in the Work in the name of the Author in compliance with United States copyright law
Books_Games: No. I don't sign problematic contracts. But I don't rely on writing income.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings - no opportunities to promote/pitch
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Motivation and decreased productivity
Contractual_changes: Advance payable on submission, not on contract

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity and a demand for new editions and ooerbacks of some of my older works.
self_publishing_comments: Amazon platform

Member_NUJ_year: Former member. Didn't feel it represented the interests of freelances outside the newspaper industry.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: All freelance work and copywriting was stopped immediately during first lockdown and some of it has not returned; volumes and rates are all lower since COVID.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Massively increased stress due to financial concerns, lack of support - I operate a limited company so was excluded from COVID support and had to use all my savings to survive. I'm now facing a double whammy of tax bills and having no money to pay them because work is busier but pays less.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic lost me a contract, potential business about to be won and the significant delay of a book publication (thus payment). However, I gained other writing work so my income went up.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As I writer I ordinarily worked from home and found it lonely but I regularly saw friends and went on short trips. During the pandemic, I found that I became far more reclusive and lonely, struggling to maintain much social contact. Much of my writing is in the local travel and adventure sport industry and because I couldn't do much of that, I found I was working far more than before and not taking any breaks or time off. For the first time in my life over a year passed without me taking any real time off. Which was stressful but I couldn't break out of the work or nothing mentality as down time seemed wasteful.
self_publishing_comments: I'm not sure if this counts, but I self-publish on my own blog as well as platforms such as Medium. My blog costs about £40 a year to maintain. I spend considerable time on upkeep, web design, graphic design, writing and marketing – all unpaid in these instances. Medium does return a small amount of income.
Contract_clauses: I strongly dislike indemnity clauses, they sound like a minefield for authors with zero risk for publishers (who have legal teams).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Very little impact. I retired from part-time academic employment in October 2019, and with Lockdown found myself at work at home on writing projects, unlike the Prime Minister and others in government. Because I have an exceptional library at hand, I could finish projects at home, and engage with new ones as well. I did have acute Covid-19 in March 2020, and lost 13,5 Kg in ten days. A long recovery, but soon back to writing using resources at hand.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: On my professional life, virtually no impact, apart from curtailing my social engagements and, ultimately, making me a bit restless. Daily walks in my neighbourhood in recovery from Covid-19 after March 2020 were a necessity. Much of my time is spent at my computer, either working with research tools or with my own library, so apart from a bit of stress, the impact of the pandemic was minor.   On reflection, I should say that a book schedulled for release in October 2021 was held back, and will now be released in October 2022, so there was that impact.  A book chapter, a journal article, a review, and two of my own projects were also delayed across the pandemic: the review went to the publisher today, the book chapter goes to the editors tomorrow, and revision of the journal article is next. Then I return to two delayed projects and a few other scraps. It was not all bad news: two colleagues and I have virtually finished another book which was begun just as Covid-19 hit town, so that is waiting in abeyance and irregardless of the state of the world.
self_publishing_comments: I have self-published three items, and prepared a fourth.   A list of international patents in my field was printed in 11 copies and circulated to colleagues (94pp, A5)  A list of the books in my professional library was printed in 3 copies and circulated to colleagues (202pp, A5) An unfinished but proposed catalogue of works was printed in 3 copies and circulated to potential publishers (136pp, A5) A group of 76 letters, plus attachments was prepared as a set of correspondence between myself and a deceased colleague, not yet printed (A4, ??210 pp?)  None of this material was marketed, with printing and postal costs incurred by myself alone. The catalogue of works is intended to be published elsewhere, and the list of patents will soon have a second edition with, possibly, wider circulation.
Contractual_changes: I have no relevant information here.
Contract_clauses: Not in the past year or so. For a contract that is still running with a proper academic publisher, royalties were initially paid for e-book copies of the work under contract, but a few years later these royalties disappeared with no explanation. And with the expansion of e-book sales by the publisher. Disgusting.
Issues_Survey: My only comment is that often, here, yes/no answers do not adequately reflect my situation. Without wanting to condemn survey analysts to unending work, a few 'maybe' or 'sometimes' items could be included.

Importance_Other_Name: film rights.  no earnings from 3 to 7.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no earnings form giving talks. less commissions.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As all writing work is done from home, it has had no significant effect.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have experienced no significant stress over Covid-19. So it has made no significant difference to my writing work.
Issues_Survey: Only that it does not always fit comfortably with my circumstances — retired with a reasonable pension, yet with some small earnings from publications over the last 25 years or so, and from occasional new publications.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Through cancellations of lectures in the first lockdown, although they have now largely moved online
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am trying to write fiction set in contemporary London, but am no longer sure what contemporary London is.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I mostly write about food and travel, two sectors that have been very affected.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Depressing- anxious - living off retirement savings

year: Having to turn down work when they halved the fees .
Employers knew we were desperate and treated us badly.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have been able to write and publish more and travelled less.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Thankfully, I and none of my family have been ill so I suffered no stress or anxiety which enabled me to write more.
self_publishing_comments: My costs are formatting print and ebook US$150 per book and cover design US$200 per book along with advertising on Amazon US$30 per month. I spend about an hour each day on marketing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I cannot be certain that the pandenmc has affected by earnings. However, I did get fewer commissions so it is fairly likely that the pandemic affected the publishers and/or school closures affected sales.
self_publishing_comments: Research, design, editing and printing all paid for. There is only a slim chance of making a profit (total expenses about £8,500). I am now spending time on marketing.
Issues_Survey: It has made me wonder if I should be getting payments on the books where I have assigned copyright to the publisher. I hope this is not the case.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of writing workshops income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity.
Issues_Survey: It's a good survey.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time working from home (non-writing work) has given me more time to write since I’m not travelling as much.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: halved ALCS payment
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no comment, retired Emeritus
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: A possible loss through travel expenses
It's made no difference at all.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I'm as annoyingly cheerful as ever.
Issues_Survey: No

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Consultancy overseas has almost entirely stopped.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have had more trime to write, but fewer requests coming in for manuscripts, and a book I was editing became painfully slow work as others involved became distracted from their work.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I do not remember now th details, but they were relatively minor points and the publisher agreed to my amendments without argument or rancour.
Contractual_changes: Publ;ishers have become more ruthless about taking titles out of print.  One of my books (about a decade ago) was involved in take-overs by two  publishers in rapid succession, the second one taking the book out of print without telling me until I wrotye to enquirte why I had had no royalty payment.  They then prevaricated when I demanded my rights back, and only reluctantly conceded them when I threatened legal action.
Contract_clauses: No or I wouldn't have signed.
Issues_Survey: Some of the quesyions could have been more clear about what information was being sought.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: All my lectures have been cancelled and I do not engage with Zoom.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Having more time has enabled me to establish and build a a large new website of local history biographies.   This will not bring any income as it is a collaborative project.  My role is as researcher, editor and administrator.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I published with Ashgate. Ashgate was bought up by Routledge and I have not received a penny since.  Indeed, Ashgate probably owed me £1000 from c.2010 but do not answer my letters.
Contractual_changes: I feel deeply offended that both Ashgate and Routledge have continued to re-print my book and have not sent me any royalty since about 2010.

year: Surely this is in defiance of the contract I signed c.2000 ?
On a tiny pension [with no other income] I cannot afford to go to law.
I suspect that they are hoping I am dead !!
Member_ALLi: Amidst the ghastly isolation of the pandemic I am grateful to share this information with an intelligent person, via this software.  Is there any hope for the publishing industry ?  I suspect not.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Covid has had positive and negative impact. Easier for me to give talks about my work virtually but has made speaking at conferences and selling books at events impossible
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Was offered £30 for writing a chapter in an academic book. Negotiated payment in books instead. NB won’t be writing for these people again as the time demands were high
self_publishing_comments: Cost 2,500 upfront publication and marketing costs for first batch. However, did quickly go into small profit. Made every mistake possible but learnt a lot. Will be self publishing again. Earnt more than I would had I gone with a publisher.
Contractual_changes: First time self publisher in 2020. Left job to become freelance speaker /trainer (centred on book).

year: The chapter that I got £30 one off fee for was a one off.
Primary_Occupations: I turned down a publisher because I was not happy with the contract

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact

Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I write mainly about theatre and entertainment and copywriting about renting a space in offices, both of which were decimated during lockdown. Earnings more than halved, topped up a little by government grants.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of earnings was stressful and increased my anxiety.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The bulk of my earnings from writing/publishing are from my Patreon members, and this did not fluctuate significantly due to the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decrease of productivity as a writer, due to lack of variety in life I guess?

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less work expenses e.g. petrol
self_publishing_comments: I think I was lucky in that my self published book sold several thousand copies, and many more than the books I had published with a well known publisher previously.   I have mixed views of the advertising offered by self-publishing platforms such as KDP - my feeling is that they are geared towards extracting fees from authors rather than boosting sales.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was offered a remote writing job in 2020 after losing my job in the tourism industry. My self employed earnings were only impacted in that my intended book release in 2020 was delayed by 7 months. I did not notice any tangible difference in sales for my books during the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Though being employed as a writer enabled me to hone my craft, write in different styles and learn more about copywriting, it has become stressful working fully from home and in front of a computer screen.  My self employed works have enjoyed some benefits in working from home in being able to conduct more interviews and podcasts and general deal with more people remotely to promote them.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No.
Contract_clauses: The obligation to offer your current publisher first refusal on your next work.
Issues_Survey: No.

Contract_clauses: Copyright is now lifetime for ebooks and it used to be seven years.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I couldn’t write during lockdown - partly because I was homeschooling three children and partly because I was too anxious to settle down to it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Wrote more
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write
self_publishing_comments: Minimal costs, pays off in terms of new contacts and commissions.
Issues_Survey: Many questions seem to assume that writing is a principal component of the respondent's income. This isn't true of me and I suspect it isn't true of many ALCS members.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Many of the smalerl book publishers have either dramatically reduced activity or closed completely
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Covid is not as bad as regulation by government. both are stressful. Both decrease innovation and entrepreneurial activity
self_publishing_comments: Very time consuming.  Often very complicated. Significant difficulties with over-seas-based organisation (Amazon digital - Kindle)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Small savings on travel
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Really nothing
Changed_contract_Negotiations: New edition, different royalty split
Issues_Survey: You didn't ask about new things a publisher came up with that aren't in the contract (e.g. political correctness police suddenly appearing out of nowhere)
no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Initially there was a drop in earning, but it quickly picked up. Substantial saving on travel costs.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I managed to negotiate a slightly better translation rate and also an important change in the contract – instead of signing over the copyright I managed to negotiate a licence-based contract.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not being invited as a speaker or visiting lecturer
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Depressed more work teaching
Issues_Survey: Too long
None

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No influence
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: None
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I signed but discovered the publisher was covertly not what they said. I cancelled within 14 days
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Publisher wanted to decide on some illustrative content. I withdrew
Contract_clauses: Yes. Realising I had signed a contract which was not exactly what they said, Withdrew immediately although, thankfully, the payment had not connected!
Issues_Survey: NOt really except a lot did not directly apply to me

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It has made no difference as we are both teachers and still have to teach whether or not we are in school.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time spent preparing for school and less spent on writing so things took much longer than anticipated.
Magazines closing. Reduction in fees and lower motivation
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income from talks and readings has decreased, but I have managed to increase other elements of income
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My income from talks and readings has decreased. I have been less able to promote my books, leading to decreased sales and lowered profile
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Publisher wished mt to give up copyright in the piece. I declined. The contract was amended.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings because of cancellation of postgraduate courses at Cranfield University and loss of lecture fees, loss of book sales because the University purchased tet book for each of its students on residential course.  Savings in travel by use of virtual external examinations - Zoom.  Unable to do some research because of limited or zero access to libraries and private heritage collections which will affect future writing and lecture material.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: A mixed bag - more time to write, but reduced opportunity to present the material at lectures. my writing has been focussed on providing articles for blogs and Royal Aeronautical Society monthly newsletters with no fee. this keeps my hand in but does not produce an income. On the other hand anything written now can be used in the future, maybe to earn a fee.
Contractual_changes: I have not experience any changes.
Issues_Survey: This survey has all been about earnings, I would appreciate more guidance on tax payment and legitimate expenses - what do other writers claim. I think ALCS should be able to provide an explanation and guidance to enable authors to understand their tax liability

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I caught Covid in early 2020 and developed long Covid shortly afterwards, which has reduced the amount of freelance work I've been physically able to take on. I've also been unable to review concerts or festivals, which was another source of income, partly due to so many being cancelled but also due to not having the energy to attend the few that were still happening. In addition to this, I've had work cancelled and book publications delayed because of the pandemic causing problems at printing companies and also in distribution. And I've lost income through PLR due to libraries being closed throughout lockdowns.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Developing long Covid has had a dramatic impact on my productivity
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I tried to get royalty payments and increase the lump sum I was offered to author a book. I was unsuccessful in both.
Contractual_changes: More buyouts and more publishers wanting worldwide rights

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity
Issues_Survey: It was a bit too long and not enough opportunities for “not applicable”. The questions about the last two tax years were v difficult to answer

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: DEcline in textbook sales
Issues_Survey: The collapse of university presses

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As my publisher is a small digital first they could publish books very quickly. This meant that we were able to publish more books at a time when more people were stuck at home and reading and when the trad publishers were delaying publication.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have had more time at home to concentrate on writing and were able to get in front of more readers. This increased my productivity.
Contractual_changes: I haven't. I sign the same contract for each book published.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Considerable reduction in earnings as a Medical herbalist, Naturopth and Iridologist. People were staying away from the practice. I did continue to research and write but of course this is a long term project writing a book.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: So much more worry and isolation. Looking after children with no schooling for awhile has depleted energy and time available, causing distraction and adding to the time lost. Stress and depression have bcome something that we have all had to try to cometo terms with. I am aware that many people have not managed to get back to normal. Children have suffered from stress with isolation.
Contractual_changes: Needed to find somewhere to write this.

year: Well researching and editing another edition of my book. The earnings and payoff will come later on. Now on my third edition of this book I always found that it would pay off eventually. From experience as a self publisher it is not easy to make money. That said I have covered the printing and distrubution costs and made a profit.
Member_ALLi: As a self publisher a lot of the questions were not relevant. As for my income I preferred not to disclose this. I have written for in-house on-line and magazine publications but they never pay at all. I think that they expect people to write for nothing. That's my experience of the herbal and naturopthic profession since 1979 when I qualified. The issue should be corrected. ALCS have been very supportive for me as I did not know about rights. They have helpedme to get payments which I never knew I was entitled to. I did write to my MP about royalty payments for writers. Aaron MP for Newcastle under Lyme wrote back a great letter ending it with 'I understand that there are no current plans to increase the overall amount of the PLR central fund in response to the Covid-19 outbreak or more generally. The British Library administers the PLR Scheme on behalf of the Government and the funding level of the PLR would form part of the consideration of the British Library’s overall funding at a future Spending Review'. Not much help there.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Limited interest from publishers in new book projects and poor book sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety and stress over reduced potential earnings.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Fewer magazines sold leading to cut in rated. One went from 200 a story to 75
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No opportunity to teach face to face. Hate zoom
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: COVID has not had any impact on our household earnings
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As above
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: N/A
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: N/A
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I’m disabled. So this has also been a key factor in my ‘output’ for writing. I also contracted Covid in the very early stages when little was known about it. It took me a long while to recover.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress. Anxiety. The ‘after effects’ of what is possibly Long term Covid. Tiredness. Brain fog.
Contractual_changes: That agents aren’t so ‘hands on’ anymore with how a book is marketed and edited.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I believe I was only able to get a grant from the Arts Council/National Lottery as an individual author because of their response and adaptation to the pandemic to support individuals. Had I not received this grant I would not have been able to continue writing.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Overall it has had a positive impact because of funding from the Arts Council grant. I also was not expected to attend events in person which was actually a real lifesaver as I was diagnosed with a long-term illness last year.  On the downside, my debut novel came out just after Super Thursday at a time when I believe the publishing industry was suffering from overwhelming book launch fatigue due to all the postponed publication dates. I was fortunate to receive great support from the community but I do think lots of new books simply got lost in the tide and many authors suffered as a result.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: The contract was with a Russian publisher and they were not interested in making the amends suggested by the SOA lawyer. My agent was not supportive.
Contractual_changes: Contracts are ever more in favour of companies and less in favour of individuals. Debut and early career authors are expected to sign without negotiating because we have very little bargaining power in an increasingly competitive market.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It's difficult to know what would have happened without the pandemic, but at the start of the pandemic I had a novel under option to a major TV production company and was commissioned to develop the treatment. This stopped when Covid hit then the option expired.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have completely lost confidence as a writer and feel I've made no progress in my career. Agents and publishers seem completely out of reach to anyone who isn't a debut novelist.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: A third party book to film agent working with my publisher wanted to me assign media rights, which I was happy to do. When I requested a reasonable reduction in the term, they withdrew their agreement.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My debut novel published in the pandemic and bookshops being shut may have decreased its sales. Also I got Covid and didn't feel well enough to write for a month, meaning my third novel will be completed later than desired.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I had to shield which was stressful. However I was lucky to find a great community of writers online.
Contractual_changes: Very difficult to get an advance.
Issues_Survey: I earn very little from my novel writing. Journalism keeps me afloat but novel writing takes more time. I'm hoping I'll be able to grow my career to secure a decent advance in the future.

Importance_Other_Name: Just '1' Can't seem to delete the others!
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had to stop working because of (non-covid) illness.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: See above.
Issues_Survey: No

Changed_contract_Negotiations: No
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lockdown was a golden time for writing

Member_ALCS_year: 2009 or maybe a year or so earlier
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income as an academic wasn't affected, and my royalties weren't affected either.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I retired at the end of 2020; prior to that I was on study leave. I was glad not to have the stress of teaching online. Lockdown just meant I could get on with my writing.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: 1. Right to receive a hard copy of the edited book I was contributing to. 2. Publisher's right to "edit, alter, adapt, adjust and prepare derivative works" - this was in a Springer contract that in the end I signed but was unhappy with
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: De Gruyter agreed with the American Psychology Association that David Matsumoto could publish almost all the chapters of our Handbook of Intercultural Communication under his name as editor and re-named the American Handbook of Intercultural Communication (only one chapter came from a different book; all the others were taken from ours). The publishers argued that Matsumoto had written a new introduction to the collection and therefore he was entitled to be editor alone. However, we had worked with the original contributors, finding them, editing their contributions etc. Eventually we were acknowledged in small print inside but have received no royalties from the sale of the APA version of our book.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: greater book sales
As most of the household earnings are based on my pension and my wife's pension the main effect was a substantial reduction in earnings from my genealogical work and my book sales.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The main impact was the inability to restock Waterstones with my non-fiction Pride Series for about 18 months and thus reduce sales.
self_publishing_comments: My costs per book are in the range £1200 to £1500. To date I have spent around £8500 self-publishing 5 paperbacks / 5 eBooks and so far I have recouped approximately £7000. I therefore still require to earn around £1500 to break even, but my books/eBooks are still selling, mainly Amazon, IngramSpark and Waterstones.  I probably spend around 1/2 hours a day on average on unpaid marketing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: minimal effect
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: senior author tried to have a person added to authorship who had not contributed at all
Issues_Survey: why do I earn so little from electronic versions while book sales are declining and e-access is increasing?

Importance_Other_Name: Q 6    ONLY 1 and 2 apply here  Q7 Only 1,2 and  3 apply  NEXT Qs 8 and 9 do not apply
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More publications finished and therefore more income from publishers
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress, but also more time at home to write
Issues_Survey: Useful questions but I found it difficult to complete questions which had items that  did not apply to me (7, 8,9) and I could not delete those items.  I also write academic articles and reviews for which I am unpaid (though it is useful for writing experience).  I could not account for these in my answers - so have only included  books which produce royalties.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Huge saving on commuting costs (rail fare, subsistence etc)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress via commute eliminated

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I spend less on travel and subsistence, but spend more on heating/electricity etc
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Far less time to think about things, kids at home a lot, less chance to see people and talk/spark ideas, lowered horizons, no separation between day job and writing - same desk, same chair etc.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Attempted to improve the dreadful royalty rate on offer, as well as increase the advance. Failed on both, but was offered the option of a time-limited "bonus" instead - if the book sells more than a certain amount in its first year, I'll receive an extra payment. Still all far too little to live on, but might make for a nice weekend away.
Contractual_changes: Advances have stayed low, royalty rates low, series jointly accounted so chance of earning out ever smaller, payments split into increasing numbers of milestones
Issues_Survey: Nobody in publishing is paid enough, yet somehow it makes enormous sums of money. Just one of life's mysteries I suppose.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Lost earnings from live events (school visits, festivals, talks to students or at conferences) and delayed royalties and advances due to publisher delaying books.  Less spent on travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, more isolation, lost event income. But more online events.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Increased expenditure on personal protective equipment and increased spending on data
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Inability to meet some deadlines due to sickness and/or morbidity
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was planning to work a further 3 years then go full time writing. The pandemic brought that sooner
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Production has occurred and increased, as my book published.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: One of the semester-long courses I taught, and two summer courses were cancelled.
Offer of a book project, more appearance fees, more freelance copywriting work being offered online.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Working from home has given me more time to work on freelance projects.
More time to work
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

self_publishing_comments: I have published an Amazon Kindle book, which has made very little money, but I have not spent anything on promoting it

Importance_Other_Name: Course materials and other teaching related documents
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Mostly savings, but some costs rising and expected future income/pensioen negatively affected
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not great for creative work, less focus/energy, more time consumed by worries etc.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings/difficulty of earnings initially, then an upswing and steady climb of work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I'm not sure COVID is responsible for the increase of my work.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Very little change. I worked at home anyway.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Little effect on productivity, more sales of fiction (although that may not be Covid but just a result of now having more titles to sell).
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: In regard to a project from a major educational publisher. The task involved reversioning existing materials that I had written to a new format for delivery. The publishers wanted to pay a flat fee, whereas in the past any such reversioning has always continued to pay royalties on the existing material being reused (in proportion to the amount of reuse). After myself and another author stopped work on the project, the publishers eventually offered us a contract that continued to pay royalties as the company had done in the past. During the process I took advice on the initial proposed contract from the Society of Authors.
self_publishing_comments: This is a very broad question, and I could write a whole essay!  So instead, I will just say that my knowledge of self-publishing was gained from reading around the subject, and taking some on-line courses about formatting, advertising etc, and using their advice. I have also found Facebook groups very helpful for sharing ideas and for getting readers.
Issues_Survey: My answers may seem confusing because I write in two very different areas: - educational materials for a large publishing company - self-publishing fiction Royalties are very different, there are no contracts involved in the latter, etc. So my answers include a mixture of responses.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My productivity has not been affected but my enthusiasm, motivation and desire to continue writing has waned. I will be submitting my finished manuscript in a couple of months time and, having spoken at length with my wife about future plans, feel that it will be the last book I work on. Covid has made me view life very differently and I no longer feel the rewards are worth the time, sacrifices and stress that writing a book entails.
Contractual_changes: On the latest edition of my book the royalty percentage went down from 12.5% (after selling 5000 copies) to a flat rate of 10% regardless of sales.
More use of Creative Commons licenses (academic work), so contracts adjust for these. This is for academic journals so there’s no payment involved with the contract

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was put on furlough for 4 months then left my job due to the schools being closed when my boss wanted me to come back into the office even though I was working well at home. I couldn't leave my children unattended and my husband works in essential services (police) and had all his leave and rest days cancelled. I had no choice but to leave my job and look for remote and freelance work which has been very slow.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The pandemic has increased my anxiety 10 thousand percent. I can't plan anything in advance anymore as I don't know when the schools will close or my kids may need to isolate. I find it harder to set and achieve goals for my career as much of it feels out of my hands. My health has suffered and I am waiting to see a consultant at the hospital. Pandemic stress has made things so much worse. Living on half your usual salary when there are bills to pay is so stressful. I'm hoping that I can increase my income this year but like many women who had childcare or caring obligations during the pandemic, I feel like my career has derailed and won't progress like it should have had we not had the pandemic.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Travel costs have gone to near-zero;  any earnings there might have been from talks, etc, have gone to zero completely, but were not large to begin with.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There has been a marked rise of interest in my work, as regards requests for articles, book reviews, online talks  (all unpaid, without exception).  Anxiety and stress have been very much increased, due to tensions within the family.
Contractual_changes: No major changes in last year.  In previous years, I have  (reluctantly)  signed contracts without reversion clauses, proper legal protection for the author, permitting editorial changes without consultation, etc;  no choice at the time, but I'm no longer with the publisher concerned.  My last few books have been with small houses where those issues don't arise.  On the other hand, sales have been tiny.
Contract_clauses: Not in the last year, but see above for previous experience in early 2010s.
Issues_Survey: No. I think it's all covered.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Retired  write for pleasure have had articles in print poetry, prose, online. Don't earn enough to pay tax.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress living in sheltered housing complex writing as helped to ease this.
Contractual_changes: Alot of writing competitions require substantal fees. Puts others off if on low incom.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It's very hard to say because I write entirely to commission. I have had slightly fewer commissions, but I can't say whether that was because of the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's been inescapable and oppressive, but frankly as a writer life has continued very much as before - working from home, submitting online. Of course the world beyond my office is a shitstorm, as much because of Brexit as because of Covid.
Contractual_changes: A slight rise in buy-out fees, thanks to a publisher with whom I have a good working relationship.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: There has been a very small increase in royalties. I am unsure of the reason.  Since all of my writings are school based texts, I assume that photocopying has been increased as a method of distributing exercises.  ??
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The only difference that I can register, is the slight increase in income, already referenced.
Issues_Survey: None

Importance_Other_Name: spoken word performances; teaching creative writing
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My (non-writing) day-job contract ended March 2020 and I was unemployed for a year and unable to carry out my plan of hosting writing workshops locally (online there was too much competition and I didn't feel I had the technical skills). Now working again remotely so no commuting costs, and my partner also has no commuting costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I was able to attend events online I wouldn't have been able to if they were held in person, and I had more time to write. On the other hand it was a stressful situation and my plans for hosting workshops and applying for development grants were scuppered.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The main source of my income comes from being a consultant. The Pandemic stopped a number of consultancy opportunities for me. They have yet to return.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have found I was doing an increasing amount of work for free, where previously I was paid. This was in order to keep up an online profile with a number of people who were furloughed and had time on their hands to develop a side hustle in my area of business.  It has been highly frustrating and caused a lot of stress that people who have far less experience are taken seriously just because of the noise they can create across social media. Yet the quality of their work appears poor compared to what I would deliver.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Household income has reduced substantially
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity due to time saved working at home

Importance_Other_Name: Education materials, nothing for following categories last year
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Dramatic reduction in freelance teaching or talks to promote book
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I wrote more, including an academic book chapter, papers and blogs, but wasn't able to network and promote them
self_publishing_comments: I aim to learn more this year & do it properly!
Issues_Survey: my last book earnt nothing last year, largely due to the fact I could do talks & workshops.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No real change
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No real change
self_publishing_comments: Royalties vastly exceed those available through traditional publishing routes.
Issues_Survey: I am deeply concerned that it will be impossible to receive royalties from academic work published in future when open access becomes mandatory. This will severely hit those authors who are not paid to do the research that they publish. It is bad enough already that academic journals do not pay for content and pocket large profits from subscriptions.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not impacted
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not impacted
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Incrased sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased income versus difficulty in travelling for research
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am also a musician and performance opportunities were down 75%.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Little impact as my music teaching transferred to Zoom.
Issues_Survey: Bo

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Furlough but offset by lower travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have less time to write. Work from home as an academic is a crazy non-stop never get a break helter skelter
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Publisher wanted to publish extracts (as teaching slides) made by them with my review but for which I would not be paid. They refused to pay so I refused to review or endorse them.
Contract_clauses: Yes.  A clause that says I will not involve myself in "a competing work" which is vague as to what "a competing work" is as the textbook is rather general and lots of things could compete with each chapter
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Re music publications in particular: since they rely heavily on ads for tours, and tours have been canceled since the pandemic began, they are are either closing (as happened with Q magazine in the UK) or asking for more work for less money. Newspapers have cut their music coverage. The competition, as a freelancer, to get assignments has become harder.  Speaking engagements have almost all been moved to Zoom, and fees have tended to go way down. For example, 100 pounds to talk on Zoom at Oxford University; same for London University. The biggest fee I was able to get was doing a ticketed series of talks arranged by a US organisation.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity because it's harder to find paid work. So many outlets now wanting you to work for free.  If you're in lockdown and not seeing people, it's hard to feel motivated.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: An e-zine wanting full rights of ownership and moral rights, to use and re-use any piece I wrote, for eternity, in any form they might choose. Since the articles often used interviews I had conducted earlier without any input from the e-zine, I declined. I offered to let them have the piece exclusively for three months for use in the e-zine but they declined. So I no longer write for them.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Sales of books, particularly eBooks, have decreased substantially over the last two years.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Poor health has contributed to the decrease in output
self_publishing_comments: eBooks and paperbacks published and sold via Amazon
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I think not having physical access to publishers, editors, agents has impacted my ability to sell my work. In addition, film work was delayed over 2020 due to nobody knowing what was going on and then I think shooting will ultimately be delayed because with the expense of testing and all the stopping and starting at the studios around London a lot of productions are behind, and it’s my understanding that larger productions are taking priority. At the very beginning of the pandemic I had a novel submitted to publishers and half the feedback we got from editors was that they were feeling very down and dark and worried an edgy, darker novel wouldn’t be what readers wanted in the near future. I don’t know if that’s specifically the case anymore, but I would expect publishers are and have been responding to covid over the last two years. I know several authors who had their releases paused over 2020, then had to wait for all the releases that had been paused before them to come out before their book came out, and of course that would have delayed the hardback or paperback payment of their contract.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I like to try and give meaning to things. I’ve had a very hard year aside from covid, with three deaths of immediate family members. Covid shows me life can be tumultuous and nothing is guaranteed. It’s made me both pull back from work to shift focus more to family, and also focus on getting one project to a stage where I’m really, really happy with it before sending it out. I think there’s been a subtle shift in publishing, as there was after 2008 and as I’m sure there will always be in times of uncertainty, to conservatism. I’ve been thinking seriously about how else I can bolster my income and lower my expenses and perhaps to take selling books at eg 5k as a win where before I would have hoped for no less than 30k.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I asked for more money!
Contractual_changes: I haven’t had a new contract in the last year; I’ve been working on ongoing ones.
Contract_clauses: I felt the amount I was paid to write for a major U.K. TV network was too low for the amount of work; I only realised after that although the contract said 4 weeks they expected me to work a lot longer on the project than that and receive many rounds of notes. It didn’t feel good to be working so hard and know those working as employees for the channel were on a lot more than me. I also felt it was hypocritical for the channel to be professing to be promoting diversity when there was no way for me, an ordinary middle class person (as opposed to an upper middle class person, meaning anyone sending their children to private school) to continue with the job without dipping into savings and putting myself into a precarious financial position. I stayed because writing for them is one of the “top jobs” I could get in the U.K. and I really believe in the project.
Issues_Survey: Thank you for running this survey and asking me to participate. For me personally, having a contract as a screenwriter that said “5k for 4 weeks” and then everyone at the tv studio saying “oh well that’s just rough, take all the time you need” and realising that in fact the contract says that to not appear illegal, because for the amount of time screenwriters end up working on these contracts we are paid, per hour, we are working for less than minimum wage. In my decade long career, I have never earned less than 25k per annum until 2019, when I found myself trapped on one of these contracts (because, of course, I wanted my project to get made, so I couldn’t kick up a stink and make it feel unpleasant for the execs to work on—given that they decide what gets made and where they spend their time it’s obvious that it does matter the “vibe” they get from working on a project). So the big issue with covid was that my government handouts were based on the previous year (because the years before I had had a ltd company and had recently closed it down and switched to self employed, so I had just one year of accounts and not two for them to base my handouts on), along with the issue of responses to a submission mentioning covid and that readers may not want to read anything dark, and the film project going into limbo for six months while we all tried to figure out what was going on and how long it was going to affect in person casting (which had already begun) and pre production. So I don’t think covid presented me with terrible problems... but it perhaps compounded the issues I was already experiencing with pay.

Contractual_changes: None as I have not published any new work this year
Issues_Survey: Some questions were not relevant to me but still required answers

Changed_contract_Negotiations: No, I asked for changes based on my own knowledge, and these were accepted.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I had issues with a film producer over the adaptation of one of my books.  I was not satisfied with the outcome.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More remote/online teaching is available and I have been able to respond to need.

Member_ALLi: Deadline clause - amended the clause to allow for delays caused by authors whose work I am editing
Importance_Other: Publishing is de facto for online courses
Downloading: As above - deadline clause for book editing

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Stock exchange losses.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: decrease productivity, anxiety
Changed_contract_Negotiations: 1) royalty rate

year: 2) number of author copies
3) Duration
4) some other copyright terms
False number of copies sold than actual

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contract_clauses: There’s a clause in my most recent textbook contract that says if the publisher wishes to produce another edition of the book and I don’t wish to write it, they may still use my name along with another author for subsequent editions. I asked for this to be removed but they said it was standard and couldn’t be removed, and also that I would have a say in who wrote it. As I think it highly unlikely they’ll want to do another edition, I left it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Since 2016 I’ve had a book a year published. I’ve not had a publishing contract since 2020 and only one paid event (which I have not yet been paid for) not much confidence for this year. My entire earnings are now tutoring/ teaching CW. I’m also having to chase up invoices for events which are few and far between. I feel the publishing industry has had little empathy for what writers have been going through and I’m seriously considering giving up
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Please see comment above. I’m felling anxious,depressed and isolated. I’m grateful that I’ve received hardship grants from creative Scotland and SoA but it’s humiliating and both my publisher and agent have basically fobbed me off and frozen me out because (surprise) my latest book did not perform as well as expected in the pandemic. My one solace is that I’m being given more work in the writing for well-being field. I work with some fabulous charities which totally understand how precarious it is to be a freelancer. The pandemic has brought home to me that the publishing industry is purely about money and not about books, talent or authors, which is very sad
Contractual_changes: Failure to negotiate more than a one-book deal. My publisher verbally agreed to take a trilogy I was writing on a one- book basis and has now dropped me after book 1. I have written 3 novels since then but they are languishing because according to my agent ‘the market hasn’t recovered.’

Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: six month period of markedly decreased earnings due to lack of TV/ film production during lockdown but this has since bounced back
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Reduced ability to travel for research trips.

year: Gneerally Reduced film production during lockdowns
Main_income: Yes, as a matter of course
Member_NUJ: Back End ie right to a percentage of net producers profit, and definition of net producers profit
Audio_RadioNonFiction: Film studios and producers  notoriously fail to pay the promised percentage of profits on a work, through creative accounting. For example I co-wrote Happy Feet and Master and Commander but apart from broadcast royalties have never seen a share of the actual profits from these films
Earn_ALCS: I have been very approximate about my earnings but the figures are more or less accurate - within a margin of 10-20%

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Development of an app based on books I write has significantly increased my earnings
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have spent more time at my desk that has not been ideal and I sit for long periods (I should do something about this but haven't).

year: I spend much longer on my own and don't seem to interact as much as before the pandemic.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I've been running a full-time global, digital business as an author and podcaster since 2011, so I was already doing everything online. The pandemic didn't impact my business — only my mental health!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The closure of physical bookstores meant that readers embraced digital ebooks and audiobooks and bought print books online so I sold more books and grew my email newsletter.   The business was fine but personally, I found it very difficult. I have a multinational family so there were a lot of difficulties in not being able to see people. Plus, travel fuels my fiction, so I found the creative well running dry. I do not like being caged.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I had signed a 7 year exclusive deal with ACX / Audible. I got my rights back to those audiobooks.
self_publishing_comments: It's the basis of my single person business. I've been an indie since I started writing in 2008. I went full-time in 2011 and have been making over 6 figures (net) since 2015. I love being an indie author!
Contractual_changes: I'm an indie, so use services like Amazon KDP.
Issues_Survey: This is very focused on traditional publishing. It shows a misunderstanding of the indie author business which is about creating intellectual property assets and then turning that into multiple streams of income.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: none
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Able to fit in more work due to most jobs now being on zoom and not having to travel any more. Also savings on travel costs. Also I work primarily specialising in TV which is having a boom due to more people watching TV during the pandemic, and the industry playing catch-up after a halt in filming.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less travel, means increased productivity and less stress. Able to spend more time at home doing hobbies and my work-life balance has therefore improved.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Copyright - when companies have asked to retain copyright on my articles I have asked them to remove that clause.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The main impact has been a loss of fees from in-person lecturing. I have found that there is a reluctance to pay  fees to people participating in conferences etc. by zoom. However I should point out (in relation  to  this and other  questions) by  the fact that I retired from academic life in January 2021. I have filled in this questionnaire based on my situation since then (ie excluding the academic salary that I earned up  to that point)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has decreased lecturing possibilities. it has also decreased the possibility of doing interesting new research - especially research based on first-hand observation, interviews etc. On the plus  side, it has allowed more time for uninterrupted writing and editing.
self_publishing_comments: I have done a lot of self-publishing in the past - including an academic journal which was distributed both as a journal, through a subscription model (with an ISSN) and as a book (with  an ISBN - each issue had a particular theme and a distinctive cover design). This was from 2006 to 2014. In 2015 I handed the journal  over to another publisher who  dropped the book format in favour of publishing only as a journal (They are now regretting this choice and trying to go  back to publishing one-off books based on selected articles from the journal). More recently, my self-publishing has mainly taken the form of blogs and other more ephemeral online publishing. The main things that put me off self-publishing were the enormous amount of time spent dealing with quite small technical glitches (eg missing fonts) and the frequency  of upgrades, requiring 'relearning' the software,  the expense of software licenses for things like Indesign and Photoshop, and the hassle of processing payments. There are also more general problems, not specifically to  do with self publishing such as the pressure to publish things open access and (if one resists this pressure) the problem of having material that should be paid for circulated illegally, including being uploaded onto platforms like academia.edu and researchgate. Finally, there is the problem of plagiarism.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: It was a complicated dispute, eventually only resolved through the intervention of  the NUJ. My 'victory' such as it was, was to prevent them publishing the document at all. I subsequently managed to publish part of it elsewhere but this was not a very satisfactory outcome, given that it took up a huge amount of time and energy and poisoned my relationship with an organisation that had previously provided me with a steady flow of work
Contractual_changes: increased pressure to go open access, meaning a drop in earnings and pressure to look at alternative forms of income generation.
Issues_Survey: there are a few inconsistencies between the descriptions of possible sources of income in different parts of the survey - eg commissioned research is not listed as an option in the earlier part of the questionnaire but is then referred to later. it might also  have been useful to have a better breakdown of types of writing (eg biographies, childrens books, technical manuals) and other types of editorial work (eg proofreading, indexing, copy-editing, translation) finally, a better breakdown of other sources of income might be useful (eg benefits, pension, renting out property, work for online platforms, crafts)

Changed_contract_Negotiations: Fee and deadlines
Issues_Survey: Yes, the questions seem to be framed only to give a picture of earnings by a narrow range of fiction writers. I earn my living mostly from popular non-fiction. I have written well over 1000 of these books, and only on four have I ever received royalties.  Publishers insist on flat fees in which they buy out all rights for all time in all editions – the only way I know of ways in which my work has been used is by searching the internet. The fees and degree of creative control has slumped dramatically over the last 10 years, and the only way i have been able to sustain a living is by churning out dozens of books a year, by ghost writing and by writing as contributor, etc.  Over the last 10-15 years, the fees have dropped by two-thirds in real terms – and if you allow for inflation, that might be 80-90 per cent.  This is at a time when worldwide sales of books I have written has risen substantially  The lack of royalties is a major issue. The books I write sell in huge numbers around the world but I receive nothing from this. One of the few books I have been given royalties on continues to bring in several thousand pounds a year, and is a a very valuable aid to survival. Had i received just average royalties on all the 1000 or more books i have written, I would certainly be a multimillionaire, rather than struggling to make ends meet.   Many non-fiction authors I know have been forced to leave the business by the drop in earnings, or supplement their income from other sources. It can mean that only authors with independent means can continue to write, which precludes many people from non-privileged backgrounds becoming authors.  It also means that agents are uninterested in representing them, because the earnings are so small. People outside the business cannot believe that as one of the world's most published, best-selling authors, I cannot get an agent in the UK.   I supplement my earnings by translation. Here again, the translator is rarely able to retain copywright or proper credit, though moves are afoot, thank goodness, among many translators to rectify this.
Northern Ireland is part of the UK

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of salaried employment, reduced freelance opportunities.

Decreased productivity due to lack of writing time, monotonous surroundings and stress.
