Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Solitude and anxiety.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income has increased, but this is not related to my writing career, it is related to my training company, which has had to move online. As a result of this, we can now teach far more students, which means that we are now generating a greater income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: During the pandemic I have had time to clear a lot of outstanding bits and pieces that got in the way of writing. It also gave me time to think about what I would like to write next.
Contractual_changes: None. No books published in the last year.
Contract_clauses: None. No books published in the last year.
Issues_Survey: All figures are estimates and I haven't published anything in quite a few years.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Lower advances all round, lower sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Difficult to meet and market books. Publishers only interested in big name authors. Slow to respond to queries.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: ALCS would appear, from the halving of my payment, to have collected a lot less on my behalf. Surprisingly, online sales of books - in my case at least - also significantly declined.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Ye gods, these questions are rocket science aren't they? Not! I suspect, if you want my purely subjective observation and concomitant theory, that folk of the demographic for whom I write (inland boaters, lunatics in general, North Americans who can read English) had less money at their disposal. Either that, or I've suddenly become shit at writing. Either is possible.
Contractual_changes: The one that springs to mind over my second mug of coffee this morning is my agreement with ALCS to complete a survey on 'EARNINGS' which would appear to have morphed into a survey on contract law, copyright knowledge, the effects of Convid and other such tenuously-related items.
Contract_clauses: When I clicked on 'Complete EARNINGS survey' and found myself answering all manner of questions unrelated to earnings, for a university in a different country (Scotland).
Issues_Survey: I skipped your question on 'postcode' because I do not live in a "postcode", I live on my boat and am officially thus classed as being of No Fixed Abode, roaming over England like an unfed, very ill-tempered raptor. We don't all live in bricks and mortar. Or Cloud Cuckoo Land.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Husband retired, so less income, but spent a lot less as no commuting, no meals/ cafe stops.  Managed to save money by not going on holiday or having days out.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: more stress as now have husband at home all day, every day.  I have lost my freedom to go shopping when I want, to see friends, have private conversations with neighbours and relatives.  I hadn't realised how much I enjoyed my own company whilst he was at work all day
Contractual_changes: none - have not been writing for a few  years

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic had a huge impact on my writing earnings - more than halving them. I was sustained by the HMRC SEISS grants, and by taking on a non-writing job as a care-worker.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Huge stress - not helped by the breakdown of my long-term relationship (brought on by the ramifications of COVID), and the loss of financial stability from my partner. My productivity took a dive and I began taking antidepressant medication, which further affected my ability to focus.  My first book came out in January 2020 and all events to publicise it from early March onwards were cancelled, effectively nixing my ability to earn and improve visibility.
Contractual_changes: None - I have only had the one contract to date, for my first book. This means I can't make comparisons.
Issues_Survey: My household income is a bit of a red herring: my partner would not freely share his income with me.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I would normally be involved in training in UK around the world. This have been replaced by online training, thought rates overall are lower.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Collaboration tends of be online which whilst useful is not as good as face to face.
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Speaking fees are 60% for virtual events
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've been doing a lot more virtual events which has meant less writing. I've taken on more teaching in order to make my income more reliable; this has also meant less time for writing. I've done a huge amount of pro bono work (eg for the NHS) which means less writing time.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I reserved other rights to myself (eg theatrical, film, tv etc)

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Just for the record,  I decided to retire after the publication of my last book in summer 2021.  I have been working less intensively for the last 3-4 years.  This may skew my earnings profile for you.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: None.  My agent has always negotitated an acceptable contract for me.  Any changes have not been significant enough for me to query.
Issues_Survey: Damn right!  I live in NORTHERN Ireland, which is part of the United Kingdom and which you failed to include in your otherwise comprehensive list of UK regions.  This error totally undermines my faith in the validity of this survey.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Being retired, I have experienced no loss of income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: N/A
Contractual_changes: Advances are smaller or non-existent. Publishers expect authors to do more in the way of preparing the text for publication
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity and motivation to finish books

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Books delayed or cancelled, more work taken in-house, publishers lowering fees for authors to make P&L sheets balance due to issues with distribution/printing delays etc. Childcare also near-impossible so partner hasn't been working.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased anxiety and stress, decreased productivity due to childcare issues, frustration with having to do work other than writing and so not progressing in that area
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Fee, liability, competition clause, first refusal clause

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Most of my fiction is either contemporary or in near-future settings extrapolated from the present day. I found it impossible to create credible near-future or contemporary settings that, by the time a piece was published, was not almost certain to be wrong on many levels (even contemporary stories involve me trying to portray the 'contemporary' of two or three years in the future, which would be when the story gets published). I had to abandon one well-developed novel project and spend months re-casting it as a near-historical piece; and since then it's taken me a long time, and a lot of trial and error, to work out strategies for creating story settings in such a rapidly changing world.   In addition to this, my partner is immune-suppressed, so our lifestyles during the pandemic have been even more curtailed than most; and as I'm the one with the stronger immune system I've taken on more responsibility for anything that involves going out into the world - with impact on my writing time and schedule.  Psychological impacts on creativity have been significant.  Finally, I'd note that my figures are deceptive: financially I've actually earned more during the pandemic than in previous years, but this is because I took on a one-off project with good fees. If this had been a 'normal' two-year period my earnings, with those project fees, would have been significantly higher than they ended up being. So what should have been two good years have ended up being two marginally better years, and that's where the financial impact of the pandemic has hit.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As noted in my previous answer, the pandemic has had significant impact on my productivity and creativity. (I put all the details in my previous answer, as the consequence of this drop in productivity and creativity has had financial impact.)  I would, however, like to emphasise the psychological and emotional impact. I've been a full-time writer on and off for more than three decades, and I've always prided myself on writing through thick and thin; I never get writer's block and I always finish what I start. The two years of the pandemic have been significantly different, and it's been a huge struggle to work out how to maintain creativity during all this.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I can't remember exactly, without trawling through lots of emails, but I think examples would include reversion terms, increasing advance payments and the weighting of those advance payments. The latter negotiations were mediated by my collaborator's agent, but the specific details and requests came from me. All of these negotiations were successful.  I didn't refer to model contracts or other recommendations, although I've done so in the past. I also regularly use my own previous publishing agreements as reference points in negotiations. The latter strategy was successful in negotiating the agreement for a project I edited over the past two years, where the initial offer (from an organisation with no experience in fiction publishing, so while they were well-intentioned their terms sucked) was a straight work-for-hire purchase of all rights; I negotiated this to a contract based on some of my own previous publishing contracts, and the project's contributors ended up retaining copyright and only licensing rights specific to the project's use of the works.
self_publishing_comments: I run an independent publishing imprint, in ebooks and print on demand. This started as a self-publishing venture (simply because it was easier to learn the ropes with my own material), republishing works that had already appeared via traditional publishing routes. This expanded to publishing the work of other authors. At times over the past ten years it has been my main activity, but the market has become less friendly to small ventures like my own and I've moved back towards traditional publishing in the last two or three years.
Contractual_changes: It's impossible to generalise. Each contract is different, so trying to identify a trend that has emerged in the last year would be misleading.
Issues_Survey: Some of the questions were impossible to answer. For example asking me for a standard ebook royalty rate when I have multiple contracts with a wide range of rates. It also doesn't appear to be comparing like with like: a traditionally published writer might give a low rate, whereas a self-published author might say 50 or 60% or more, but these are very different publishing models - which all appear to be lumped together by that question.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: no travel
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no change

year: I live on a wheelchair

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My first novel was published in late 2019 and the lack of opportunity to sell at in person events (author talks and festivals) significantly affected sales during the year it was a front list book. Several rights deals didn't occur for the same reason as the LBF at which it was due to be pitched was cancelled at the last minute.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Definitely had a negative impact on my mental health.
Contract_clauses: Foreign sales rights exclusively given over to the publisher when they are UK based and had no track record of overseas sales. It was conditional to signing the deal and non-negotiable, even though I tried.
Issues_Survey: Questions around income would be further enlightened by more detail on expenditure or costs associated with promoting and marketing ourselves as authors.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: I requested an amendment in order to reflect the secondary royalties I am entitled to receive.
Issues_Survey: You asked that i rank the publications/outlets I write for, without giving me a choice that I might not write for at least half of those outlets!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Remained about the same but only because of the SEISS
Changed_contract_Negotiations: For over 20 years the cost of indexing my work and redrawing some images was part of my contract. Now, apparently to help the publisher survive, I have to do everything.
self_publishing_comments: The final product does not look as good as when professionally done - but not bad! Extra time needed to do this but then full control is kept and all income is mine.
Contractual_changes: The publisher seems to demand more and do less.
Contract_clauses: Overseas royalties because they are ridiculously small.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The bulk of my earnings is made through school visits (part fees, part book sales), which didn't happen between April 2020 and December 2021. Virtual visits contributed a small amount of income, but not enough to make up for the lack of face to face visiting.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, partly due to home schooling.
self_publishing_comments: I enjoy the business of self-publishing - I have complete control over everything that happens in the process and I have access to immediate and accurate sales information to indicate whether my actions have been successful. I also sell a large proportion of my books directly to children in schools, which might be less easy if I had a traditional publisher.  My only regret is that for very obvious and understandable reasons (eg. the generally low quality of self-published output), self-publishing has a bad reputation.
Contractual_changes: Nothing contractual. The only change is that the printing cost of stock has gone up and up, and I've chosen not to increase the buying price of my books for customers, so my margins are shrinking, both for direct sales and indirect (through Ingram Spark).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: COVID has substantially reduced the overall income that comes into my limited company BUT I have been able to sustain the previous year's 'income' to myself
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The veterinary journals that invite me to write for them continued to require papers/articles, so my writing income remained consistent
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I've lost my academic fellowship as I had a baby at the same time that the funding finished on my job. I am now a single parent. THe editor of the magazine I wrote for died and so that magazine folded immediately (it's a niche music publication). I'll be honest it's been a terrible couple of years. I'm now working in some awful admin jobs for the NHS and the NIHR and I hate it. I have neither the time nor the inclination to write.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's just impacted my life generally, we aren't as socially connected, there's not as much going on. I don't feel as though I want to write, and there are fewer academic posts around which means i'm not doing research nor writing 'science for the public' which is what I love doing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As publishers furloughed staff they needed more freelance support just at a time when their readers demanded more content. Also, many professional services firms needed fresh content to enable the  to keep in touch with clients while the business world was locked down.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It brought in more work, some of which will go but some of which I hope to build on. I was used to working from home so the transition when lockdown hit was seamless although there was a brief period of disruption while my main clients and contacts adjusted. With no events and no travelling I was able to use the time to finish a book which I had been finding challenging because of the time needed to collate the research.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Suffered a loss of earnings through the suspension of live events, e.g. talks.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased output because of the lack of opportunities for publication, and the general slow down in the industry.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: General higher level of anxiety and lack of contact with others, so harder to network. Some payments for work were delayed due to tV productions being unable to start filming.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Issues_Survey: Brexit has been the greatest problem as overseas markets dried up.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs and the area of travel writing in which I specialise becoming more popular as a result of the pandemic
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity for desk-based research, but stressful at the loss of opportunities for travel
Changed_contract_Negotiations: One one contract, it was to remove 'all rights' on certain types of articles and to include that images provided by me were only to be used with the article for which they were provided.  On another contract, it was to ensure that it was acknowledged that certain content had already been published before.
Issues_Survey: Rates per page/article for most magazines I work for have remained the same for the past 15 years, yet the cost of living has gone up vastly. So, while my income has increased slightly, due to the reduction of travel costs during the pandemic, this doesn't actually reflect the true picture. There is too much content available online that is accessible free of charge, to the detriment of writers' earnings.

year: Days when the brain doesn't function properly!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More home-working has meant larger fuel bills but this has been offset by the reduction of travel costs and making lunch at home. Our income has therefore remained fairly stable.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Because we were locked down at various points, this meant I have had more time to complete my assignments for my Writers Bureau course. This means I have been quite productive and can potential generate income from some of the work I have completed.
Issues_Survey: It was hard to complete because the fields asking about money were not predefined and the system kept rejecting my answers.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As someone who is used to working from home I think I had an advantage in finding work and working flexibly when this became the norm. I have also saved some money on travel.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has made both writing and training/lecturing less enjoyable, as rather than meeting people everything has taken place through video and phone calls.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I have challenged 'all rights/work for hire' clauses, but will work this way if the money is right. I always challenge clauses that place full liability for any legal claims on the writer, and have in the past refused work if these are insisted upon.
Issues_Survey: Some of the work I undertake is partly writing, partly editing. I have included it here in full as I am paid to produce, for example, a publication from my own writing and editing other people's without defining how much of the former is required.

Importance_Other_Name: business communications (board reports, investor proposals etc)
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: First year of covid my main client didn't hire me for at least 6 months, other clients of mine went bust or ceased trading. Clearly our expenses were lower that year. Year 2 of Covid things more or less back to normal, main client returned and I found a new one.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: WFH is something I've done my whole career, so no problems there. I started a new line of work, tech consultancy, which is moving away from my main area of expertise (writing), although it hasn't paid much so far.

Importance_Other_Name: ?Are you asking about MY earnings, or which of these categories should pay authors the most??
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact - my paid job as editor has not changed; my freelance work as a writer is ongoing
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Working more from home is a positive - easier to get more writing done - bur during the times when children were at home also meant far less hours in the day to work, so overall negative. A combination of stress and more condensed working hours.
Contractual_changes: More detailed breakdown of all different types of publishing / sales: Hardback, paperback, e-books but also audiobooks, film/tv rights,  right to license content to publishers overseas in various territoires
Issues_Survey: Only that I didn't understand siome of the questions...  There was also no question I could answer to explain that the vast bulk of my earnings come from a job as an in-house writer/editor for a single Publisher. I exchange for a monthly salary + the usual benefits of employment I do not claim any sort of royalties on the books I write or edit, and assign all copyright on those books to the publisher. It's an arrangement that suits me well.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Clarification of wording around specific clauses, querying terms, implementing recommendations from SoA

Member_NUJ_year: In the past, and I’m wondering whether to join BSME, for profile - but it’s expensive
Importance_Other_Name: Teaching I have stopped recently, and I used to make money from consultancy, but there’s none of that post-Covid
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had other incomes before Covid.  Mainly consultancy and some teaching.  In Covid I set up a Substack and my debut novel came out last year.   I first received a grant from SOA and started prioritising my writing because of Covid - after a life as a journalist I could stop going out for other people.  I did a residency I. berlin, and then became Managing Editor, then editor of Ambit.    I applied to Ambit after being published by them in the past, but because the advertising fell from my past gig as arts editor for DJMag which paid £250 a month for three pages and took a good few weeks a month.  I co tributes book reviews to Mu magazine for their first year, recently stopping as it was too much and I realised I couldn’t contribute to literature for free at risk of my own work on top of Ambit which ends up being far beneath minimum wage for the actual work it takes.  I hope to improve this over the next year with grants and increasing sales.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I loved the silence from outside - not needing to spend money.  It was wonderful.  I wrote a novel. Then life became more demanding - meetings etc.
self_publishing_comments: I can’t make this about the money.

year: It’s got to be passion.
As it’s so small.
Art needs to be respected financially - especially by those of us who have dedicated our lives to it.
Importance_Audio: It’s so boring that there’s no money.

year: I barely pay contributors to Ambit.
I am barely paid myself.

Hail the ACLS.

Issues_Survey: I am a limited company with self and wife as directors. Our income on top of royalties is from pensions. Often I work with another author. The normal royalty rate is 5% but sometimes I have to share this so 2.5% . My estimate for me solely is 4% shown in the prior boxes

Importance_Other_Name: Executive Producer duties are folded into overall writer contracts, but probably constitute 10% of overall income.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Partner wasn't able to work as much due to increased childcare, affecting her writing earnings.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Fewer in-person meetings! That has been welcome, and even now most people happily offer either in-person or zoom. This is saving a lot of time in travel and chatter, which means more focused hours at my desk.  However, my relationships are established at this point, so sustaining them online feels fine. This would not have been the case when I started out, when meeting people in person and attending events helped build those relationships, and I feel bad for those who were trying to break-in during the pandemic... it will have been hard on many of them.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: My agent does this as a matter of course. Every contract involves negotiation over terms. I'm not sure "I" did the attempting, but in terms of my contracts, of course that happens.
Issues_Survey: I appreciate that it's complex designing a survey for multiple types of writers. Where a writer is mostly a screenwriter, for questions on copyright and 'moral rights' etc. it'd be best just to talk to an agent, as film and TV have standard contractual practices around deeming even original works as 'work for hire' for copyright reasons (which relates to payment structures too).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My overall income has not been affected very much due to to furlough.  Expenditure has increased especially on-line.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Covid has had a negative impact on my life in many areas including work (retired earlier than anticipated), expenditure increased (including PPE), reduced exercise (gym membership cancelled) with minimal socialising and no holidays whatsoever. I have spent a lot of  time looking after an elderly family relative  due to shielding. I have lacked any motivation to write.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I wished to relinquish a current contract so that I could publish the work on Amazon

year: myself.  The publisher (Kogan-Page) was not prepared to publish a new edition so that the work could be updated.  Consequently sales have declined. Any future works will be self-published (Kindle KDP).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Most of my self employed work is running creative groups which I was unable to continue. I also lost a very important contract due to the individual in the partnership being affected by covid and the working partnership was no longer able to continue without them. I had a huge loss of potential earnings and was unable to find secure work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has made it difficult to carry out my work causing mental stress and anxiety due to financial worries. It has meant the my perceived growth as a self employed business was unable to go forward and I have felt as though I am starting again. At times this has had a personal affect creating low moods and lack of motivation. I also, due to my leaning difficulties, found it difficult to join online groups and so found myself isolated and struggling to connect during and post covid as lots of meetings and networking has moved online.
self_publishing_comments: Costs of printing, unpaid time putting artwork and collecting pieces together, unpaid time marketing and promoting.
Issues_Survey: As a fairly new writer there were subjects around contractual matters that I don't have the experience of and so whilst useful to see areas that others might be affected by it would be useful to have the option to skip ahead in questions that aren't relevant.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I don’t think it’s directly to do with the pandemic. I crowdfunded two books in 2019 and 2020 (one during the major lockdown) and these two have really taken off.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Again, it’s down to the two books. They are now stocked by three independent book shops, and have given me the opportunity to appear virtually at festivals and on panels. It’s increased my visibility, helped me know my niche, and made me more confident in myself as a writer. I don’t know whether it would have been different without the pandemic.
self_publishing_comments: I did it by crowdfunding. So there was a lot of time and effort (and stress!) spent on the month of the crowdfunding campaign. But once I had the money, I could then use that to pay a high-end self-publishing service, who did most of the other work for me.  It also meant that I had a good number of readers waiting for the books, which I packaged up and sent out (or distributed electronically via Book Funnel) once they were ready. I wasn’t able to do as much marketing in terms of book lunch and live appearances as I did with the first book (because of lockdown). But I had sent info to several independent book shops, and when lockdown was finished, they started contacting me.
Contractual_changes: I can’t think of any change. I have only worked with indie presses (magazines, anthologies etc.) and self-publishing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Newspapers cut back on reviewing.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: the increased uncertainty and the reduced availability of work as newspapers cut back on reviews etc has increased stress and anxiety
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Talks and meetings with clients have been cancelled. But that does mean I have saved a lot on petrol.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There hasn't been any effect.
Contract_clauses: I haven't had to sign any in the past year.
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Very little effect
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No effect
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I remain employed full time in an academic post and the pandemic has not affected my earnings. I am one of the lucky ones in that regard.
Contractual_changes: I have not experienced any significant changes in the last year.
Issues_Survey: As an academic writer of mainly research papers I don't feel best placed to address many of the concerns suggested by this survey. I remain interested to learn about developments nevertheless.
many are irrelevant, as I now write only in a voluntary capacity

Changed_contract_Negotiations: Date of submission

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am retired so it has had no impact on my earnings.
Issues_Survey: In 1987, I co-wrote an existing textbook with another teacher. I have been retired from teaching for over 20 years.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: With a partner obliged to shield from Covid, I have not been able to travel to do research. My earnings from freelance work were already very small. The mental impact has been mixed.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've marked positive because in one way, the enforced isolation has driven me to revisit projects that I care deeply about but had abandoned. There is no guarantee that they will 'earn' me anything in material terms, but their psychological and emotional importance for me personally are huge.   Other positives have come about by having access to on-line resources that are designed to encourage writers, reading a lot, and having access to a community where people talk to each other and are very creative.    The negative effect has been an increased sense of self-pity, hopelessness and worthlessness, being already 'out on a limb' (ie far from big cities, cultural stimulus including libraries), and already officially a pensioner, therefore at the end of the road and of no use to anyone.
self_publishing_comments: In the past three years, I've been making and posting videos to YouTube. A couple of them were paid commissions for documentaries, but most are self-generated projects. I don't make money from them, but would certainly like to.
Contractual_changes: I have sold the rights to a travel book which an online publisher had agreed to put out for me. The earnings from this book were negligible, and I was very disheartened by the state of affairs so I agreed to hand it over. The book has been removed from the publisher's website but is still on Amazon. All receipts from the sales there will go to her.
Issues_Survey: I'm glad to be asked, frankly. If anything I've said helps someone else to improve their lives, that would be great. In the meantime, I will keep buggering on.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Reduced book sales, inability to sell books at live events
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have experienced loss of earnings through a lack of commissions and residencies as arts organisations lost or had to redirect funding in 2020.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: This is difficult to weigh because I've been lucky enough to have time to write and have written a lot for my blog, online magazines and academic journals, but these are largely unpaid pursuits. The anxiety over having little to no income has prevented me from realising plans for new books I want to work on and I have been applying for jobs, which is also time-consuming and demoralising.
self_publishing_comments: It might not be what the question is getting at, but I produced a PDF study guide and am selling through my own online shop. I haven't looking into putting it on Kindle or other ebook sites, mainly as I had intended to use it as a foundational draft for a proposal to send to a traditional publisher. Other things have come up and I haven't got back to it. But all the time I spent on it was unpaid and I've sold one copy.
Issues_Survey: I think it would be useful to look at the impact of the UK leaving the EU as a factor in these issues alongside the Covid pandemic. I have also lost work as a proofreader for European academics as it's easier and cheaper for many to work with English speakers in the US now. Also the government's financial schemes were inaccessible to many freelance and self-employed writers. The lack of resources, income and the sheer anxiety of the whole situation has been detrimental to many of us who were just scraping by as it was.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was lucky in having income from a book deal, which sold internationally, but income from events and journalism has been substantially reduced, which makes it much harder to actually sell copies of books. Sales are definitely down, and as publications that previously offered review coverage or literary essays close, it's hard not to feel this is an ongoing trend.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Massive anxiety, two books came out during the pandemic, one did well, one did very badly. Impossible to tour but also to have the kind of encounters that might lead to commissions or coverage. A very frightening time.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Increased percentage by which publisher contributes to permissions
Issues_Survey: It's unclear whether you're asking in the first few questions about the individual's payment from various sources or general perception.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have also had to reduce my salaried work (from three days to two) in order to take greater care of my aged father; during the lockdowns I became his sole carer, cleaner, cook and visitor and had to reduce all work commitments accordingly.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Several publishers I work for furloughed their staff so all projects ground to a halt. Others simply put projects on hold and even now, some have not been restarted. Library borrowings fell substantially, as did photocopying of my books, and this has had  a great impact on my PLR and ALCS earnings.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Almost all of my publishers require me to sign an indemnity clause which means that I am liable for any and all costs if someone suggests that my work is not original or suchlike. I always change my contracts to stipulate that I am only liable if such claims are substantiated.   I have never sought legal advice on this matter, but found the recommendation to do this on an author's blog.
Contract_clauses: I think the warranty and indemnity clauses are a problem for authors like myself as we are expected to agree to pay a limitless sum in compensation for everyone else's costs if someone makes any spurious claim against us or our work. The publishers pass all the financial risk on to us, which is simply not fair.
Issues_Survey: I do not think the rates that authors get paid reflect their knowledge and experience. Rates rarely increase but the workload increases; I'm often asked to do picture research for example. I'm often asked to 'consult' on books which means a salaried editor (with no specialist knowledge) or a 'famous person' writes a book (full of basic errors and facts gleaned from the internet without references) and I am paid a piddling sum (perhaps just £200) to check it all and supply corrections with fully researched references. This is becoming more common, rather than just commissioning me, or someone like me (with the knowledge to get it right first time) to produce the text.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Brief period initially when first major lockdown occurred and sporting events I write about were cancelled. I received small government loan. Only needed that once. Return of sport restarted my regular paid work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Acted as the discipline required to keep me at my desk. So psychological boost to my working practice. Not so good for fitness and general health of course. Externally imposed lockdown was beneficial to work. Not unlike my time as prison writer in residence!
self_publishing_comments: I went initially through an agency to build a readership and clientele but have self published for the past year. Costs are nil given that internet is a household bill. I tried more conventional book publishing before that but promotion was the ball buster.After 20 years as a poet on the road, I had no desire to return to self promotion and have instead found a kind or writing/publishing that simply lets the writing do the talking. No need to advertise. Wish I'd had this facility as a young poet. Too old really now to make best use of it but am a contented old fart nevertheless!
Contractual_changes: Mainly I avoid contract work. Best working for myself.
Contract_clauses: Never trust a Tory is the only maxim I work by. Attempts to control or limit what I write have never been acceptable to me.This works best when I work with a professional editor of course. Only done that once or twice in my 40 year long career. I spent a great deal of early writing career giving my writing away for free. Still the best way to be a professional and enjoy it!
Issues_Survey: Only that it is assumed that money matters to writers and earnings likewise. Not all writers rate money. I come from banker and bookmaker stock and have also worked in both and that is where I think money belongs. Only money a writer really needs is the basic subsistence amount. So speaks a poet who has brought up three children on his professional earnings. With the help of a partner for the first two children. The third child was raised on my earnings alone. Never much. Always enough. The work the ALCS does is greatly revered however. But it is the act of writing itself that is the life force. Money is of little to no consequence.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Some books haven't sold as well as expected because of bad news breaking which has led me to being dropped by my publisher. Emotionally, it's been hard to write while stressed, homeschooling two primary-aged children and worrying.
self_publishing_comments: It cost a lot of money for an editor and cover design but the book just sank to the bottom of the Amazon rankings so I've taken it down and am now trying to sell it through my agent to a traditional publisher.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Lack of opportunity to promote books in person.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of access to archives to carry out research.
self_publishing_comments: The publisher promised more marketing than was delivered.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The Pandemic allowed me more time to write. Zoom meetings cut down on travel. Email and attachments were all that was required to get published. On the other hand, of course, libraries and bookshops were closed, but online purchases and e-books continued.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased stress, helped health - note how at the present mixing in large groups has increased infections.
self_publishing_comments: Marketing remains the biggest barrier and consumer of time. Electronic publishing (eg via Amazon) is very easy and cheap.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Reduced days for company.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Work has reduced due to companies we work for on hold. This has decreased our momentum and currently enthusiasm is less.
self_publishing_comments: Although not strictly self-publishing, I publish through my own Indie publishing company so it is seen that way. I make little money from it by the time I've paid printing costs, discounts and postage to Gardners. In fact I can't afford to be on Waterstones list or I would be paying them to stock my books.  My books are distributed to outlets in my region (about 30 miles radius) and are popular, they are on Amazon as ebooks, which helps income, otherwise it wouldn't be viable. I print about 300 books a year but there are now 11 books in the series - I wouldn't be doing it for the money!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I earn money through several sources. I work part-time as an A Level/GCSE examiner and obviously most exams stopped during the pandemic. I am writing some travel guides and had to cease research for these due to travel restrictions. However I was able to claim the SEISS grant.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As well as catching Covid myself, I also have family caring responsibilities and this impacted the time I could spend on work.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: With regard to the level of professional liability insurance required.
Contractual_changes: None in the last year or so, but in the last twenty years there seems to be something of a move from payment by royalty to payment by flat fee. (I mainly write school textbooks.)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of fees from festivals and writing workshops, and potential loss of royalties from inability to promote new books.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of community.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write, and the peace to write fiction which I have never done before.
Issues_Survey: Yes, you didn't leave a don't know space for an entry I couldn't answer

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No difference - all submissions via email.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Difficult to get hold of research materials due to library closures.
self_publishing_comments: Used an online service which supplied an incompetent cover designer, but was refunded. Found good cheap formatter and good cover designer via personal recommendation. Low expenses, but due to poor marketing skills (and reluctance to devote sufficient energy to marketing) have probably just recouped investment.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I don't know if you'd call it integrity, but they copyrighted the book in their name, not mine, and are very protective of possible film rights, etc., though they let people create terrible plays based on it without even charging.
Issues_Survey: Per-word rates haven't changed for at least fifty years, and though I know publications are struggling, so are writers! Looking at my earnings compared to my husband's (the family income) certainly made  me feel embarrassed. Copywriting seems to be the only profitable angle. Don't know if this is any use.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No teaching

year: Fewer academic books sold

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I'm a novelist and screenwriter, my working life has not been affected, but my sales were very much affected as my book was being promoted in bookshops - specifically ones at stations and airports - at the exact time of the first lockdown. Closed bookshops, and Amazon selling books so, so cheaply means poor sales. My latest book sold to my publisher for less as a result. My husband is an architect and his income has been moderately affected. We have spent less on travel, probably - but more on other things.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress very high. Productivity about the same.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It hasn't, as we have both worked from for many years
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It prompted me to return to novel writing
self_publishing_comments: An interesting and relatively painless experience, with the help of my children. The worst part is the need for relentless self-promotion on Facebook, Twitter, etc
Contractual_changes: The publishers want more rights for less money

Importance_Other_Name: Copywriting and social media and digital marketing
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I left London just before the covid-19 pandemic started in 2020. This was because of poor health and needing to rebuild my life. During the past two years, I have built a decent self-employed business, as I can afford to work from home and rent alone in South Yorkshire. The pandemic gave me an opportunity to gradually get better - being diagnosed as autistic in February 2020. I had no meetings or pressure from the DWP/Jobcentre between March 2020 and October 2021. This gave me the time and space to slowly rebuild my life, meaning I was declared gainfully self employed by the DWP.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Being able to spend over a year in mostly solitude, less social interaction, fewer demands, less noise...was very helpful for recovery from autistic burnout and starting to write again.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: The publisher having complete international rights and I having no copyright.
Contract_clauses: Global exclusive rights but did not sign and secured own rights

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was lucky in that my contract on a university research project was totally unaffected by covid.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It opened up the writing community to me. I was able to be in contact with writers all over the world, attending far more workshops and meeting more people than I would have otherwise. This revitalised my practice and allowed me to feel very supported. However, the stress of the pandemic in its later stages, when the rules became harder to interpret, increased my stress and anxiety levels and made writing far more difficult. I wrote far less after the initial six months of covid.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As a freelance musician I earned £50 for one gig in 2019/20. Normally it might be between £1500 - £2000.  Cars have inconsequence been driven less, about 8000 miles less.   Heating costs rose a bit  - at home nearly 100% of the time. Pales into insignificance compared to with 2022 rises!  Ate out less, bought no takeaways after lockdown. No that we do either of these things much.  Holidays not taken. We've had one night away from home since 2020 lockdown, normally might have ben 25-30 a year including holidays. So money saved, some of it spent on (mildly neglected) exterior of property. Window cleaner of 25 years asked if we were downsizing..... We're not.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No longer writing, so very little difference. I don't do conferences any more, don't write or mark GCSE papers since 2017, but leave to younger folk these joys.  I have taught myself to play the piano accordion - a tribute to my wife's patience.  Playing with other musicians is beginning to take place, though I'm still cautious about venues. But I played a Burns night ceilidh last weekend - surprisingly well-attended.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No effect
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No effect
Contract_clauses: Not applicable - no clauses in contracts signed that I thought were problematic.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Project for writing web materials dropped March 2020
Contractual_changes: Over the last ten years a relentless drive by major school publishers (e.g. Pearson, OUP, Hodder) to drive down royalties, and also, in publishing for exam syllabuses, to force all writers across the series to accept a small share in the royalty of the whole series, rather than a royalty on the book they write. Twenty years ago they didn't worry if they didn't cover unpopular options, or, paid a fee for those books on which they tried out new authors. Ten years ago the fee arrangement was more common, but shared royalty schemes were growing. This isn't all bad for authors - the one writing a depth study on Alfred the Great will get more money (but takes a real risk on the quality of the key books in the series, like the Nazi Germany depth study. For experienced and successful authors such a me, who usually write on of the key books in the series, is has considerably reduced my earnings.
Contract_clauses: US - US rights when companies are multinational

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: little effect on earnings, except possibly some small savings on travel
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no effect
Issues_Survey: NO

Importance_Other_Name: Authoring of English Language Teaching materials e.g. graded readers
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My non-writing work continued as usual, but I was in the middle of a big project so that may have been luck. My book deal didn't land until December 2020, so it's hard to know how it may have affected my writing career.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's meant fewer or no in-house meetings with publishers and agents which has impacted on relationship building and general morale. Writing is lonely enough as it is, without Covid making things worse!
Changed_contract_Negotiations: In a two-book deal, the advance is accounted against both books, rather than split between two titles. This means it takes longer for advance to earn out and if the first book is successful but book 2 less so, the author doesn't reap the benefits.
Contractual_changes: n/a as I only signed one contract so far
Contract_clauses: As previously - amalgamation of advances over titles. Also - is it really an advance if it gets paid in instalments, half of which seems to be on publication of various formats!
Issues_Survey: I have written for fixed fees and assigned my rights to the publishers for educational writing - but this is standard practice nowadays.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have probably been more distracted, less productive, and less able to establish health work/home boundaries.

Member_ALCS_year: Chartered Institute of Bankers, now known as LIBF (1963) Fellow since 1999.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Nothing.
Contractual_changes: My last book was written in 2013, so nothing to report.
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Possible loss of income due to cancelled events, as I launched two books during the pandemic and was unable to do in-person events. I also had to delay various writing projects while homeschooling children.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity and increased stress, pressure to write while in a full house. Less able to research at libraries or attend conferences, fewer promotional opportunities. As a writer releasing my first books, this may have affected the profile I have been able to build.
Contractual_changes: None that I have noticed, but I got an agent and began negotiating larger contracts fairly recently, so I don't have much to compare it to.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of potential income from public appearances.
Issues_Survey: Another question which could be asked is the total of outgoings relating to writing - for example, research costs, fees to Society of Authors, maintenance of websites.  For writers with a low gross income from writing, these can amount to quite a lot - in my case for 2020/21, the total outgoings were 25% of my writing income.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel, eating out, attending meetings with other people, food buying, shopping,  gifts, interaction with other human beings, savings on club memberships, and all sorts of untold non-spending activities while living a cave-like existence.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety and stress +++  More so as I'm old and living alone.  No hope or future for the grandchildren and their children, if the beautiful world I grew up in is no more because of abuse of our planet through technological strides, climate change and an ever-increasing world-wide population to feed. Not to mention another horrendous pandemic the young ones are now in fear of.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Terms of copywrite on 12 German e-book contract from UK backlist of hardback and paperback editions of my books, advised by SoA to ask for 5 years not 7 years, but in absence of an agent, signed for 7 years for an advance I needed at the time.
Contractual_changes: So much, I can't begin to tell it all here.  I was first published in 1985, it was hard then, it's a virtual jungle now.  I write for myself now, because it is my life, and while I still want to continue to educate, entertain and inform my readership, I am disillusioned by the whole publishing setup.   Perhaps my grandchildren will inherit the earth and the works thereof!
Contract_clauses: Yes, a 5 year contract advised, but the publisher wanted 7 years, and that's what happened.
Issues_Survey: Exhausting!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: So many people are struggling financially, that selling my services to other authors is near on impossible. You can't charge people if they don't have money to spend. The need is high, but the cash flow is minimal
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My emotional book club fiction debut was put on hold for publication due to 'readers not wanting to read emotional fiction during a pandemic' - which meant me not having an area of the market to sell my fiction books to. The attitude of editors during a pandemic meant I had no area of the industry to work in.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: None.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have done almost no writing.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I tried to negotiate royalties as opposed to a flat fee.
self_publishing_comments: None.  I published tweets online for free.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had too many read-for-free events.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I can't do any more Meet the Author events.
self_publishing_comments: I have spent a small fortune on editors, sensitivity readers, cover designers, and formatters.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: very little as we have no children and academic life has carried on
Loss of earningsfrom giving retreats workshops, etc.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less interest/activity from publishers, decreased publicity effort
Changed_contract_Negotiations: reversion of rights when a title goes out of print or is remaindered

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: no impact
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Sales dropped. A large income was from signed copies at book shows and air shows. These were cancelled. Expenses reduced through lack of travel.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I was forced to close my business as sales plummeted and no chance to top up with show sales. Overheads remained high but income reduced. It has caused me to reduce my writing to a minimum.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs and moving in with family while working from home (not having to pay rent)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stressed but also increased opportunity to attend online events, courses, and workshops
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I proposed an advance and was offered an hourly rate for work for hire. Did not refer to model contract.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: The publisher sought to use my work in a way I deemed harmful to my reputation as an author (NFTs). Dispute is ongoing.

Issues_Survey: Although I receive royalties and payments for copying I am no longer an active writer

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write, and made up my mind to take early retirement and focus on my writing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact on my earnings which are from my UK retirement pensions and royalties from ALCS, HarperCollins Publishers and Cambridge University Press.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I retired from writing Primary Mathematics Schemes for my publishers in 2015.
Contractual_changes: Not applicable as I am now retired.
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No change just harder work!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lots of extra work and now having to make videos to support educational materials which takes ages.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs, hotels, etc. Furlough payments Loss of training work in schools
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More opportunities for online training work, authoring videos, wider reach due to international opportunities. More time for writing.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Yes, I use the Society of Authors service and also my own knowledge of their advice from previous occasions.
Contractual_changes: I have done some work for a large publisher where it is more a 'work for hire' model than a royalty model. This is fine for me, as royalties from sales tend to go down over time and for the type of materials involved I don't see any need to have my name on them.
Contract_clauses: I was asked to sign a contract recently which was effectively a 'work for hire' but where the terms were more akin to a royalty model contract. I am still negotiating the staged payments.
Issues_Survey: You should include 'prefer not to say' in the ethnicity question

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not able to get creative due to worrying and also trying to keep the family business going. It’s now closed (family business) so hopefully will get back to writing ✍️
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress and worry, also knocked my confidence- thank you so much ALCS for making me know that writing is my aim/destiny.
Issues_Survey: Just thank you for your support x 😊✍️

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Big savings on commuting travel and travelling subsistence; I also got promoted but that was nothing to do with Covid!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There is less time overall; academic employment is in a funding spiral and consequent panic, and the digital pivot and the government's outsourcing of its concern for students onto academics rather than the support workers the fees won't pay for has added considerably to workloads.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Consequences for breach, start date; no.
Contractual_changes: None; the only such agreements I deal in at the moment are journal copyright permissions, which have stayed the same as far as I can see
Issues_Survey: I am much less of a professional writer than the people you were thinking of when you made this survey!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I don't understand this question. My earnings have increased but nothing to do with Covid - simply that I got a good publishing deal just before the start of lockdown and the first royalties filtered through just in time to be recorded in my 2020/21 tax return.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Inability to visit archives, museums, places for research. No face to face meetings with other writers for mutual support, no conferences or RNA chapter meetings. Plus huge Zoom-related stress!
Changed_contract_Negotiations: First refusal on subsequent works

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: N/A - I had my first book published in March 2021
Contractual_changes: NONE - I HAVE ONLY JUST PUBLISHED MY FIRST BOOK
Issues_Survey: NO

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Because I am retired (86) it's had little or no impact.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has given me time to compile and publish a collection of pieces I wrote for a magazine called World Medicine in the 1970s.
Contractual_changes: So far as I know, none.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Initially my non wrting work more or less ceased for some 3-6 months, but then picked up as more and more could be done online
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Enabled me to complete another book a year ahead of schedule
Issues_Survey: NO

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: nothing negative
Issues_Survey: only to say that Q59 omits Northern Ireland as a place of residence

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More flexibility for writing
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Fix error in contract
Issues_Survey: Lack of clarity in some questions. Some are leading questions.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: inflation is far higher than claimed, utilities have increased and I have not been getting any overtime.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: decreased productivity, anxiety, stress and hospitalisation for COVID-19 (and the long recovery period).
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I needed to extend my book deadline as I was unable to write for six months following COVID-19. My publisher was very obliging and agreed a mutually helpful date.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More time to write and independently publish at my own pace, therefore increasing my income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity
Contractual_changes: None. I am independently published so make the decisions which are best for me.
Issues_Survey: Too focused on traditional publishing when indie authors are making a small fortune in the publishing industry.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No casual payments for other duties, I would have normally been paid. Basic pay only.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Made me realise I want to be a full time writer although I didn't write much over the first lockdown.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs and social life
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Impossibility of travel to work with my main co-author (Asia based)
Contractual_changes: The pressure to publish open access with a CC-BY licence. It is usually possible to add NC and/or ND by negotiation but academics are increasingly encouraged to publish CC-BY, which, in the humanities and social sciences, allows misrepresentation of one's work, quoting/citing out of context as well as commercial publishers making money from one's work without permission or recompense.   I haven't seen ALCS take up this issue - it bothers academics far more than what we earn from writing (which is a pittance). It affects me less now that I have retired and no longer have the institutional requirements to publish CC-BY

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less work and in the first year (2020) a significant drop in royalties earnings.
Serious lifestyle changes allowed me to even out the damage.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have needed to focus on non-writing work in order to make ends meet.
Issues_Survey: N/A

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No lecture fees.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity

year: Lack of creative stimulus
Lack of ability to bounce ideas off other people in the same way as before (Zoom lectures etc a poor substitute)
Allowance for images
Books_Educational: clause advising no tweets to be made that might damage sales of book

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Almost all my income is from pensions, so some questions re not particularly relevant.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not relevant
Contract_clauses: Yes - when Crown copyright takes away Intellectual Property Right

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Fewer paid invitations to speak
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Since retirement I have always worked from home, using my own library; so no change

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: There was increased demand for corporate copywriting services as a result of the pandemic. People wanted to communicate more. My earnings increased by over 10% as a result.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: This is a hard question to answer because Covid-19 had a positive impact on my earnings. I am not sure it benefitted me personally though. I have felt cut off from contacts and made fewer visits to London. Also, I probably overworked at times. I wonder if potentially it will have a negative impact going forwards because of the impact on networking and also clients moving to different jobs after reevaluating their lives. Interestingly, my work is actually tailing off a bit now.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I didn't change a written contract, but I got a pay rise.
Contractual_changes: I don't know about changes - sometimes I think a lack of changes is the issue. Freelance journalists are often being paid the same rate per word by publications that they were paid 10 years ago. Inflation is not being factored in at all. I put my prices up for my corporate work, but I do less journalism now because of the poor pay.
Issues_Survey: I hardly have any contracts for the work I do as a copywriter, journalist and editor. So I don't have much in the way of protection. I do have a contract for the book I wrote.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less opportunity to earn from poetry because venues were closed and live readings weren't an option. Most poetry books are sold at readings. My book was also caught in Bertrams folding with the loss of royalties from sales not passed back to the publisher. Copies of my book had been distributed to bookshops on a sale or return basis and the bookshops that closed and didn't have a webstore returned the books anyway despite not giving them chance to sell.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My writing productivity stayed the same. Although not being able to do live poetry readings did impact book sales, being able to do online events (Zoom, Facebook, YouTube, etc) opened opportunities to participate in readings held in Australia, Canada and venues in the UK I wouldn't normally be able to travel to. I also review and was overwhelmed with review requests because poets realised reviews were a good way to keep news of their books in circulation with venues shut.

Issues_Survey: Ethnic origin should be alphabetical not white first. Some questions could be better written. Confused a out last year, is it complete tax years or last 12 months?

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Teaching in person one-to-one was much more lucrative than online teaching, and quite a large proportion of monthly income.  These have stopped and not resumed.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, probably because of lack of travel!  I suspect the lack of social contact also meant that there were opportunities that didn't arise.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Reversion of rights to author if no reprinting,  various other points suggested by SOA reviewers.  All points were accepted, primarily because they had been accepted in the past.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Given me more writing time as I was isolating
self_publishing_comments: Over the ten years I've been writing I produced fourteen books - nine children's books, four humorous books for the inner child in all adults, and ghost authored one. All told, I would say I've spent £15,000 on covers designs, editors and copy writers, illustrations, and marketing. My returns have amounted to no more than £1,000 in total.  More recently, with my children's books, because they deal with emotional wellbeing, I've been making them freely available to reading charities and overseas (developing countries) primary schools. To date, I've given away some 150,000 books - eBooks or the writes to freely copy.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had an unexpectedly high-earning year during Covid because I couldn't do the travel I would have done otherwise. My travel costs have also reduced due to a relocation to a city with better research resources, so not all of the change is down to Covid.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's a bit early to say. When I found my social life completely cancelled in lockdown (I live alone) I spent some time experimenting with a book in a new genre. If this sells, then I'm going to say that's a very positive impact! If it doesn't, I think the experience will. still have a positive effect on my wider writing career. On the other hand, the pandemic has meant having to completely reschedule research and writing on my main contracted book: I'm lucky that I haven't had to move deadlines because I was at the beginning of a writing cycle with time to spare, but it hasn't been ideal.
Decreased productivity but more access to online events which were previously in person events only
self_publishing_comments: Costs incurred for cover design, advertising and marketing expenses not yet recouped so don't expect to make a profit this year or next.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: TV shows I had in developed were either paused for up to a year or were cancelled all together.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Same answer as above
Changed_contract_Negotiations: My agent agreed for more favourable terms

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not really. It does not affect academic research.

year: I am a teacher at a little school and give mostly individual lessons. So the income remained almost the same.
Main_income: Increased productivity. Much more free time,
Importance_Other: I do academic work. My publications are mainly on the platform www.academia.edu There are no costs incurred, the publications can be easily accessed by the specialists in my field (which is good), but there is no payment for time spent on research, recovery of expenses for the research, academic paper itself and usage of my research by readers.

Issues_Survey: Most questions irrelevant to me as I haven't written anything for at least a decade, although I still get ALCS payments

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am retired and COVID has not affected my pensions
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Sales, and in particular page reads in Kindle Unlimited increased significantly in 2021. Whether this was a direct result of COVID, I cannot say.  Apart from that, the isolation due to COVID was very stressful, coming, as it did, not long after my husband's sudden and unexpected death.   However, although I found it hard sometimes to write, the support from the online writing community helped alleviate the isolation.
self_publishing_comments: For 2020  Total Gross Income  31,544.14  Less expenditure 6209.75 total net income  25,334.39   I spend at least an hour a day on marketing and admin  Expenditure   includes marketing, research materials (I write historical fiction), publishing costs (e.g. proof-reading, formatting, cover design including cost of cover images, ISBNs,), IT, stationery, membership of associations, In other years, there could also be travel for research purposes or to attend conferences.
Issues_Survey: As I live in Ireland, my earnings are reported in Euros and refer to the Irish tax years (= calendar years) of 2020 and 2021  Many writers living in Ireland are able to avail themselves of the Creative Artists' exemption under which royalties are tax-free to a maximum of €50,000 per annum.  You will find further information from the Revenue Commissioners at revenue.ie

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs from not commuting by train into the office every day though some increased spending on household bills from increased electricity and gas due to working from home.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity due to anxiety at the beginning of the pandemic.
Contractual_changes: I have no experience in contractual practices as all my work is self-published.
Contract_clauses: I have no experience in contractual practices as all my work is self-published.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I left my job as a Head of Department in a secondary school because I had long Covid, and took early retirement
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My publications were A level revision guides, and A levels were cancelled for two years running, so sales plummeted. Also I stopped writing blogs for teachers (for which I was paid by OUP, because exams were cancelled, and because I had then left teaching.
self_publishing_comments: Just a blog, but I may turn it into a book

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My role became more important and I was asked to go full time instead of part-time. Reduction in cost of travel, too.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Burnout. Stress of home schooling while working full time. No/limited access to archives for historical research (I write nonfiction local history).
Issues_Survey: PLR was terrible this year. I write local history and not a single library in the eastern region is in the sample!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Even though my take-home earnings went up overall, this was due to royalties/advance payments agreed pre-pandemic. My advances during the pandemic were reduced by a third and I would have also earned more through school visits.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It had a negative impact in the early days because of having to juggle my writing work with a homeschooling family and a husband at home, all fighting for WiFi access and workspace. There are some positives though, particularly the wealth of interesting writing courses now available online and accessible regardless of location.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Minor changes recommended by the SoA, e.g. asking for them to consult me over adaptations/abridgements/ approval of certain usage.
Contractual_changes: One publisher has begun to charge storage/distribution costs. They also tried to charge these costs on books already published, by deducting the costs from royalties, but (along with another small group of authors), I contested this and they refunded the deductions.

Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I did have a consultancy startup before Covid, which had to fold almost immediately
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity
self_publishing_comments: Gah! Marketing! Does my head in. Especially with no opportunity to attend local fairs, etc.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Clashed with retirement

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I did have a staff writer job, in addition to freelance work, and went fully self-employed just prior to the pandemic. Instead of pursuing writing, as the opportunities quickly dried up, I took on a salaried role that is not writing related. As a newly full time self employed person, I didn’t qualify for furlough or the SEISS grants. I still manage to obtain some freelance writing work but nowhere near enough for a sustainable income.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More on-line teaching
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity at home

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Publication delayed for a year, bookshops closed, libraries closed. Festivals & schools closed.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As previous question but new opportunities have also arisen, including new writing projects & developing online events for schools so less time is spent  travelling.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have found it harder to write due to massive mental health issues brought on by the pandemic, and to connect with the publishing industry due to lack of physical events. My earnings have mostly been from books written/published before the pandemic, with a substantial slow-down in production I expect to have a knock-on effect.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Massively decreased productivity due to stress and anxiety, especially in 2020. Also, a lack of communication from publishers due to their own pandemic-related problems (two of my editors moved on and another suffered huge staff changes) which has affected communication to the effect that I had time to write a whole book before getting feedback on an outline.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Specific clauses regarding writing for other publishers with whom I already had an arrangement; also a couple of clauses confusingly worded or in conflict, ie “we will not be asking for dramatic rights” and then “we will be asking for XYZ dramatic rights”. There was no problem with altering these.  The SoA did reference industry standards as regards royalties but as what I was offered fit that standard, I didn’t ask for change.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Childcare responsibilities increased
More time to write. I also had some very encouraging feedback which helped me to write more.
self_publishing_comments: Kindle Direct Publishing has made self pub

year: Ishing delightfully easy and cost free. I love it.
Books_Games: Well done, and thanks for everything

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time available in longer periods to focus and write, with fewer other distractions. A very productive time.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: The publishers (OUP) believed that an appointed editor had the right to alter, edit and amend my work without consent.
Issues_Survey: Too much confidential information required.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Believe that Covid may make agents less likely to take me on as a new client, despite me being shortlisted in a major National competition and being longlisted in several others, since a number of agents have requested a full manuscript and then gone silent on me.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My ptoductivity has stayed more or less the same.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I mostly earn royalties, and as book sales have decreased around the world, this has slightly affected my self-employed income.

No negative impact as far as I am personally concerned.

Issues_Survey: Some of the questions are impossible to answer as I am retired.

Importance_Other_Name: Academic teaching (I selected this as main source of income on previous page)
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: We were able to continue salaried work online. Schools and festival visits stopped, but I took a government grant to top that up.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The government grant lessened the financial impact. However, I waas badly affected creatively and found it very difficult to produce work as a result of the stress of the wider situation.
