Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: N/A
Issues_Survey: Publishers are increasingly reluctant to pay for ANYTHING, and it is very difficult to get a decent remuneration for the time spent on researching and writing. It is not a gripe, but a fact.

Contractual_changes: Less radio production. Podcasts overtaking broadcasts
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of household earnings through furlough Fewer events, opportunities to promote book and do workshops Thankfully online writing work (game writing, for example) was unaffected
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More anxiety about the future, which means less creative productivity
Changed_contract_Negotiations: In 2018-19 I successfully changed a contract I was offered with the help of the SoA (the publisher changed most clauses to a different base contract, more in alignment with the SoA's requirements - so yes, this was a minimum terms/model contract situation, where the publisher's initial contract had been heavily biased against the author)  In 2020-21, I was dealing with a bigger publisher and an agent, and successfully negotiated some clauses (retaining gaming rights, for example) whilst being unsuccessful with others (retaining French-speaking rights so I could do the translation myself, for example)  SoA - Society of Authors
Contractual_changes: In game writing for text-based games, the royalty rates start at the ebook rate (25%) but went up slightly the next two years (26, then 27%)
Contract_clauses: This agreement shall automatically terminate if the Publisher allows the Work to go out of print or it becomes only available in print-on-demand formats, within three months of written notice from the Author. - I feel this clause should have included 'only available in print-on-demand or ebook formats' but the publisher refused to include ebooks.  A clause in my contract was changed: "Our proposal for the future is to set the royalty for print books to 12% of net sales receipts (money we’ve received) for printed books. By ‘net sales receipts’ I mean money we have received for sales, less returns and discounts, but completely ignoring our costs." Before, the publisher offered 14% royalties over their net benefice. I think the 2% royalty cuts should have been properly negotiated, and the advantages/disadvantages properly discussed, before this was put in place.
Issues_Survey: Thank you for doing this survey - it is important to know how much authors are earning to be able to properly help/support them

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had less translation work, so as a self-employed freelance translator I was entitled to a SEISS grant from the government. This is part of tax calculations for that year.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I was fortunately enough to sign with another publisher during the Covid-19 pandemic, but this wasn't because of Covid-19, so all in all it hasn't had a significant impact. The stress I suffered was due to the writing deadline, but this has had a positive outcome because I now have a new book out and a potential for a higher writing income in next tax year.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
self_publishing_comments: Putting a self-published Christmas book on Kindle was relatively easy. I engaged a freelance editor and cover artist before I published it, costing me £200 (mate rates), and I paid a blog tour organisor £65 for a week-long blog tour to help me market the book. So far, the book hasn't made enough to cover the costs of production. I think it drowned in a crowded Christmas ebook market.
Contractual_changes: My previous publisher offered me a contract for a book, which was a very restrictive contract, and on taking advice from the Society of Authors, I decided not to sign with them again and instead self-publish the book. The rights to my previous works with that publisher have now reverted to me.
Contract_clauses: On advice from the Society of Authors I decided not to sign a restrictive contract, which would essentially have tied me to them indefinitely.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No school visits - but no longer do many so the decrease is marginal
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have been in a state of limbo since the first lockdown and disinterested in

year: writing/working.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had just begun touring schools and venues running workshops around my debut children's book. Of course these were cancelled and I haven't as yet been able to book any more. Had the pandemic not happened, I would have expected my earnings to increase substantially from these workshops and events.  My husband was also made redundant and is currently re-training also contributing to our overall loss of earnings.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Homeschooling my kids meant less time for work - and at a point when the youngest had just started nursery so the extra time I anticipated having for work evaporated. Also, anxiety, stress and a too-full house made creation trickier at times.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Theatre production cancelled

year: Theatre production postponed and then hit by low audiences after Omicron wave
Near collapse of school visit and festival income
Publication delayed because of closed bookshops
Main_income: Limited ability to promote and sell books in person at events Lack of real world networking and interaction with other writers Reduced travel, affecting research possibilities and inspiration opportunities No school visits acted as brake on career development - virtual visits no substitute for meeting teachers, librarians and children as real person. Stressful as projects disappeared or were postponed before my eyes Hard to write in first lockdown as emotionally engaged in managing shock and stress Need to experience life to write about it Frustrating to see good work not maximising earning potential because of reduced promotional opportunities, closed bookshops and low theatre attendance.
Member_ALCS: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of speaking appointments and the consequent loss of book sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Fewer speaking engagements but more time to think and write.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I wrote more books. People bought more of my books.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I don't believe it had any impact on my professional life - only on my personal life. I wrote more books but I've done that in other years when there wasn't a pandemic, so any increased productivity was simply due to more time to write and to me wanting to make more money. It wasn't directly as a result of Covid-19.
self_publishing_comments: All my books are self-published - by choice. I've had offers from publishers but always rejected them.  I hate marketing and am rubbish at it, so I don't do any. I could make a lot more money if I did and it is something I need to address at some stage. I hire a professional editor and a website designer/manager.
Contractual_changes: None. I don't enter into contracts.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less purchase by educational institutions dealing with covid

I write textbooks for business management students. With disruption to teaching, it seemed that students were not buying books. My main textbook, however, has a companion website that would be helful in these circumstances. I am perhaps unusual, and I have no contacts with other writers, so I do not know there experiences. I should add that my publisher was taken over by another company in June 2021. There were problems with my former publisher paying my royalties. Therefore, the reduced royalties I received in the autumn of 2021 seemed to reflect this situation.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It was very stressful. I suffer from stress anyway. The changing of publisher was also stressful. The publishers tend to treat authors like me simply as service or goods suppliers, not as part of their organization.  These are major publishers who need to behave in decent ways to retain authors. Authors are not like employees, who were transferred automatically in a takeover. I was kept in the dark about whether the book I am currently writing would be taken up by the new publisher.  It was, but it was months before a contract came through. The anxiety caused the flare-up of a medical condition which I suffer from (I have attacks that last 2-3 days, and I can't work). I got tablets for these in the summer of 2020, and I have been much better since then.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No.  I succeeded in getting a change of terms on payment of royalties twice a year, rather than once a year. I have complained about a number of terms, but found I had accepted them in previous contracts (unwittingly).
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: The company that was my former publisher allowed some chapters from one of my books to be included in a course textbook put together by a teacher, who used it in a tailormade book for his course. He put his name on the cover of this book as the author, even though it included my chapters. And he listed the book on his CV with himself as the author. My publisher refused to do anything about this. I blamed my editor for this, and asked for a new editor, as relations had broken down. This did not happen. I hope my new publisher would not allow this kind of thing to happen.
Contractual_changes: Basically, neglect by the publisher. I get no timely answers to queries, sometimes no answer at all.  My feeling has been that, as they are working at home, they are not really keeping track of things.
Contract_clauses: No, not quite. I was so relieved to receive a contract at all, that I just accepted it.
Issues_Survey: It has made me go back and look at the contract I signed last August, which I didn't read properly. I would say you have raised all the right issues - things that have concerned me for years (this is my 22nd year of writing).

Importance_Other_Name: sample translations used to sell books to various markets
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My 2019-20 earnings are not representative of previous earnings. 2020-21 was slower in terms of income, although a reduction in expenses alleviated that to some extent.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Periods of inactivity and extreme stress, followed by periods of extreme activity without any rest. When the work comes, you have to take it, no matter how it affects your personal/home life.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Royalties, rates, copyright, crediting. I always refer to a model contract but publishers rarely follow it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Opportunities to supplement my meagre earnings from writing with other kinds of work has decreased
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not been ablate do unperson readings where I can sell books. Also increased anxiety and uncertainty about the future

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: They have only increased because I published another book in 2020 which lead to another batch of sales. I was at the stage where I was hoping to get earnings from author visits, but that obviously didn't happen.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I found the first lockdown very peaceful, in spite of having to home school children and keep on working. The clutter of constant demands from the world died down and I wrote one children's book that will be out this summer, one fairytale that was published in British Fantasy Society's magazine just before Christmas and two picture books that are coming out early 2023 and in the summer of 2024.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I negotiated more free copies of my book, from 10 to 25 and negotiated an advance from £0 to £400. This was on the advice of other authors published by the same publishers and not from a professional body.
Contract_clauses: One publisher doesn't produce audio books and don't want me to go elsewhere for those rights either.
Issues_Survey: I didn't understand some of the questions, the ones about copyright for example assumed some background knowledge, which perhaps I ought to have, but don't. Also the questions about earnings weren't entirely clear to me. There was no box for author visits.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I write about exhibitions in galleries and museums; the closure of these spaces meant drastically less commissions
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It gave me space to work on a book of literary nonfiction, away from the deadlines of art publishing
Issues_Survey: Working as a freelance art critic, publishing mainly in specialist periodicals (which are not academic), while also writing contributions to books that museums and galleries publish, I don't quite qualify as a 'journalist' (the NUJ wouldn't have me!) or write 'journalism' or 'nonfiction popular'. As such the survey felt geared towards other forms of writer
No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I changed the way I work. So I no longer do any schools visits, which used to something I did a lot of.  But I do more teaching at university.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety, stress, noise - hugely decreased writing productivity. I didn't write at all during Covid 19.
Issues_Survey: I've used ALCS's survey results in my teaching so I'm familiar with the general decline in writers' incomes.  I fear the trend is continuing.  Many of the writers I know are now only able to survive through teaching.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Furlough and isolation time without full pay. Writing earning have stayed around the same.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Balance of being able to attend online gigs and workshops and feeling less isolated balanced against the fact online audiences do not tend to buy books and I have had time to write more in furlough around home schooling and found a new paying avenue for some of my already published poems. I have written more to make sense of the world and about the new opening up and pockets of normal and adventures in the rare times we could do these and when things started to open up again.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less magazine work (travel features) and more guidebook work in 20/21 than 19/20. The financial impact will actually be felt more in 21/22, because I am used to being paid on publication, often a year after delivering features. Lack of travel means that magazines don't have my usual stock of material, for which I would gradually be paid.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've marked 'no impact' because the pandemic has had both positive and negative impacts that have balanced out. My earnings have been hit longer term, but I've had time to work on my own narrative non-fiction and to do a lot of online training, taking my writing in new directions.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I referred to SoA guidance, but magazine publisher was adamant about grabbing more rights than previously.
Contractual_changes: Publishers wanting to take more rights so that they can exploit work in multiple ways in print and online.
Contract_clauses: Yes, because they weren't in plain English and I couldn't get absolute clarification of what they meant.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Online courses income has increased. more writing time has led to the publication of two additional successful books, which has also increased back catalogue revenue.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress from government mishandling, pressure to accept vaccination, restrictions, and impact on family mental health. Family member unemployment and sense of despondency about future impacts on those working from home. But also a positive effect in less pressure to accept in person speaking engagements and more time to write at home.
self_publishing_comments: Brilliant. Have done this for several years. Am far better paid than when I was traditionally published; approx 40% royalty compared to the 5-10% offered by my traditional publisher (and then on heavily discounted book price). Can't see myself ever going back to traditional publishing.
Contractual_changes: Lower royalty. Less consideration for authors.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress, impact on working hours with added childcare and lack of working space in the house.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The sales of physical books (2 hardbacks and a paperback in my case) that were launched during the pandemic were impacted as bookshops were closed, or harder to access. Although additional library loans, once the libraries opened again, seem to be reflected in the most recent PLR statement (more recent than the ones mentioned above)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's a solitary occupation, so I carried on much as before. There were times it was hard to write, but it's hard to know whether they would have happened anyway. And it was harder to go to places to research, but much of that can be done online, too.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Only in terms of the money on offer as an advance
Contractual_changes: None, other than a reduction in fees
Issues_Survey: It feels increasingly that the authors are at the bottom of the pile in terms of earnings (unless they are very fortunate), while the publishers increase their profits but fail to provide anything like a living wage to the writers on whom they rely.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No real change except inconvenience
self_publishing_comments: You are always taking a risk in the outlay for design, permissions and printing, etc. the reduction of outlets with the rise of Amazon and the almost monopoly enjoyed by Waterstones which crushed any number of independent bookshops very adversely affected my sales, since my publications pertain to geographically very discrete areas.
Contractual_changes: None, as I have signed no new contracts
Issues_Survey: I had a lot of uncertainty about the tax figures submitted - I kept on wondering about definitions but assumed individual earnings did include the figure below, for self-employed writing

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Saving on travel costs, but spent more on heating.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Had to spend a lot of time home-schooling my children, so had to work around that.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Amount of pay

year: schedule of pay
addition of ACLS quit clause
Books_Educational: Producers still not putting in ALCS quit clause and not wanting to, though that's not really a change...  Producers wanting to pay even less up front, or even nothing at all...
Books_Games: Any buyout contract for animation writing is fundamentally unfair given that it is the exact same job as writing for live action TV, yet does not attract royalties or WDP payments. This is and always will be 100% unfair.
Broadcasting: Animation writers should be paid the same as other writers, and be able to collect WDP.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I quit full-time work as a content writer at a tech company (last salary was around 45k) to deliberately launch myself as a freelance writer. I work from home, so I have no costs in terms of commuting, buying lunches out or other associated expenses.  Since then, I've almost doubled my earnings from 2020.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I launched myself freelance last year, and I've grown in skills, confidence and experience. Clients seek me out, not the other way around. I have a unique skillset — a PhD, background in journalism, and a focus in HR technology. Since quitting my full-time job I get to pick only the projects I love doing, and the clients I want to work with.
Unable to attend events.
Unable to do future work during the pandemic - this will result in a loss of royalties in the future
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: At first my work stopped almost completely and I was eligible for support schemes like SEISS, but then when work started up again, I got a lot all in one go, which meant my earnings actually went up a bit over the last year.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has been much more difficult to maintain networking. I used to attend a lot of events regularly and realised when they stopped how important they are for maintaining networks and contacts. I also found it more difficult to write when I was confined to the house, and was not able to perform at live events.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am a new author of children's books. My first book was published in February 2020. It and its sequels did very well, but could have done better if the ecosystem of schools and libraries and bookshops had been open. Word of mouth would have given them an opportunity to spread further. I also did not benefit from conducting school visits or attending most festivals. This would have raised my profile and earned me income. But, that said, my income remained relatively stable as I was supported by delivery advances for contracted books.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have done quite well considering, but the pandemic closures meant I lost a lot of the opportunities I would have had as a debut author to attend events, meet people and make connections to further my career. Two years later and I have yet to attend a book function and have met very few of my peers in person. It's less fun. Less sociable. More stressful and insular. I have also found it much harder to be creative with little ability to travel or do research in person.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I asked a publication date to be put back as the stress of our deadlines was too much. The publisher admitted the deadline was unreasonable but did not more the deadline back more than 2 weeks. We would have preferred six months.
Contractual_changes: Having only signed three contracts in the last four years, I have noticed no significant changes.
Issues_Survey: I am not sure what my royalty percentages are and was surprised you did not include a 'not sure' category for this or offer a range of answers rather than asking me to be specific.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of additional income capabilities.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased anxiety, especially due to financial issues combined with hefty increases in costs of living -- especially groceries.
self_publishing_comments: Unfortunately marketing is not my forte -- nor can I afford to hire others to promote my works.
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Sold more books
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As I write about trauma, I learned more about collective trauma. Also had more time since I didn't have to travel.  Did a lot of  Zoom.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The year before the pandemic, I had already decided to add to my skillset by training in editing and proofreading because I could not earn enough from freelance writing. During the pandemic and in the tax year 2021/22, I have been able to earn roughly the same amount from editing/proofreading as from writing, so my income almost doubled. I anticipate I will be doing far more editing/proofreading than writing in the years to come because of the lack of freelance writing opportunities.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I was already working from home so I was better able to manage any stress levels during the first lockdown. I have had more anxiety about my husband's income than my own (he is a self-employed piano teacher).
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: None. I have not written a book since 2019.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No space to write.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No change overall.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Harder to meet contacts and have unstructured conversations

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: travel jobs all went. Magazines closed. They don['t always come back.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: stress, less productivity, less motivation, anxiety
Contractual_changes: way lower advances for book projects - like half or even less  publishers demanding you now market things yourself more than before  contracts in general stagnant if not worth much less, partly due to idiots who work for free

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact as all writing done from home
Fewer books sold.

Member_ALCS_year: british association for counselling and psychotherapy
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: no longer able to look after grandchildren so i could take on more counselling clients.

year: savings on cost of travel; weekly to grandchildren and journeys to visit family and friends abroad
Main_income: reduction in some stresses;  clients online do not come to the house so i didn't have to clean nor dress the same.  (a few coming back now)  I decided I didn't need to retire, which i had been planning to do, because there was nothing else to do for my husband and myself except work.  We both enjoy our work very much  Not seeing the grandchildren every week was a massive reduction in stress.  Being in my son's house made me anxious.  work is much easier and less stressful. I decided not to work in the afternoons; this also reduced stress.  I did write a bit, but not too much; the pressure seems to have gone with age. (I reached 70 the week before the first lockdown)
Importance_Other: just a blog; does this count?

year: I also posted a story round friends and family; decided not to submit for publication because it was too much effort
Books_Games: sorry i couldn't face looking for the percentages i get. the sums are so small it's not worth worrying about them

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: loss of self-employment
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: been far too busy chasing work and not enough time writing to earn
Contractual_changes: not sure I have had any
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Mostly my change of earnings has not been to do with Covid but with Brexit, but because of Covid I have now (in the current tax year) increased the proportion of my contract with my employer because there is not much else in the way of outside work (which would normally be unpaid, but would be facilitated by having free time). I have saved massively on travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Few other things going on, so more coherent uninterrupted time for writing (apart from the months when my daughter and grandson moved in for a while due to needing to relocate from abroad during covid).  But also few opportunities for exchange of ideas in conferences, so a reduction in stimulus and exchange of ideas to get the writing improved and discussed.
Contractual_changes: There seems to be a lot of selling the rights on to various kinds of electronic outlets and also for translation and distribution in other countries (with no consultation with the author).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: savings due to no holidays, meals out, theatre etc
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: increased isolation due to lack of in-person school visits, book launches, festivals, conferences increased isolation due to inability to meet editors, publicists etc in person
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Negotiations referred to advice given by Society of Authors. However, because the contracts were for new books in an ongoing series, the publisher refused to change the terms from those agreed for previous books in the series.
Contract_clauses: I have continually asked for the right to approve special sales and ultra high discount sales deals in the first 12 months of publication, but the publisher will not agree to this.I have also asked for 10% of publisher receipts on these types of deals, but they will not increase from 7.5%, so I have ended up signing contracts on the publishers' terms.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not at all
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Slight frustration, but nothing significant
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Concerns over additional work relating to a supporting web site supporting a web site. Reluctant to sign up to unrestricted work.
Contractual_changes: Nothing that I am aware of
Contract_clauses: There were problematic clauses elating to unpaid work supporting a web site related to a text book. These were altered before signing
Issues_Survey: None

Changed_contract_Negotiations: * Option on future work clauses

year: * Non-compete clauses
* How I was credited
* How much I was paid
* Invoice payment clauses
* Payment due dates - e.g. on publication v fixed period
Member_NUJ_year: Mostly requires additional advertising (Amazon ads) to be successful now.
Books_NonfictionChildren: At the contract stage over crediting
Books_Educational: Liability clauses are much nastier - they often put all risk on the author, stating that even if problems are merely alleged that the author must pay to defend them.
Books_Games: More and more I find that liability clauses are often deeply unethical by putting all risk on the author and - if enforced - could ruin any author without sufficient insurance.
Broadcasting: To be sure of capturing accurate results, the survey should perhaps have acknowledged that authors can be paid via their limited companies for contracting purposes and legal protection, so income is not technically 'self employed' - even though in practice it is tantamount to being so.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No real impact
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It hasn't
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Deleted paragraph giving publisher first right to any further works by me
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic has slowed the writing and research process, affecting it quite profoundly at times.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As above. The general turmoil in the world has been a great negative factor too, making concentration and time much harder to find.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: We negotiated around lots of detail in a TV series development contract
Contractual_changes: Some magazine want to own the copyright and research materials to work they publish. I have a refused and always will, preferring not to write for those publications. These days I focus my book writing on America, now having a US agent and main publisher. I find the UK publishing industry hardly worth bothering with, so they have become an afterthought. UK TV and radio is still significant though.
Contract_clauses: I think royalties on ebooks are too low.
Issues_Survey: The ability to earn a living from writing anything other than TV has grown far worse since 2008 and the dominance of advertising by tech companies. Amazon have driven down the price of books, while magazines and newspapers pay very poorly, with the result that freelance writing has all but disappeared. The boom in newsletters may help, if it sustains. My fear is that only people from wealthy backgrounds will now be able to get a foothold in the profession: someone from my background would find it hard to get established now. There were many more routes in when I began - though it was still hard to get through even then.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: More freelance writing became available.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More willingness to engage in digital communication (such as Zoom) with my interviewees (rather than face-to-face).
Issues_Survey: A few of the questions weren't relevant.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased time at home, no commute, more time to write. A sense of being 'bunkered' and not planning /going on holidays gave me more focus on writing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less thesis editing
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Isolation during successive lockdowns; less work
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No access to a quiet working space due to working from home instead of being in the office

year: No access to a gym due to lockdowns
Difficulty accessing source materials and other literature
Anxiety/stress-induced insomnia

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Impeded productivity. Problems accessing libraries and archives has slowed research. General disincentive to engage with focused writing. Lack of social (f2f) stimulation and exchange of ideas, and encouragement.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Saving on travel costs.  Got more invitations to readings and events online, as travel costs no longer an issue for the host organisations.
Issues_Survey: Why is Scotland treated as one region?  I would guess that answers from rural Scotland would be very different from those given by writers in the Central Belt.

Contract_clauses: One that allowed rights to revert to the author if the book fell out of print. eBooks and print-on-demand books are never out of print. Unfortunately it didn't occur to me until after I'd signed it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: it is difficult to attribute anything specifically to Covid: I remained in academic employment on full salary, and royalties depend upon sales which can be affected by a range of factors. Other income -- from lectures at institutions other than my employer for instance -- produced lower income because of rearrangements due to Covid but these were marginal. I did save on travel to conferences and for research but this was partly offset by additional costs from working from home.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The work I was doing remained the same: it was the location and mode of delivery that changed (face-to-face replaced by Zoom; delivery in person by email; etc.). I managed to produce my planned book on time and as planned.
Issues_Survey: None

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I claimed the self employed grant the first two times it was offered but not after that and it restored my income to what it would have been
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The number of clients hiring fell dramatically in the early part of the pandemic but returned to more or less normal in the summer of 2021, where it has remained.
Contractual_changes: Nothing, this is an irrelevance in freelance business journalism
Issues_Survey: It appears largely aimed at authors, screenwriters etc so most of the questions had no bearing on me as a freelance business journalist

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: other people starting businesses following lifestyle changes brought about by covid led to more freelance writing work.

year: I also secured funding for a major project made available through covid support grant.
Main_income: At some stages of the epidemic, uncertainty and anxiety made creative work difficult, but at other times I was able to produce more - people are generally awful and the plague helped me avoid them :)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Reduced book sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Reduced book sales and more difficult to move publisher.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: It was regarding an exclusivity clause for future works.
Contractual_changes: Signed a new four book deal with a new publisher offering double the royalty rates I have been used to.
Contract_clauses: Exclusivity rights to future works not deemed part of the series of which the deal relates to.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No effect
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of income from talks and training - although a few things have gone online, they've largely been unpaid. Several publishers I work for regularly stopped all freelance contracts and took a lot of work in-house.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less freelance writing work available and fees significantly lower as publishers rein in budgets.  Fewer opportunities to attend face-to-face events has meant fewer opportunities to network - that makes it difficult to find new work, but also leads to a sense of isolation.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I always ask for 'non-compete' clauses to be removed from fee-based contracts - most publishers agree, although they don't take them out as a matter of course.
Contractual_changes: Significantly lower fees being offered for writing within my area (English Language Teaching, ELT). I've turned down offers of work where fees were less than half what had been paid by the same publisher for identical work just 5 years ago.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on going out, eating, holidays etc
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not no impact but a neutral impact as there are pluses and minuses:  Positive in the increase in PLR and digital sales.  Negative in the loss of supermarket slots and reduced PB sales and missed opportunity at climbing charts e.g, Heatseekers

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of income through pubishing contracts cancelled/suspended and few new contracts offered. Greatly reduced PLR this year as chidlren's non-fiction saw significant reductions in borrowing (around 50% usual PLR this Jan). Increased income by renting out parts of my house. SEISS made up some of the loss, too
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, decreased opportunities, decreased ability to focus or enthusiasm to pitch book ideas or seek a new agent (separated from agent before lockdown)
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Changed fee, changed schedule, included the right to claim ALCS/PLR monies even though selling the copyright
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I often (when I can be bothered) dispute the default clause in children's non-fiction that moral rights will be waived. I usually manage to gain attribution and never managed to gain integrity. Publishers think it means they can't edit the book and won't be persuaded otherwise. I have once demanded my name be removed from a book because they mangled it so badly, so I guess that's a win for attibution in a twisted sort of way
Contractual_changes: Contracts no longer sent out on paper at all, but a few want me to print and post it back! Almost all now signed digitally. Publishers possibly even slower than before in producing the contract - but varies by publisher. A lot of this questionnaire is difficult for those of us who work with many different publishers (eg different standard royalty rates with different publishers)
Contract_clauses: Yes: integrity, liability - but it's sign or don't work in my field
Issues_Survey: Survey too unclear: income including/excluding expenses (so turnover or taxable income?) - I did turnover. I got extra money from renting parts of my house and SEISS payments, but there's nowhere to put that

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Impossible to calibrate potential loss of earnings as I cannot guess what books publishers may have commissioned if Covid had not happened.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Being semi-retired, the impact is relatively light - but as I stated above, I have no inkling of what approaches publishers may have made to me if Covid had not impacted their plans.
Contractual_changes: My last contract was signed in 2019, so I cannot help you with this question.
Issues_Survey: It does not ask about pensions, so I was unable to specify what percentage of our household income was based on pensions.
Some questions do not have a not applicable or does not apply check box

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I assume the increase in my earnings may, in part, arise from more book buying by readers, but I have no evidence to support this.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have been unable to attend publicity events like book signings and library talks. I have also been unable to travel to America, a source of more than 50% of my income.
Contractual_changes: I am not aware of any. My agent would advise me if this were the case.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact. A new book increased royalty fees in 2021-22.
Issues_Survey: No
no - have really finished writing

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not a major impact, but the general anxiety and additional requirements of the teaching side of my job have meant less time for writing. Also have had less access to writing retreats which I would normally use to support my writing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am retired so my book earnings are from previous years. I stopped writing in 2015.

year: My other income is from pensions.
Main_income: As I am retired it has not impacted me at all in this respect.
Earn_Grants: A  lot of this does not really apply to me as I am retired. I was published by John Murray who were taken over by Hodder and I was treated extremely well.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My job has continued so while the way I work has changed, my income is stable.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I love working from home and find it works much better for me. I have felt the pandemic stress for sure, but the shift working from home has been so good for me.  There is a backlog to get academic publications through which has slowed down my publishing considerably.
Contractual_changes: None- this rarely applies to my work
Issues_Survey: It’s awful that I publish and review for academic publishers and get no money while they make billions. But my job as a professor depends on it, so I have to.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: None

self_publishing_comments: same as for publishing as I run a small publishing house.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: All theatre work was cancelled - zero royalties from touring shows and work abroad etc.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It's been stressful balancing work, home-schooling, and just general sense of low-level anxiety and uncertainty. (projects keep changing, dates keep changing because of COVID.)
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Most income is from pension, state and USS so little impact

Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity
self_publishing_comments: I enjoy writing. I'm financially OK having enjoyed a high ranking academic post and a generous pension after retirement.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No impact
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I got the publisher to change the number of books I was entitled to receive when published.
Contractual_changes: Publishers are increasingly putting the burden of insurance indemnity for anything written in the book that might cause offence onto the author. For example, in a UK based book it is acceptable to say the Universe started with the Big Bang - the generally accepted scientific concept. This idea is not acceptable to a large number of people in the USA  because of their religious beliefs.   Publishers have also reduced the number of books given to authors on publication. In the 1980s, 90s and 2000s the rule was 6 copies of each edition. It is now usual to be offered one copy of he first edition only.
Issues_Survey: As a writer and someone who has written for around 40 years and is now old enough not to rely on my yearly author's income, I write when I want to rather than when asked by a publisher.  I feel your questionnaire takes no notice of the fact that  1. writers can refuse jobs - I do so regularly 2. there are people like me who categorise themselves as retired even though we continue to earn income from the odd bit of writing, and from books written years ago 3. as a writer I have always made a reasonable amount of money as a consultant - reading other people's books on behalf of a publisher to check a book's content, facts and their interpretation. 'Consultant' didn't seem to feature in your money-making options.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of work through voluntary redundancy
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased time and focus on fewer aspects of my work. Previously time was divided between more different sources of income. Eventually I feel this may be beneficial, but is taking time to build up.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was made redundant from my paid employment; I lost a significant amount of regular freelance work; my costs have now gone up because I am having to travel further to fulfil new work commitments.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: While my, and my wife's main income is secure and unaffected by the pandemic, book sales saw a surge at the beginning of 2020, but fell to just over half in 2021 even though most of the sales of my books are online. I have had no call for professional articles or books at all in this period.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has restricted some research activity, and attendance at book fairs and book shops.
self_publishing_comments: The cost of self-publishing depends on whether or not one does it properly. I use an editor, a cover designer and a book interior designer through an "Independent Publisher". My books are only just starting to pay a return on what is effectively a "joint venture" publication, though I actually publish the finished book through my own account on Amazon and the Publisher lists them with Ingram and Bowker in the US. Costs run to 0,03c perword for editing, plus the cost of cover design and preparation and the cost of the ISBNs for eBook, Paperback and Hardcover.
Issues_Survey: There are shades of "self-publishing" which the answers/questions don't address. I am technically "published" by an American Independent Publisher, however, they provide me with the finished files and I upload these to the publishing platform. The publisher is named in the book Metadata and deals with all the registrations, etc. So, while I am, in a sense, self-publishing, it is not quite as that is generally understood.
This survey was really long and time-consuming to fill out.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Provided uninterrupted time for writing. I took early retirement from my career in 2011 and so rely on my pension as sole source of income. I also live alone and so was isolated for long periods of time. Writing kept me going and stopped me falling into depression or despair!
self_publishing_comments: I have never sought an agent or publisher because I love the freedom of self-publishing. I have a band of beta readers and editors who are happy to be rewarded with a copy of the finished book. I design my own covers and do all my own formatting. It means I can publish a book from start to finish in less than a year - far quicker than traditional publishers. I agree that marketing is a problem - I don't do any because my passion is writing, not selling myself. (I would have to sell myself if I had a traditional publisher). Despite this my books sell moderately well and, in fact, one of the non-fiction books is recommended as a course book at a USA University. It costs me nothing to publish my books through Amazon kdp and they have an excellent support team who rectify printing or book display issues immediately. To date I have self-published 20 books.
Contractual_changes: none - apart from Createspace Publishing being transferred to Amazon KDP.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Spent the time writing and got a more lucrative publishing deal.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Both publishers and copywriting clients immediately cancelled ongoing work when the pandemic struck - some have now come back, but on a one-off or short-term basis, rather than commissioning regular or longer-term work. This makes cashflow forecasts much harder for me. The SEISS grants were useful, but failed to match the help offered to employed people through furlough - more broken promises from the UK Government.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The decrease in income and subsequent decrease in regular/predictable income has made freelancing more stressful and has put large life decisions on hold.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: JPiMedia (owner of The Scotsman) inserted Clause 4.2 (indemnity) into its freelance agreement - this required writers to take liability and pay costs for any legal action arising from an article. This goes against the basic tenets of journalism and copywriting - the publisher takes the legal responsibility not the writer. The commissioning editor at The Scotsman wouldn't remove the clause and stopped commissioning work from me.
Contractual_changes: See previous answer - in March 2021, JPiMedia (owner of The Scotsman) sent me an updated freelance agreement containing Clause 4.2 (indemnity), which required the writer to pay any legal costs arising from publication of an article - this goes against the basic tenets of journalism and copywriting, in that the publisher take responsibility for legal bills. I asked for the clause to be removed but the commissioning editor at The Scotsman refused to do so, and instead simply stopped commissioning articles from me.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My annual income varies hugely, so the 2020-21 income seems high because it includes an advance which was actually for work that had taken place over 2 years prior to that book deal being made.  But Covid definitely cut down on the kind of work that was available to me. I earn money as a public speaker and many of the events where I could have spoken were initially cancelled for a while. Also, my partner (whom I did not meet until 2019) lost his job in May 2021, which has created an added pressure financially, especially as we have a young child.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I would not say it is a huge impact in either direction, but it has been very isolating -- which some might see as a good situation to be in, if you're trying to get work done. Mainly it is the loss of in-person events, which means a certain loss in community -- something fairly vital for lonely occupations like writing. This has made it harder to network and to maintain connections and find support as a writer.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I am a comedy writer. During the first lockdown...  * A colleague tragically died of COVID-19. Obviously, this was completely devastating - and a commissioned project a large group of us had been working on, and which had been scheduled for the autumn of 2020, was abandoned.  * A regular television show, which I work on every year, was postponed as one of the other writer/performers was shielding.   * My role in assisting stand-up comedians with theatre shows was immediately redundant once the Edinburgh Festival was cancelled.   * Existing radio work, crafted to be performed in front of an audience, had to be re-written in such a way that it could be recorded a) remotely and b) without an audience. This meant a considerable amount of extra work on three radio series - all of which went unpaid.   * Potential work was lost when television companies delayed or abandoned their commissioning rounds and processes.   Fortunately, I did qualify for the SEISS grant, which went some way to helping with the loss of income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Aside from the loss of income from cancelled projects (which for me, personally, runs into tens of thousands of pounds) - it's worth noting the general loss of momentum I, and many of my colleagues, feel we have suffered during the pandemic.   Projects being pitched to TV companies were immediately dropped as broadcasters, understandably, had to rethink how they spent money during the pandemic.   It felt like there was a certain (and again, understandable) reluctance by indies or broadcasters to commit to larger projects as the year went on. Many of us who assist stand-up comedians with their live work were also hit by the cancellation of the Edinburgh Festival.  My radio background was certainly useful when it came to picking-up bits of work on the shows and formats which could continue - but what work was about did seem relatively small and piecemeal in comparison to 2019.   The idea of writers benefiting from some sort of "increased productivity" while locked-away during the pandemic is a bit of a romantic one. Maybe there was a small amount of freedom in having the time to write-up that idea you always wanted to... But who was in a position to buy your work? The uncertainty made it quite difficult.  2022 has got off to a slightly better start for me personally, but we shall have to wait and see what transpires and how long it takes for the industry to truly pick itself up.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
self_publishing_comments: Was invited onto a podcast project and it felt like a good time (while work was somewhat thin on the ground) to give it a go.
Contractual_changes: In comedy it is common to by paid directly by a comic for assistance with material ahead of a TV or Radio show panel game appearance. No credit is given and none is expected. This is a tale as old as time.  HOWEVER, since 2020 I have done work on narrative TV shows (sitcoms etc) on a day-rate in which I have been paid directly by a production company on the understanding I will not receive a credit. Maybe I am naive but, personally, this was unheard of 5 or 6 years ago.
Issues_Survey: Yes I have a few concerns about the questions.  Question 10 - "All figures should be based on earnings BEFORE tax and should exclude any agent's fees"  My question here is did you want my GROSS or NET earnings? It really isn't clear. The way you phrase it suggests (to me) NET  - As that is usually what people mean when they "earnings before tax". (It's what I usually associate with "what my mortgage company want to know").   However, if you then compare my NET earnings with my writing income, it's a very disingenuous calculation - because my writing income will be a raw number representing "money in" - Effectively, GROSS writing earnings. So it will not include deductions for expenses etc.  which the NET figure will. So you're really not comparing like-with-like.   The overall effect of this is that our writing incomes will always appear to be a larger % than they actually are.   For what it is worth, I did mine as GROSS income and then full writing earnings which is, I believe, mathematically sound - although I don't know how many others will make the same call and will therefore give some potentially confusing and incorrect results.   Also, in a subsequent question you used the phrase "Publishers". Did this also include "Broadcasters"? I do not work in print at all, really - all my work is on radio and TV. As such, I left this as zero, but otherwise this could have been the bulk of my earnings.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As a retired lecturer, self employed writer and occasional workshop leader there has been no real impact.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have been working at home as usual, so no change there but workshop activities have moved on-line to avoid face to face contact with students.
Issues_Survey: I did not have the information available to answer a few of the questions - particularly on royalty rates.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I've been lucky to have a Residency (extended by an ACE grant) which has kept me buoyant since the pandemic, supplemented by other smaller fees coming in.  This comes to an end October 2022 and things will be very different – anticipating a sudden and dramatic dip in my income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As above, I have been fortunate in having paid work since the pandemic.  But I have found working online quite stressful, even though it has made the social engagement work possible and extended its reach, ditto readings and teaching etc.  I have continued working on my own writing and have appreciated being more home-based, with less travel breaking up my routine.  Again, there's a paradox here –  I've missed the social contact that comes from leading workshops and giving and attending readings.    So, a real mix of benefits and disadvantages.  Longer term, it doesn't feel sustainable though – we do need more in person human contact and a sense of a shared future.
Contractual_changes: Not a lot of experience in this area this past year.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Book sales have increased - notably ebooks.

Opportunities for conferences - with benefits such as networking, promotion, professional development - have been extremely limited. Anxiety and difficulties supporting my elderly parents have increased my stress levels, affecting my creativity.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: Persuaded them not to remove my moral rights as an author for a new use of my work
self_publishing_comments: In the year for which I have given writer income figures my self publishing produced only a very small profit.  However, this is because I had produced a new title, incurring initial  costs of editor, cover designer, printer and ebook conversion. I also had to pay for reprints of existing titles, one of which has sold over 8,000 copies.  Overall my profits from my most successful self-published titles are far more lucrative than royalties.  So far (over several years) my most commercial title has earned c. 10x the amount I would have expected from conventionally published royalties, for just 2x the amount of work.  I do put considerable efforts into promotion and marketing - which means I have total control over what happens with my books.  My most recent self published book garnered glowing full length reviews in 2 major national journals.   I have no problem in getting bookshops to stock my self published books, which look exactly the same as books produced by conventional publishers, with strong covers.    The key is to understand how the book trade works before embarking on self publishing and to act in a totally professional way throughout.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Pearson wished to re-use a story I wrote some years ago for one of their primary school reading schemes.  The re-use was in an anthology.    The original contract did not cover this form of re-use so we had to negotiate a fee.  they originally offered me a pittance of £110.    I refused to accept this and thought that would be the end of it, but they subsequently increased it to £500.  They then sent me an addendum to the original contract, which contained a clause saying I waived all my moral rights for this re-use.  Again, I refused to accept it.  Eventually they re-drafted the addendum saying that this clause was deleted, and specifying that I would be credited as author in all editions of this re-use.  Pearson are a nightmare to deal with, they keep sending me crazy bureaucratic forms and their IT system makes it very difficult to sign and submit things online.  Since this re-use was for an anthology, I fear other, less experienced, authors may have been exploited for it in a way that I refused to be.
Contract_clauses: Refuse to sign contracts with problematic clauses
Issues_Survey: Huge international publishing companies such as Pearson need to be educated on how to treat their authors

Changed_contract_Negotiations: I have always changed most of the terms in my contract since I began writing. I am a lawyer and make sure that I look at all clauses which will hopefully be in my favour. My publishers (Routledge) tell me that I am mostly the only author who changes or amends terms of the publishing contract. I try and negotiate better royalties in percentage terms; I try and get as many free copies (hardback and paperback) as I can. I look carefully at the e-copies of the book in terms of royalties. The clauses which are the most contentious are the ones - if there is legal action - such as being sued in defamation - the publishers will not normally assist the author in a legal action. You are on your own. This is most important that authors read these clauses. I also never agree to doing my own indexing or images/ tables. As part of the contract I get the publishers to do this for me since this would take an extraordinary amount of time.
Contractual_changes: None so far other than signing contracts online / virtually
Contract_clauses: No. I make sure that this does not arise at the start for reasons I have explained.

self_publishing_comments: I self print and self publish a letterpress magazine. Probably the only hand typeset magazine left in the world! Every copy sells out to 16 different countries and usually within 48 hours of going on sale. This is based on reputation alone -0 I don't do any marketing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Across the board of my curatorial practice, for the first time ever I received direct funding from the Arts Council, two grants in the same year, after trying unsuccessfully since 2007 ! Also had success with other funding bodies who had never supported my work before, but I had only recently applied to directly. I could not however claim SEISS or furlough.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As a writer my main directional change has been to write about projects before or as they are about to happen, less after the event, which was the majority case before. I have also become much involved in funding application proposals which are so complex that my experience as a writer have become incredibly valuable and of great use not just to me, but other creative practitioners and emerging organisations that I have helped secure financial support from various sources.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Territorial and length of time are key, but also getting paid for online uses and licensing to third party publishers, especially when translated.
self_publishing_comments: Digital reproduction has made it no longer cost effective to have to produce thousands of copies,as with traditional litho. Short runs a ideal for time sensitive works, so usually for self-publishing, digital is the first option I consider, although as I’m usually working closely with a graphic designer they are well placed to advise on what is best for each particular publication. One thing that we find has become much expensive is buying ISBNs.
Contractual_changes: Since I have only self-published in the last twelve months I cannot answer this

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I actually got more commissions through covid because I was asked to write an online monologue which led to an online film which led to an online full length theatre play. None of this would have happened if it wasn't for covid.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I worte a comedy monologue for a theatre co which went online, then I wrote a short film which was entered into film festivals throughout the world and won some awards, I started directing as a result. Then I did an online zoom play which was funded by the Arts Council, none of this would have happened pre-covid
Issues_Survey: I haven't had any writing contracts in the last few years, they have all been self-commissioned work.
I'm a ghostwriter-for-hire and the questions didn't seem to consider that.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Furlough enabled me to focus more attention on my author business which allowed me to grow revenue from 400 per year to 11000 per year (GBP).
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It gave me time to grow and diversify my income.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I got a production partner to remove the right to reuse my content for commercial purposes.
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Am working at home more and so have had more time to write. Less distractions.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was unable to do clinics with patients whom I write academic papers on, real effect was on my vitality and ability start and follow-through on projects due to the stop-start, coil-recoil nature of the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Initially was in fear, pervasive generalised fear. I could not see this virus... I have discovered that I gain vitality through meeting people with a similar set off interests.  It affected the starting of things, I literally lost my drive. It felt like someone had removed my internal battery and gave me two AA batteries to function on.  It felt like a depression, but it was not, as whenever I could get near a scrap of my own normal life, I felt my energy rising. I never realised how symbiotically connected I am to the world and people around me. I could not write when in fear, I felt a disgust and lethargy to commencing something.  When I made public appearances or talks, I found my thinking style had become black/white, all/nothing, grey, lacking my normal creativity and blue sky thinking had been shot in the proverbial when attempting flight. My libido plummeted, as I felt impotent in the world, I did not feel like I was affecting anything, ineffective, useless. I found myself at the age of 52 becoming obsessed with my pension plan, which is crazy. I spent hours planning my life in 15 years time, hours and hours, listening to work whilst lying on my bed.  The emperor's new clothes, my childhood favourite book was now playing live in front of me. I was so filled with futile anger and angst that it dried me of any creation. I sometimes played the part of the agreeable fool like everyone else, agreeing that zoom meetings were so helpful, whilst my feet and hands got colder.  My body locking down, my mind seeking escape; I do hope that it is all nearly over. I figured out on the weekend that I am actually now frightened of having hope, that feeling hope makes my corpus tense and I cried with self and other compassion, large globular tears that could refresh a humming bird.
Issues_Survey: I have found writing my responses very helpful, it has quietened and allowed me to express my fears and concerns

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost all my work overnight when lockdowns were announced around the world (approx £25,000 worth of work). I have been unable to travel freely to do my job as a travel writer, so have been hindered for at least two years.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: In a strange way, while I didn't benefit financially, I did benefit professionally as I became outspoken about industry issues and built my profile as a writer during the pandemic.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I changed payment terms in a contract so I could receive 50% payment upfront.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: no substantial change
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no significant impact
Contractual_changes: I've had very few contracts so can't really contribute to this question.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I took voluntary redundancy from my academic post in summer 2020 to write full time.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I signed with an agent in January 2020 and the pandemic has made it difficult to see my agent and editor in person so building professional relationships has been less straightforward.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: 2020 was particularly bad due to the pandemic closing many of my regular titles. However, touch wood, 2021-22 seems to have picked up well.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity, but led to high anxiety and stress
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Negotiated the removal of a copyright clause handing over my works to a publishing group.
Contractual_changes: Fees have decreased and the number of words expected for a professional piece is worth much less

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: Very difficult to earn a living as a writer.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic hasn't had an effect on my writing earnings - except that I wrote all the way through lockdown. My earnings are more in the most recent tax year because my most recent books (ebooks, digital publisher) were paying quarterly royalties, which weren't coming through in 2019-2020. Lucky enough to help run a family business, so monthly salary from that (and the business was deemed essential so could operate through lockdown)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There have been pros and cons. The first lockdown coincided with a three-book contract so I was able to dedicate time to writing, but as my working life (family business) is flexible I can take time out to write anyway. Lack of social life did help with the daily word count though! I'd say there was a level of stress, but only a part of that was the existential 'we're all doomed' pandemic sort of stress. The real stress has been self-inflicted in that we sold our house and can't find one to buy... although we have a roof over our heads, being 'stateless' doesn't help with peace of mind!
Contractual_changes: I don't think my contracts have changed (have just resigned another three-book deal contract and I think it's the same as the one I signed in 2019) My agent looks over the contracts though, so I might not know all the ins and outs

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As an academic I can work remotely so this has not impacted my income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My academic writing has not been impacted by COVID
self_publishing_comments: I do not engage in self-publishing
Issues_Survey: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Non-writing earnings fell substantially, e.g. especially tour guiding (CS Lewis’s house in Oxford, very popular with groups, esp. from overseas. After two years with no tours, , the tours have very gradually started again with covid  some restrictions lifting.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The covid threat has something of a weight. There is some ease belonging to the C-19 Zoe group, highly informative.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: While some television production was postponed in 2020 (causing a loss of income) this was compensated in my case by an increase in repeats of previous episodes on BBC One. In 2021, production went on more or less as it did before the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There is a backlog of productions in the pipeline and many production companies are reluctant to take new work onto their slate in the short term. This is making it hard to sell new ideas. Also, financial pressures on BBC have increased, making them more risk averse and limiting some drama production.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Via my agent, we have renegotiated terms and fees in contracts so they are more beneficial, sometimes in reference to the WGGB/PACT television agreement. These improvements have related to minimum episode guarantees, buy-out fees, credits and production deadlines.
Contractual_changes: Because of the increase in streaming services and international sales in television, more companies seem to want complete buy-outs or less generous royalty terms, which limits the longterm earning potential for scriptwriters.
Contract_clauses: Britbox have demanded longterm buy-outs while only wanting to pay minimal percentages to compensate writers.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings because I used to deliver face to face training. This stopped altogether for a while, then moved online. For online training I cannot charge as much and do not deliver a full day. So I might have earned £500 for a full day of face to face, whereas now I might earn £200 for 3 hours of online.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress. Online working has added to my workload. Home schooling added immense pressure and less time to write.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Total loss of steady income mainly from closure of schools/colleges/adult education. Reduction in number of books/anthologies being published. Loss of writer-in-residence opportunities.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The loss of my fairly regular income has been a  issue for my wife and I. We are both pensioners (though very active!) Also, my own writing output has reduced dramatically as there are no 'prods' from anthology publishers nor broadcasters. However, the most serious issue is that I feel very isolated from other writers and teachers. And I most definitely miss working with children - and they are the ones who inspire me!!!
Issues_Survey: I am surprised that a tickable list of author types was not included. For example, the earnings of poets are so very different from, say, novelists.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of household earnings through lack of contract work - firms not engaging contract staff when everyone working from home
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Huge increase in anxiety
Contractual_changes: Publishers not putting reversion clauses into contracts, and making it 'muddy' when you want to get your rights back to take the work elsewhere. Magazines taking all rights in stories and articles.
Contract_clauses: Selling all rights in an article - I'd prefer to sell only first British so I can resell it to other markets.
Issues_Survey: The issues around copyright really need examining - thanks for asking these questions!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less spent socialising, travel, holidays
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Made lab work impossible

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Publishers haven't carried out extensive marketing. Readers have been reluctant and have not had a good feedback as far as having readers is concerned. I have been affected individually but the impact has been extreme. The publishers couldn't be contacted at a one to one basis and this has been noticeable in achieving a cordial contact with the publishers. I have had to adjust my effort in the way I market my books. The level of contacting publishers has been minimal and the publishers can only been contacted online and its difficult to have a speaking engagement with the publishers due to covid -19.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have had to to write in the meantime and have had issues in trying to get readers like contacting librarians, reviewers and bookshops and this has been positive. They have been a varying response and have received good tidings with the effort I  have carried out.  My effort has been productive because I didn't work in vain. I have had my book stocked in libraries and have been reviewed therefore that has been positive.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Although I was just beginning my career, I had looked forward to subsidising my earnings with school visits, library events, and festivals, which all but stopped during the pandemic. I looked to enhance my income elsewhere and started my own business as a freelance editor. Whilst this has been successful, I have seen my book sales suffer, as a result of not being able to showcase them in schools. Starting a new business and focusing on other writers' work has also had an impact on my own productivity. During Covid, I have also seen a long delay between signing my next book deal and publication - in fact, the book I was signed for has been shelved and I am now working on a new title, pushing my next publication date from 2022 to 2024 - a four-year gap since my last book. Writing was also difficult during the early stages of Covid, as I was homeschooling, which took away a great deal of my ability to focus and create and therefore produce saleable content.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Covid hit just as my second book was released - everything I had looked forward to, in terms of promoting my series, was cancelled - the launch, publicity, and most importantly, school visits. I have managed to squeeze a couple in between lockdowns but without the ability to do multiple visits, each feels like the first one again - stressful and anxiety-inducing! In the beginning, there was a panicked rush to provide content online, to maintain a presence, to feel relevant, and this was overwhelming.  Just prior to the first lockdown I signed a new 2-book deal, which was initially put on hold, and then the book in question was shelved. This was entirely due to the pandemic and obviously caused not only stress, but a further delay in my career. In lieu of books on the shelves and author events to promote them, I have had to look for alternative income streams, all of which take away from writing. I have also had to homeschool two children, and manage their concerns, none of which is conducive to being creative! In summary, for me, Covid has resulted in decreased productivity and increased stress
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

self_publishing_comments: Incurred costs c. £500 for two books on cover design and also buying rights back from a previous publisher. Haven't made that back but was totally worth it anyway to not have books sitting with that publisher.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Drop in sales of books, both paperbacks and ebooks. My individual earnings from my pensions have stayed much the same.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress because I have to spend more time promoting my self-published books for less return. Advertising costs have risen and more traditional publishers are competing in the same market place as self-published authors. I don't know whether it is a coincidence, because of Covid or other factors.
self_publishing_comments: The cost of advertising through Facebook, Amazon and Bookbub is very high and often results in very high costs of sales, so you are spending more than you receive in sales.  Producing audiobooks is very expensive because you have to pay the narrator and the return on sales is low because many audiobooks are sold on a subscription basis. Ebooks provide the most profit but even there, many people have subscriptions with Amazon that mean they get so many free books each month. The number of books sold at 0.99 and given away for free has escalated recently, in my opinion. The unpaid time required for marketing, publishing your book and self-promotion far outweighs the time spent in writing.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decrease productivity
