Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More family life (I normally live on my own, but formed a bubble with family during lockdown.  Much less time spent travelling, creating more time for solitary activitis such as writing, but less motivation to do so.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Contract required professional indeminity insurance maintained during and for 6 years following the contract, at a cost approximately twice the total fee offerered.   I said I that would not be reasonable or possible. They agreed that I should be convered as a subcontractor by their own professinal liability insurance.   That discussion has not yet been completed and signed, so I am not absolutely certain it is resolved, but I think it has.
self_publishing_comments: At present this is very small scale - written articles 'pubished' by circulation of a Dropbox code which allows downloading by people who see a reference to it. No charge made.  Later this year I plan to self-publish a 500 page book, being an annotated compilation or articles published in a magazine over 20 years, of which I own the copyright by agreement with the publisher. There will be a small number of copies in paper form, with the main circulation in electronic form (possibly Kindle though I have not decided that finally).  I have not yet decided on price or conditions, but the main motivation is the maximum possible readership, not to make a financial profit (and possibly not even to recover costs). All the writing and formatting will be done by me, and I will commission a publisher specialising in vanity books to do the physical production of the paper versions. (For guidance, the maximum readership of the paper plus electronic formats will be, I guess, about 100, and I will be happy with half that).
Contractual_changes: For magazine articles, I used t receive a fixed sum per article. I recently negotated to waive the fee in order to 'buy back' my copyright of back articles with the same magazine, and maintain the copyright for future articles.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: savings on travel costs but it means I can't travel to do research
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Neighbours being home and on furlough has meant much more noise (from building work) and therefore less time to concentrate on my writing.

Importance_Other_Name: I work in television mainly now - producing/writing briefs etc for presenters. I can no longer afford to have writing as my main income.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Writing fees - for magazines/periodicals - have dropped year on year. Day rates on magazines (for in-house work) have either stayed the same or dropped over the past 20 years.

year: I have saved on transport though.
Main_income: More anxiety - due to the low fees etc mentioned above. It's increasingly hard to keep afloat from pure writing, which is why I've branched out into TV. I think there's a lack of respect for freelancers in terms of paying them on time too. I think the pandemic has also led to a 'brain fog' in my case, so less motivation sometimes.
Broadcasting: Not with books, but with magazines etc, there is an increase in umbrella companies, buy-outs etc. Pay is lower.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Additional stress at work has meant coming down to 3 days per week from 5 days to allow me to do the writing I want to do.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: See above, increased stress so no headspace to plan or research writing which necessitated a reduction in hours.
Contract_clauses: The need to take my next idea for a book to this publisher before going to others. They would not necessarily be the best publisher for all my writing.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: One of my publishers has become a lot less efficient, perhaps partly due to Covid.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I always specify that the publisher should undertake the work involved in getting permissions for reproduction of figures. They also must pay for them. Otherwise required changes are minor, e.g. deadline date.
Contractual_changes: As you will have gathered, although I have earned money from writing since 1983, this has always been a minor proportion of my income. I have signed about one contract every couple of years. They tend to have become longer and more fussy but the terms for me have remained about the same.
Issues_Survey: I went to one ALCS AGM and was amazed at the diversity of people who self-identify as "writers". I suspect that only a small minority are dependent on writing for their entire income.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have been supplementing my writing work by working as a carer. However, I have also been advertising my self-published books, so this has increased my income from writing a little (a lot of the increase is cancelled out by the advertising costs, but it's still nice to know that more of my writing is being read).
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My marriage has ended (partly due to the stress of being stuck inside all the time together, which is Covid-related) so I now need to earn money so have less time to write (because the writing doesn't earn much). However, I am sure the situation will improve.
self_publishing_comments: I like self-publishing because I have control over the process. However, it is not very lucrative, at least for me, and I have reached the point where I would like to be traditionally published.
Contractual_changes: I have never had a contract; I have always self-published
Issues_Survey: A lot of the questions don't apply to me as I am self-published; maybe separate surveys for self-published, traditionally published and both might be easier (for you to collate the information)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost all my speaking events in 2020 and 2021. Few are being offered in 2022 - the online option has taken over many of the technical conferences and sessions I used to get paid to attend. Not as easy to charge as much when it is online.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have managed to keep work coming in by converting my research work to an online format - interviews via Zoom rather than face-to-face. It has saved me quite a bit of money in travel and time once people had got used to the format.
self_publishing_comments: It was really good and relatively easy. I used Amazon’s print on demand service and it worked really well. I needed the help of a local designer to lay up the document but a bottle of gin did the job!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My earnings to supplement my writing was through hospitality.  Hard hit during the pandemic.  Less opportunity for live gigs and readings.   I spent time writing a book, which has been published.  I'm now having an increase in bookings to read and run workshops and retreats since my book was published.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have needed to cate for family during this time, and spent more time writing my book in-between.   Writing has been a salvation and a comfort during yhe pandemic.   I have greatly missed face to face contact with other writers and hearing live spoken word and readings.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost my job in an NGO abroad and I had to start my journalist career from zero again in my own country.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It made my life much worse because I lost my job, my community and I had to give up one of my dreams when I was sent home from Indonesia due to the pandemic. I had to start looking for a job as a journalist again, but it was so hard, so eventually, I took a summer job as a receptionist. Being a freelance journalist is really hard nowadays because there are tons of journalists jobless and the private and independent media outlets are also struggling with lower payments.
Contractual_changes: I started a new contract with a news agency to write more for them on a daily basis.
Issues_Survey: No

Importance_Other_Name: Doing talks and presentations based on the books, also competitions
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Any paid employment got replaced by needing to volunteer to support emergency services - I'm a voluntary Carer Ambassador supporting unpaid carers and we have seen support needs double in the last 2 years. I've also had to support my autistic son when all other education and support disappeared. My daughter's mental health has been severely damaged by the pandemic lockdowns, so I spent a lot of time supporting her, and also keeping my partner (our chief earner) sane in his employment. He was at least 12 hours working online every day, and I helped with breaks and meals. I also took on looking after my mother who has early-stage dementia. Basically, like many women, I gave up any prospect of employment or chance of living my own life.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: What professional life? Decimated. Now have PTSD.
Contractual_changes: Increase in "do this for free for exposure" and "if you write this, we can help you crowdfund to make money" - huge increases in the latter online. Increase in "we'll train you to write for us" and "write for us unpaid because you love social media" - reminds me of indentured servants, grateful for the work! Lots of free internships giving people the golden opportunity to write for them.
Contract_clauses: worried about transfer to screen rights, but signed it anyway.
Issues_Survey: you need to do a follow-up questionnaire looking at employment opportunities in writing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Reduction of salary due to school lockdowns and distance learning
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, stress, lack of motivation
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: loss of earnings through furlough, loss of business due to Brexit plus Covid - people in UK not buying consultancy.  Book income about the same.

Member_Other_year: British Association for South Asian Studies

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: saved on travel and work agreed I could continue to teach online, so good. My health is poor and I am likely to leave after periods off work in last four years. My partner took early retirement during the pandemic (the employer was terrible and initially refused home-working despite being a telecommunications organisation!).
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: basically my chronic health issues are my biggest issue and the pandemic helped relieve those a little by allowing me to avoid trains with the wheelchair - which was massively stressful and pain inducing. I felt others understood my home-bound life a little. I had a wee bit more energy and could engage with my writing again.
Contractual_changes: Unsure. Initial advance and contract was with The Women's Press and they went out of business before my non-fiction book was published.  Currently I'm completing a children's non-fiction book (though I've ticked the 'educational' box above as there is loads of super-accurate science in it - but the purpose is to be fun) with materials scientists from the University of Leeds. I received  a flat fee and the books will be given out for free in areas of the city that are poorest, possibly via libraries or schools or foodbanks. because of that I'm not worried about lack of royalties. It is 'collaborative' and will be illustrated, but none of the others are writers. I did sign a contract but more as a project participant/ freelance worker than one like the Women's Press publisher's one.
Issues_Survey: It was a bit complicated! Like doing a tax retunr. I nearly stopped but I'm autistic and like to complete things I've started, so you were lucky there. You might have asked if income matches expenditure. Not quite the happiness index but the sense of security we all need. Our combined income looks low but we are house -rich. We have paid off mortgages on two properties and live in one and rent out the other. This is why my partner was safe to early retire and why I am looking at leaving employment soon through ill health.  (I also get PIP  high mobility and low care benefit which is around 300 a month, but I did not include this in our household income as it is NOT subject to tax. But obvs I can use it to pay the bills).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Fewer articles commissioned, freelance payments have stagnated (even more than they already did). That said, I got some work from foreign publications due to being in a country their own reporters couldn't get to, due to Covid border closures.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: This question is hard to answer because in fact it has done both. It opened up opportunities with foreign publications, so that is a positive. But it caused great stress and has made travel for work very complicated. And it was impossible to concentrate on pulling together a proposal for my next book.
Contractual_changes: None, as I have only had one contract and that was several years ago.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Slightly better off as covid gave me time to apply for promotion.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased sickness and other absences from colleagues - impacted workload as I picked up additional work to support them.

year: Increased anxiety and stress - as an academic dealing with very anxious students and providing reassurance took a lot of time and impacted productivity.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost my job, have only found a part time replacement, so have to work much harder to earn less. It looks like I'm earning a good salary but my job entails high expenses (not refunded) of around 25,000 a year, so as I live alone I have to be careful. I was travelling most weeks for work before the pandemic, now I have had to pivot my specialism to earn without so much travel.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Vastly increased anxiety and stress leading to very decreased productivity. I haven't found another stable job, I am freelancing on zero hours contracts.

Importance_Other_Name: Teaching material for creative writing courses
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: In early 2020 I lost £10000.00 of planned income as writing courses and public talks were cancelled, but things improved financially in May 2020 when I was offered a book commission for £8000 and was awarded an emergency grant for the SoA.  As the pandemic went on, I was offered a number of on-line speaking gigs, and also took on private on-line teaching, and a second book commission.  I also was able to increase the amount of book reviewing I do which helped keep my overall income roughly stable.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The pandemic messed with the delicate eco-system of my writing life. It significantly increased the stress, anxiety and isolation of being a freelance writer and dramatically decreased the enjoyable (and necessary) perks such as literary festivals events, public speaking engagements, IRL teaching, and general opportunities for meeting like-minded people.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I successfully negotiated text and cover approval,  and the retention of adaptation and audio rights, and sub-licensing approval.  I was not successful in reserving translation rights.   I was also prevented from accepting an offer from Bloomsbury for a book that was already under contract with a charity that planned to self-publish, even though I was advised informally by a lawyer that the charity was in breach of the principle of estoppel.  I couldn't afford legal representation and didn't have an agent at the time with the result that the charity was able to block the offer from Bloomsbury (and is currently making a total hash of self-publishing!)
Contractual_changes: It has become harder to negotiate terms.
Contract_clauses: Reversion of rights is weighted heavily against the author, made worse by POD.  Failures on the part of the publisher to fulfil their obligations also seem to be hard to enforce.
Issues_Survey: I had a contract for a book suddenly cancelled in early 2018 for reasons which were never properly explained or justified.  I felt I had no say in this decision, which came at a very difficult time in my life personally and was a huge blow to my confidence and finances.  What was particularly odd was that the publisher had just  paid me 25% of the advance a few weeks before they cancelled the whole contract.  I believe the reasons for cancelling were primarily ideological but have no way of proving this.  My then agent did not fight the cancellation but did negotiate that I should pay back the 25% received when /if I ever sold the book for more than £20k.
no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had to leave my permanent part time civil service role due to disability discrimination prior to COVID; I am currently awaiting my employment tribunal. I currently have a full time higher paid role in a university, which is higher paid but less secure, with considerably more pressure.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As a disabled person, most events going online has been very beneficial for me. Eg: previously I was told it was too difficult for me to join meetings by telephone, so I was excluded when my work place was unsafe for me to navigate due to disabilities. Now it feels that I would not face such exclusion as people are more motivated to use technology.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had a play which a theatre company had scheduled for production. This was cancelled. I usually earn a substantial amount from creative writing workshops. These were also cancelled, and I am only just beginning to be asked to lead further workshops.   I have used the time to write a novel, but it will be a while before I see any earnings from that.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Theatres are very reluctant to commission new work.  Arts organisations have not been running writing workshops.  I also suffered two bereavements during 2020 (one of which was directly related to Covid-19, the other indirectly). The combined effect of these and the variouys lockdowns and restrictions made it difficult to focus, and I found that for long periods I was much less productive and proavctive than I usually am.
Issues_Survey: Early on you ask a question about main source of writing income. I answered 'playwriting' (for theatre). No subsequent questions refer to that.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost a freelance contract and branched out into other work (consultancy). I did save on travel and also had the SEISS payments which helped a lot.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have more anxiety and no clarity about future work.
Issues_Survey: I find it hard to classify all the different bits and bobs I do as a writer. I don't publish books but I write for a living.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Covid significantly lowered our household income for several months, as my partner is self-employed and did not qualify for most of the covid relief measures. However, this has now returned to normal.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have experienced increased stress during the pandemic, mostly in terms of the volume of demands for my work, with reduced capacity at times due to increased childcare requirements (e.g., with closures of schools and nurseries) and the impact of illness / self-isolation. More time spent in front of a computer rather than with people has lowered my motivation to spend my personal time writing.
Issues_Survey: As an academic, I was amazing at the income I received from ALCS from academic journal publication. As I do my writing during my salaried time, I didn't expect to receive further income in addition to this. In contrast, I receive almost no money in royalties for a book I published.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No impact.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: A US-based publisher didn't want to give me an advance for an academic book, but I argued my case and they agreed to give me one. They cited Covid as why they couldn't initially.
Contractual_changes: See above re: advance. As an editor of a book series, I now get a flat fee, rather than a percentage of sales, for every book published in my series.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Everything roughly the same
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: No financial effect but very stressful homeschooling primary school age child while working full time

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: loss of household earnings + loss of royalties because of reduced sales

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My earnings have increased through the publication of more books, but this is not necessarily due to covid.

I am a secondary school teacher and the pandemic meant I was teaching remotely from home. The stress was incredible and  not something I would like to go through again. There were far too many headless chickens squawking about what had to be done and an insane expectation that we were suddenly au fait with systems we'd never used before, such as Teams, Loom etc.   The publisher I used has a model of expecting authors to be really pushy and do a lot of their own marketing. This is fine if you are a. gregarious, outgoing and a bit of a show off and b. not in full-time employment!  They do do some marketing for you, set up interviews and so on but a lot is down to the author. I had a book come out in the middle of the pandemic lockdown and it all fell - and felt - a bit flat.Sad really.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress levels through the roof -  mainly because it feels we are lead by a bunch of blind, soft nellies at a national level.  Just expected to get on with it, whilst being expected to support every other person and their dog. Sick to  death of hearing about 'mental health' - all that will do is create a crisis. Amazing how kids in the past came through wars, accidents, other extremes and just picked up and got on with it.  This is the oportunity missed to teach them what the current buzzword - resiliance - actually means.
self_publishing_comments: Many, many hours of unpaid work!  Each magazine issue for HOTT took around 30 hours. Stories for Pooka much the same, then when I took over editing as the editor became ill, around 40 hours to produce the copy and another 20 to send it round the various places it was advertised.  No real cost, apart from electricity and time. Oh - and coffee. Lots and lots of coffee :-)
Issues_Survey: It's a bit lengthy. Had I known how long, I would not have started it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: NOT IMPACTED: WRITING FROM HOME
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: LIMITED PERFORMANCE IN POETRY
Issues_Survey: Poets aren't paid enough

Importance_Other_Name: I do also make some money from audiobook editions of my published work.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My debut book was published in 2020. The publisher had to shift the pub date back from April to November in the UK, and bookstore/festival closures meant that I was unable to do public events. Excerpts planned to run in national press were cancelled to make space either for COVID coverage, or for 'lighter' topics (I write natural history with a focus on extinction). This was the worst possible outcome for a debut writer, particularly one who is attempting to get a foothold in the UK. I am a dual Australian/British national and I spend about 4-6 months each year in London, but in 2020 I was stranded by the Australian government's international travel restrictions in the UK for much longer than anticipated (an additional 6 months), with tailing income because of a loss of teaching I ordinarily do in the second half of the year in Sydney. I was lucky in the sense that I had a book in the market, and the final portion of my advance payment was timed with the pub date — so that lump sum saw me through. But I feel that the book's sales in the UK were much, much flatter than they might otherwise have been. In 2021 a "highly commended" in the Wainwright prize bought some visibility, along with a strong BBC interview. But we're still not where we could have been.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: In all frankness (!): Decreased productivity and anxiousness, yes. My partner is a playwright and we were separated from one another in different countries by border closures for some 2020: he also saw his income plummet. The initial period of the pandemic saw a flurry of activity and thought — I thought I was well positioned to write in this moment. But then I started overblowing deadlines (I write critical reviews for large print magazines; in 2020/21 The Guardian, The Atlantic and in Australia, The Monthly) and letting editors down, and though I was spending hours at the desk I had no fluency. I was incredibly ashamed of the lack of professionalism. I was paralysed by the fear of getting the virus for a time — I was living in a London borough with the highest death rate in the country — and I was sure that I would not be able to get to my parents if they got sick (they're in Perth, WA). I had a mild depressive episode, and needed to see a psychologist to re-stabilize. I had not yet built up enough of a writing community in London to have peers to lean on or for solidarity, and my Australian community were going through a very different texture of experience in terms of the COVID waves and variants.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: I signed my first book contract in 2013, with a mid-tier publisher in Australia. The contract was short and included world rights. The advance was very small.   I got an agent in 2018, and — via a side letter off setting US/North American rights to that agent — signed a contract in the US with a top tier publisher in 2019. That contract was more comprehensive, and for considerably more money. My Australian publisher sought to have their UK outlet produce the British edition of the book. That book was published in 2020 (hardback) / 2021 (paperback).   My second book contract was signed in 2021; with my existing Australian and US publishers, and with a new mid-tier UK publisher. The advance in the US was lower, but the advance in the UK and Australia was higher — the total is roughly equivalent to what I received for my first book, but the amounts are parcelled up differently (one on signing, one of partial submission, one on completed m/s, one on publication of hardback, one on publication of paperback). These contracts were all negotiated by my agent, who is US-based.
Contract_clauses: Not with publishers, no, but with teaching organisations. Especially where teaching orgs seek rights over written materials produced in the course of delivering a workshop series; or record lectures/talks to repackage and re-deliver to participants in future offerings, without further payment to the author/teacher. I learnt to be especially live to these circumstances.
Issues_Survey: Thank you for compiling this data!

Issues_Survey: Because of my full-time job - and the energy it depletes from me - I have not managed to do any writing for the last few years but I intend to sometime soon. I have a small publishing company and would like to convert all my titles into ebooks but have repeatedly found I've been unable to create epub files. There don't seem to be adequate guides on this around and I wonder if this is a large part of the reason why ebooks are not as popular as had been initially predicted - i.e. many titles aren't available as ebooks as publishers haven't managed to work out how to produce them (really)! I'm usually very good with technology and all kinds of software so this is perplexing me.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have not been working on a textbook in the last two years so no major impact. Just produced a couple of articles.
Contractual_changes: I have only written articles for Sociology review which pays a fixed fee and takes over copyright in the last year. Most of my previous writing was for textooks where a percentage royalty was payable.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Considerable savings on travel and subsistence costs have reduced losses. (NB I registered a business loss in both years but your format does not allow me to enter minus figures.)

year: Savings on other normal expenditure such as paid attendance at conferences.
Main_income: Regular Zooming with fellow authors has improved my productivity and helped reduce feelings of isolation. By "regular", I mean 6 times a week.
Importance_Other: With practice, self-publishing the actual book (formatting etc) becomes easier and quicker and I am confident there. Marketing is difficult, time-consuming and, if using paid advertising, can be expensive. The crucial thing about self-publishing is discoverability and that can be a nightmare.
Broadcasting: None as I have not agreed a contract with a traditional publisher in that time.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No direct impact - any savings on travel negated by office moving and new longer commute even if less frequent.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Only real impact is the loss of real world events, opportunities to meet fellow writers and publishers following my first publication,
Contractual_changes: None for me. My first publication was done without contract, have not been published since.
Issues_Survey: None

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Both of my 2020 books came out into lockdowns. I have lost ground and supermarkets are now less willing to stock my books. Publication of one of my books in Germany was delayed, which meant that a) the second part of the advance wasn't triggered b) there was a hiatus in selling to them, ie no new book that year. Another smaller publisher asked to defer payment for advances until after March 2022.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I was able to keep writing but I believe personnel at my publisher's faired less well and didn't do the job of which they're capable.
Contractual_changes: My publisher did try not to increase the advance at contract time but we had another publisher up our sleeves so that soon changed.
Issues_Survey: As I earn via a limited company, instead of tax years 20/21 and 19/20, I have given the figures for my financial year, i.e. 2019 and 2020. 2021 figures are not yet available.  Re the question about ebook royalties, I have utilised my current contracts for this, but some older contracts with a previous publisher contained escalators. I moved to my current publisher in 2016.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I kept working at university and the salary was not affected
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Overall I would say it had a positive impact as I had to learn  new skills like teaching on line and working as part of a team, even if remotely, to respond to a crisis. However, it was a very stressful time with great demands in teaching and administration and the uncertainty of the health emergency.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I didn't know what to put as my earnings have increased but not to do with Covid.

year: I think that question on the survey was poorly designed.

My earnings have increased substantially as I finished my PhD and got my first FT permanent job in academia. That has nothing to do with Covid though... Sorry! Prior to that I was teaching as an Associate Lecturer 2 days a week (terrible casual contract where I didn't get paid any holiday so they didn't pay me for 6 months of the year.)
Main_income: Can't really comment sorry. There was a period when writing my PhD was harder as my partner couldn't get furloughed and I was doing childcare.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: A show I am a core writer on decreased episodes from 6 a week (which would be one commission for a single writer), to 4 per week, which was then shared between two writers. All promised commissioned for the year ahead of the 6 episode show were cancelled and no guarantees were made about who would receive what work. Any in person teaching, workshops etc were cancelled. My stage play at the time was due to have a reading in the first May Covid hit and a production around about now - but the reading happened winter 2021 and now the production is likely to be around 2023. I secured an episode on a flagship, primetime television show, which I have experience in but have been trying to break back into after some time away - but the entire Covid impact on the show meant the process for me as a first time writer was riddled with incidents that would not ordinarily have happened and resulted in the episode being taken back and handed to an experienced hand to complete. The head of the show called me to give me the (bad) news - and admitted that had there not been the pressures of covid, mine and other episodes in the block would have had a little more time to iron out an issues, but with covid impact on filming and production, they were having to take the most straight forward and quick path - passing the episode to someone else. There were two other stage projects that I had which were cancelled due to the impact of covid on theatre and small theatre companies.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Writing is an isolated job - and most writers know that and enjoy that - but it is crucial to have some human interaction with one's fellow peers or production teams. I fear that with Zoom, much as it can benefit those who can't get away from home so easily, the cost benefits to production teams may mean writers are further side-lined and tucked away in a corner from the rest of the team who make a show.  Opportunities for newer voices in any ongoing programme in any medium is more of a risk (or seen that way) and production teams are leaning on experienced people and steering clear of anyone who may have a passion and a talent for writing, but challenging home lives. This is a tragedy, as often such are the voices with real insight into the human condition.  I went for two of the available SIESS grants - and they helped us get through as my partner was out of work for 7 months this year just gone. But given the tax bill I face, I would probably rather have faced the challenges of not having the grant, that raised the tax bill anyway.
Contract_clauses: The most recent contract I signed - like others - practically may as well say "we agree to conceded nothing in exchange for everything from the writer". when one is involved at the development stage of a project that may go on to be made for years and years and be sold elsewhere and for repeats, it is really difficult that we haven't found a way in which writers and creatives can be fairly remunerated for the input which ends up being part of a show - but very cleverly ownership of those ideas "shared" by all - so no one has to pay you for your vital contribution.
Issues_Survey: I believe that more needs to be done to involve and educate writers in negotiations and agents in supporting writers in those negotiations.  I also believe companies ought to pay the agent's fee or part of it, as they benefit more from an agent pairing them with a writer that fits a project. I believe development people from all companies ought to be the ones who travel to other parts of Britain (outside London) in order to connect with regional creatives, as opposed to freelance writers having to take the cost of a whole day out of work and travel and expenses to 'meet' a development person from a production company for what's usually half any hour, if that. If the companies can't pay the writer's expenses to meet with them, then they ought to pay for their development people to travel out and meet writers in the regions.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Fewer students using textbooks
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time for writing

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings in 2021: Unable to travel and less demand for material relating to travel.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: There has been very little change.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Again, very little change.

Also, some of my answers to do with writing go back to experiences in the 1990s.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Covid 19 will have had most effect on my earnings for 21-22. As I'm a television writer, the process is very much 'in advance'. Therefore, it's been the development of work that has slowed in 21-22, as companies have been catching up with their backlog of making shows, and somewhat filling the pipeline. 21-22 will have decreased my income from TV earnings a lot.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Negative impact - as above, it's hit due to earnings / pipeline. Also, meetings that aren't in person don't seem to have the same impact and I haven't been 'scoring' the jobs that I feel I would have done ordinarily.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: Questions were more skewed towards authors rather than audio-visual writers which made some questions difficult to answer; fully or in-part

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has altered the way I earn. But has given more time to focus and allowed for online delivery of some performance, talks and workshops which saves time / money on travel.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: N/a

Contractual_changes: The most significant thing for me has been the requirement that academic publications become open access.  I used to get roughly three times my current ALCS income; now they are just downloaded.  I don't rely on this income, so for me it does not really matter - but for those who do, it is a significant reduction.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Sales declined through the first year 2020.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The situation was distracting and I found it difficult to concentrate so did not write as much as I normally would.
self_publishing_comments: I used to spend a lot of time marketing, but I have reduced that because I sell well now and don't have to do as much. Thus, I can spend more time writing and minimal time marketing. I do keep an eye on stats every week and act accordingly. If more promo is needed, I will do that. I pay a virtual assistant to do some of the technical stuff and to keep things moving while I am away. I buy cover design and interior formatting when self-publishing. The majority of my self-published titles are reversions from a traditional publisher.
Contractual_changes: Because most of my income derives from e-book sales or page reads now, my percentage rates have gone up. My contracts are now pretty standard with escalators. All contracts are arranged through my agent.
Issues_Survey: I think I have been lucky over the last few years. Prior to 2018, when I signed with a new traditional publisher, my career was in the doldrums and I struggled to make a living. My responses then would have been very different from what they are now. E-books and Amazon KDP Select have made a tremendous difference to author earnings. It is possible to make a living and better now.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel as I now work from home. New opportunities for my husband in his field (outdoor education) as schools take on more outdoor activities in an effort to keep classrooms distanced.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity, working from home makes it harder to separate work from home and therefore to carve out writing time, unable to hold physical book events which were a key sales area for me.
self_publishing_comments: It was an interactive piece, so was made with Twine and released on Itch.io with no expectation of revenue.
Contractual_changes: I have never had an advance in my entire career, but I used to at least hear of friends and colleagues getting them. That doesn't seem to be the case any more.
Contract_clauses: Yes, I didn't realise until my novel was optioned by a film company that it was not the norm for the publisher to hold 100% of the rights. Fortunately they gave 50% of the rights back to me in order to get the film deal, but I sense that perhaps if the film maker had not felt strongly about this, they may not have. Similarly with my short story collection, I did not realise until after publication that they not only owned the rights to the collection as a whole, but also to each individual story. I suppose these are the pitfalls of not having an agent, but after spending more than 10 years attempting to find one who would take me on, I fear I am unagentable!

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Much greater stress, anxiety, and depression, and decreased productivity. I'm still meeting deadlines, but I do literally nothing but work, eat, and sleep.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Non-compete clauses, legal liability clauses, a bunch of other things. It always falls straight back to "Sign or go away".
Contractual_changes: Every year, the contracts get more hostile, more punitive, more unreasonable and unenforceable. Editors have no latitude to change them.
Contract_clauses: Non-compete clauses particularly. They crop up more and more, are almost certainly unenforceable, and extend for longer and longer periods -- 15 years on any work in the same subject area, most recently.
Issues_Survey: Remaining in the industry has become untenable. The trend to increasing predation is only going to get worse and worse.  I've been in publishing since 1993. I have written more than a hundred books for traditional publication, and edited three hundred more. Next week, I am taking a job in insurance, thanks to a friend.  It's heartbreaking.

year: indemnity

Broadcasting: I think the main issue is that freelance rates, which had in most cases been frozen, or reduced, in real terms, since at least 2000, have actually shrunk even further this past 18 months - publishers have used the pandemic as an excuse to cut rates and keep them low. For instance, in 2005 I was paid £1200 for a 2,800 word article; for the same slot today I am paid £1000 and have to file 5,000 words plus source photographs. Sorry but it has long become unsustainable - I genuinely can earn more stacking supermarket shelves or driving a moped now.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was not able to obtain funding to finish my book project or to obtain a new salaried position due to massive cuts in the academic sector. Secondly, as a German academic I earn part of my money from the German licensing service VG Wort. This normally provides a nice sum of money, but since they do not pay for academic publications that are only available as online sources in German libraries they informed me that I will not get paid for several of my articles that appeared during the pandemic because libraries cancelled their print subscriptions and only kept their digital subscriptions. This will affect my earnings in 2022 and henceforth as long as VG Wort does not change its regulations.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Apart from the above mentioned issues, the lockdown and the insecurity affected my health (stress-related illnesses that flared up) and it is a cause of constant anxiety that affects my productivity.
Contractual_changes: Publishers include clauses regarding reselling my work without paying part of this money to me as an author.
Contract_clauses: Yes, a large and reputable academic publisher pinned me down to wave my rights to any earnings for the subsequent reselling of a book chapter I wrote as part of a larger work.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I write theatre plays for the am dram market, and performances have dried up completely. Nobody is hiring plays so I earned nothing. My non writing job also disappeared during Covid. I worked within my own small town so travel costs were minimal.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I spent time homeschooling my granddaughter, and increased time caring for her so was unable to write. However, since my other job also disappeared, I was able to use the time previously spent working as a writer. I earned nothing at all from my theatre work, and it became harder to send novels to traditional publishers, and those that did accept submissions took a long time to reply.  When not caring for the child, I was able to write with fewer interruptions, as people were not expecting me to socialise or go out to meet them and there were fewer demands on my time.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The pandemic prompted us to emigrate from England to Australia, and we were fortunate to both keep our jobs and be able to work from home. For my husband, this meant his hours decreased significantly simply due to availability, so he was earning less. My journalism was impacted - I was writing fewer articles - and my income from this decreased for the first year of the pandemic by about 50%, but it has picked up again and is about 75% of some of my highest-earning years in journalism. I self-published a book that sold out and did well enough to earn about 4,000 GBP, but this really only covered the publishing costs, and while it was great (!) it was a bit of an outlier in my usual writing income. I do not usually make more than a few hundred pounds per book that is published (perhaps due to usually working with small-press publishers, so the royalties are small). We also spent all of our savings on moving to Australia and buying an house, renovating that house, and we have had a baby, all exciting but expensive!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: By and large, my writing hasn't been hugely affected by the pandemic, probably because I have always worked on fairly small scales anyway. My self-published book was hosted by Blackwell's and did very well; it was probably delayed by about a year due to the pandemic, but once it was published, it sold well, so that did not seem to be too affected by the pandemic. However, Blackwell's itself is being sold (devastating) and my book would probably have gone into a second edition with the support of Blackwell's - now, that won't happen. So there is a negative impact.   When the pandemic first hit the UK, my journalism dropped off completely for a few months, and has come back, not to its full extent, but pretty well. Some of that is due to my move oveaseas; I'm writing more book reviews and fewer theatre and museum exhibition reviews (almost all of which used to be London-centric,) because I'm simply not there, which is related to the pandemic, but not the precise cause.
self_publishing_comments: This novel, Ophelia Swam, was supported by Blackwell's, and I would not have self-published it if I did not have that arrangement in place, because effectively Blackwell's acted as my marketing and distribution platform. If I did not have that arrangement, the cost of self-publishing the book would not have been viable. It worked very well and I'm sorry we won't be able to repeat the project. I put about 5k into the initial production of the book (personal funds) which included paying a typesetter and covered printing costs. Then, I had an arrangement with Blackwell's, who bought the books (500 copies) for 40% off the RRP; we agreed the RRP to be beneficial to both them and me. It worked very nicely and reinforced that you can effectively cut out the middle-men if you and the bookseller have a good relationship.
Issues_Survey: It is interesting to continually fall through the cracks as a freelance writer in terms of government support. For example, I have recently had a baby, and while my husband (a working-from-home contractor,) was considered eligible for paternity leave reimbursement, I was not. This was not due to the amount of incoming I was earning (substantially less than he earns,) but due to working too few hours - effectively, my per-hour income is 'too high' to be considered eligible for maternity leave support. How curious to be penalised for earning a good hourly rate!?

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I ended up taking a more junior position in a different area of broadcasting for the security of a permanent job during the pandemic. This means my day rate for my journalism role has fallen from £300-350 to £150-180.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Initially it had a positive impact as I wrote more and got more writing commissions. I also took a course which helped develop my pitching skills, which helped me secure more and higher paid writing jobs. However, as I felt forced into a permanent role, which often involves 10-12 hour days it's harder to find time to write. Taking on commissions are often very stressful as I have to write around work (late at night, throughout the night and early in the morning) and throughout the weekend. This means months sometimes pass by with no breaks.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I've asked that I can continue to write for print publications and online platforms while I work full time as a journalist in broadcasting.
Contractual_changes: I've changed a contract to allow me to own the copyright of my work.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less close professional and social contact with other human beings.

year: Reduced productivity from working at home.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Getting books into supermarkets was, obviously, a nightmare. Ditto for bookshops.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Mores stressed because the books I thought would do well, didn't at all as they were debut books in a year of no access to humans, but...who's to say they might've done worse??? Hard to reckon.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: saving on travel costs and accommodation
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: more time for research and writing
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Requirement to submit next book to same publisher, following advice from SoA. Clause was struck out without argument
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As a romance novelist published primarily in e, I saw a significant sales increase.   However my husband left full time employment for consultancy work just before the pandemic started, so we lost his income for nine months.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has been fairly horrible trying to write with these stress levels and the limited opportunity to take a break, plus having children home schooling during lockdowns. My writing speed and fluency are dragging horribly compared to pre pandemic.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
self_publishing_comments: Incredibly profitable and a far better experience than working with traditional publishers. I control my covers and titles, I don't have to take "the sales department says" into account*, I can publish without a two year lag time, and it's not as if most authors get any sort of marketing from publishers so I'm scarcely doing any more work.   *My most recent trilogy was rejected on the grounds of "Sales says this setting doesn't sell". I've sold over 70,000 copies self pub at £3.99 since May 2020. Just saying.
Contractual_changes: Publishers being increasingly demanding about rights ("all formats now and yet to be invented throughout the universe"), refusing to include eg penalty clauses for non payment, whittling away at reversion clauses to make them useless.
Contract_clauses: Any reversion clause that doesn't allow the author to reclaim individual rights (eg print or audio) that a publisher isn't exploiting. Any reversion clause with a ludicrously low number like 50 copies a year.
Issues_Survey: I make enough money from e publishing that I don't actually need publishers. I'm quite surprised publishing is so happily watching the rise of this entire separate publishing economy where a lot of extremely profitable authors are going, instead of trying to improve its own practices.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less demand for talks based on published works
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity due to time pressures from my main job
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Royalties increased by 50% on what offered for a new books

year: Removal of clause for future publications
Rewriting of clauses about my own usage of what I had written (eg on my own website)
These followed recommendations from the Society of Authors
Books_Educational: Publishers are valuing the writer considerably less.

year: Publishers are failing to take into account digital forms of publishing sufficiently

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Minor savings on travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity
Contractual_changes: Reductions in royalty rate, disappearance of advances, no payment for chapters

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Most of my work is remote so covid did not affect it. I had more time to write and other aspects of my work became busier
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write/edit

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My full time 'proper job' is about getting people to work smarter and better online. So, with the move to online working, I've been busy!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity through virtual working and meetings
Contractual_changes: None, other than substantial increase to my ebook royalty rate from 50% to 80%

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As a writer of fiction I have seen sales dip - largely, I think due to closures of bookshops and libraries.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The overall situation has undoubtedly caused anxiety and stress - also a great sense of isolation.  Even though writing is a solitary occupation, the sense of being cut off from people and from ordinary life has been profound.  It has not always been easy to shut these emotions out and concentrate on working.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: I can't recall any changes in this respect.  I do leave that side of things to my agent, but I always read contracts carefully, and question anything I don't understand or am not happy about.
Issues_Survey: No - it seems very comprehensive.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: The fee paid
Issues_Survey: Northern Ireland was not given as a residential option - this is where I live.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No difference. I am an isolated hermit.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am untouched by it all.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: My book with a traditional publisher has no escape clause in the contract and the publisher has constantly refused to add one. After 5 years, he still has my book and refuses to tell me how many he is selling.  I had my lawyer send him a letter as he never sent me any royalties for three years following publication. My only resource is to wrest my book back by force, contract be damned.
self_publishing_comments: Not really. Exhaustion has set in.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Already stated previously
Issues_Survey: It's too damn long  :)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Postponed engagements
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Unable to travel to events, meetings etc.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Termination clauses

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Less travel, more time to work on writing. Can accept more commissions
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: A lot less time-wasting travel to festivals, at home and abroad. Festivals are fun but there are so many and a refusal often offends. I feel a duty to attend some and they take up a lot of time.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: time frames

year: monies being paid and when
reversion clauses for rights

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Much less publishing activity in ELT sector. I have not applied for an HMRC grant to boost income.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less paid work. More time for personal creative work.  The pandemic has given me more free time and I have written two novels since the first lockdown. Unfortunately, so have millions of other people, so no luck with a literary agent!
Changed_contract_Negotiations: See 26 above. I have requested changes this very morning to a contract, and haven't yet received a reply. This is for various articles across perhaps a year, and comes from a Chinese?US outfit. The contract specified that I would bear bank charges, which I am not happy with, as these will be a significant cut in my fee.  The amount of work required was not clearly specified, so I have asked for a clearer schedule of work.
Contractual_changes: None, as I have had so few contracts.
Issues_Survey: I am very concerned that author copyright is protected as it currently stands.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had a book released in lockdown, so sales and publicity suffered. I had a sharp drop-off in freelance work, too, but took on extra teaching and mentoring to cover it. My partner is also freelance and had no work for a while.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: For about a year I was very unproductive - anxiety, stress and lack of stimulation. I'm more productive now, but still feel very isolated. I haven't seen my agent or editor in over two years and have never met or even Zoomed with my publicity team. Online events are great, but I feel there's much less opportunity for newer or unknown writers to partake in them as it's big names that attract viewers. I also just miss going to in-person events, hearing and speaking to other writers, feeling creatively stimulated.
Contractual_changes: I haven't signed any new contracts in the past year.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My salaried employer enforced a 20% pay cut for everyone in the business, although this was a temporary measure that lasted 5 months, but it reduced my income for the year. However, we did save money by not being able to go out and I got some unexpected freelance work as story consultant and freelance editor.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've had to focus less on own writing because of a new family anyway, and one of the reasons I took a paying job was the unpredictability and low reward of writing for publication (as much as it a pleasure to do). As a professional copywriter, the work has got more stressful as we're expect to do more with less.

Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Before the pandemic, I was delivering face-to-face training so that was cancelled and hasn't yet resumed.  I have undertaken some work online but my business has yet to recover so I've taken on a PAYE role for two days a week to supplement my income.  My workforce wellbeing book was published in November 2019 and the Publisher was due to connect with Universities and Colleges to promote it with people who were undertaking, for instance business administration courses. I was promoting the book at face-to-face network meetings as well but the pandemic stopped us both from having those interactions and so potentially the sales of the book have been reduced.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The Publisher was looking to engage with Universities and Colleges which were running business administration, HR and other people management courses, to promote the book and to suggest that they could engage with me to offer advice and guidance to their students.  I've worked in business and management for thirty years and would very much like to support people as they move towards management roles.  I would have enjoyed that work and it could have been a positive income stream for me but the pandemic stopped the interaction of the Publisher and my attempts to engage with educational organisations have not been successful.
Issues_Survey: No

Contract_clauses: Most clauses of most contracts (what can you do though, it is what it is)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It had not impacted my earnings - my writing income is necessarily lumpy because I do not produce a book every year
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Reduced opportunity for any social interaction with other writers, and reduced opportunity to raise profile (eg festivals). Also the streamers overbought content and now it is difficult to sell screen rights.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress levels leading to a lack of motivation - coupled with higher demands from my main employer to prioritise non-writing work in favour of teaching. Some disruption to use of archive sources that prevented some work being finished to deadline.
Contractual_changes: N/A as I was fulfilling existing contracts not taking on new ones.

legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Issues_Survey: I am a retired academic and most of the income comes from the legacy articles/books that I published during my career.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Went down to 89% during last months of furlough
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Really enjoyed being off work - would have retired already if I could, but discovered (just before I assumed I'd retire) that I have to work an extra six years;  So COVID was actually great. More time to read and to write
self_publishing_comments: My publisher dropped me and handed me back the ownership of the five works they had previously published so decided to self publish so at least they were available to readers

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My main income comes from writing about gardening, which experienced a surge in the pandemic. My writing is also mainly online, through my blog and YouTube channel, so both of these saw substantial increases in revenue, too. My YouTube channel is now my main source of income via YouTube advertising, although you didn't mention YouTube or vlogging in one of the categories (where you list the importance of different earning categories), so this may not be fully reflected in your results.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The increase in online activity has opened up new channels, although I may not necessarily take them up - eg paid newsletters through substack or Patreon, brand collaborations etc. It's difficult to measure productivity as I am slowing down as I get older rather than due to the pandemic. I think the pandemic has, however, been very stressful so there is more underlying anxiety.
self_publishing_comments: We paid a professional designer £1,400. Sales are mainly driven through my blog without any extra promotion.
Contractual_changes: I haven't experienced any changes as I have self published or earned through my blog or vlog. I've been doing that for at least five years, so have earned very little through the traditional agented channels.
Issues_Survey: Just that some of the questions should have had 'don't know' and 'not relevant' as options.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I work from home anyway, so no difference there. Hard to say how much potential income lost from cancelling tour of indie bookshops.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Periods of lethargy and a certain lack of confidence re travelling. Meeting with other authors was a huge loss.

Importance_Other_Name: MP3 & CD & downloads of academic commentary on Shakespeare
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Marginal saving on eating out/leisure trips
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lock-down gave a bit more time to complete two writing projects - one fiction, one non-fiction
self_publishing_comments: Self-publishing is a hobby. I get royalties from work published by others, but I don't expect to make money from either the niche non-fiction I publish myself, or the fictional or poetic material. I am happy to pay a printer to produce physical books and to upload to Amazon and to create ebooks for KDP. Also I don't mind taking adverts out in literary or niche magazines and doing some marketing myself. Overall, I do not make money out of these enterprises at present - but I enjoy the hobby, (much as someone is happy to spend money on belonging to a swish golf club, but doesn't expect to be come the next Olympic champion!) I like to think that I have books out there - it's better than having them on a computer!
Issues_Survey: It was simple and easy

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Prevented travel and face-to-face communication, so I haven't enjoyed the work as much and have felt isolated less interested in my work.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: An attempt to re-publish my work in books and online. My invoices always state FBSR, single use only. I pointed this out to the publisher and I am now paid extra for additional use.  Publisher attempted to put all liabilities onto me. I refused.  This is a dodgy area. If people ignore an undesirable contract, and not sign, they are still bound by it if they submit work after seeing it. It's essential to clearly refuse aspects of the contract in writing, and retain evidence.
Issues_Survey: This question should read: Do you have any comments …

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time to write, less distractions
Changed_contract_Negotiations: 1) Article fees negotiated up 2) Contract terms on book series editorship negotiated to include future editions even if I am no longer editor.  No, no reference made to model contracts.
self_publishing_comments: Zero costs - also zero income - the thing in question is a free to read blog. However, it does relate to a published (not self-published) book
Contractual_changes: None that I can think of
Issues_Survey: Questions about Royalty rates on books are hard to answer as it depends on the publisher. I have answered based on the book of mine that sells the most and generates the most income, but I have contracts with several other publishers and the rates vary.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Having children at home, and home-schooling, meant less time and space to work. Beginning fewer new projects than usual during lock-down resulted in a financial 'hungry gap' that I am just reaching the other side of this month (with payments due mid February).   On the other hand, having so much time at home without so much work gave me more 'dreaming' time than usual, which has resulted in a number of bigger-than-usual visions for new projects, which I hope will go ahead. (So that, overall, perhaps the financial losses caused by covid will be balanced by future gains. I hope so!)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I write books for children, specialising in books that celebrate nature and encourage green living.   The lockdowns have, in my eyes, given many families a direct experience of the value of nature, which they may not have had time to appreciate in the busyness of normal life. I hope that this will mean that the demand for children's books that celebrate the natural world will continue to grow.
Contractual_changes: As in the past I haven't been confident in the jargon of contracts, I've just trusted my agent to deal with the paperwork, and to let me know if there's anything we could negotiate.
Contract_clauses: I am in the process of negotiating with a publisher about the licensing rights on a book we are planning together. As I said, I would like to be able to re-use my own re-tellings in different (obviously non-competing) markets. In the past I have written traditional tales for educational publishers, and had a clause in my contract allowing me to re-use my re-tellings in the trade market, which I very much valued.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: On the plus side, I have had more time to write, as I write at home, and also more time to think about what I'm writing, as I have had fewer distractions.  On the negative side, I have had less in-person interaction with friends and acquaintances. I live in a university area, and normally have regular social meetings with students and faculty, and my conversation with them is both inspiring and informative.  It is these contacts that I have missed both in a personal sense and in regard to my intellectual/creative activities.
Issues_Survey: The question regarding "earnings" was vague for me. I know my overall income, but am not sure what part of it is  considered "earnings" as a portion of it is from savings, investments, capital gain, and the state pension, and some of it is not acquired in the UK (I report and pay for income in more than one country).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Home working did not reduce costs as my office in a mile away, bills increased and I worked only part time due to client closures.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has benefitted me as deadlines reduced, hours work reduced and more time was available for talking, training and learning.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No, I have a law degree and a knowledge of the market, so I do it myself.
self_publishing_comments: Writing as a professional about your profession and for academic purposes, cost way more in time than you receive in revenue. My three business books will never return the years of research.  Fiction about breaks even with the time expended marketing and publishing costs. It does not make a significant contribution to household income when you have a decent well paying job already.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No school visits.

year: Less live literature events
Depression

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: At 83, I am fully retired so only earn from my books via ALCS. Last March I got about half of what I would previously have expected from borrowing charges. Hardly surprising as many libraries shut.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Covid-129 has not affected me, see above.  I have published a book in 2021, but that will hardly have got into libraries yet. I am working on another, but my routines have not been affected .
Issues_Survey: I have only ever been a part-time writer as a sideline to my teaching. The aim of this questionnaire appears slanted more towards people who depend on their writing income, which I never have.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More time for writing.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have lost earnings from school visits which were cancelled and have not yet been reinstated yet.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have lost confidence
Issues_Survey: Whilst I have continued copywriting during the pandemic, my creative writing has suffered. I've lost confidence in the publishing system (very middle class and risk averse). Self-publishing is the way forward, but takes a great deal of work. The way agents / publishers ask for submissions, but don't respond is soul destroying.  Also. Public Lending Right is OK IF your work is in the sample libraries. The libraries that stock my books have been taken off, so income from PLR has dried up.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Savings on travel costs, personal care (hair/salon treatments etc), cleaner.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Basically no impact, other than inability to attend or run live events relating to my books.
Issues_Survey: Some of the questions didn't cover all eventualities.   I would have answered 'Not applicable' to some - and did skip some but forgot with others so answered the closest to my situation.   Also I felt the questions didn't always relate to me - for example I haven't self-published within the last year but did several times the year before; I can't remember the royalty rates with my early books although I still regularly receive payments from them.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Permanently working from home so no need for two cars and much reduced travel costs.
I have benefited because the lockdowns precluded travelling to lectures and gigs so I have had more time for writing (and editing), and there have been concomitant savings on costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Writing is always a solitary occupation, but face to face meetings with other writers provide an important stimulus. Zoom has substituted fairly adequately for such meetings but it isn't quite as satisfactory.   I haven't PERSONALLY suffered anxiety or stress as a result of the pandemic, but of course I've been concerned about family and friends - and like all of us, I've lost a few.   The effect on my productivity has been largely positive.
Contractual_changes: None that I can think of!
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Although I've now recently retired, (this Jan) my main income was nursery nurse bank staff. Earnings were reduced substantially, due to nursery closure and lockdown.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Depression and lack of enthusiasm. Living on your own in lockdown is okay for a while as writing time was increased, but for the length of lockdown it became very depressing as I had to also shield through health issues.
Contractual_changes: My contract for my new book published in July 2021 was the same with no changes as the one I had in 2015

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: No one is travelling so earnings from my travel writing publications have plummeted.  Haven't been able to run in-person workshops. I coach writers and their incomes have fallen which mean they can't afford coaching.
No school visits and longer delay between work being accepted and publication.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less to write about when you're largely confined to the house.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contract_clauses: No. But I believe my agent has managed to remove a few things.
Issues_Survey: Considering we create the product, I've always thought writers didn't get a big enough slice of the pie.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have been in the process of retiring so it is not possible to link the reduction in my earnings to Covid
Contractual_changes: Significant reduction in rates of pay for new members of the team I worked with, followed by reduction in fees for all the team  based on revenue for digital access to text (a professional legal reference work)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: A slight decrease in work coming in.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Amount of professional liability insurance. No reference to professional body.

Importance_Other_Name: Translation of academic and scientific books/publications
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Decline in most sources of income from a range of clients and publications, as well as income derived from translation work for academics and research institutions, in addition to less publishing and editorial work associated with various imprints and series for which I am an editor.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Since a good proportion of my income was based on working with academics and other authors in Europe and elsewhere, travel constraints were a minor but nonetheless noticeable factor, (and could be alleviated by use of technology such as Zoom for face to face meetings) but the much greater impact came from the disruption of translation and publishing work associated with uncertainties in the world of scientific journals and research monographs. This has meant a substantial decline in income and activity in 2021-2022 which will probably mean a substantial decline in turnover during the tax year 2021-2022. The uncertainty about income levels from this work has created a major strain both at home and in relations with colleagues in the publishing business where many people are losing their jobs or being subjected to great strain in their workplace connected to the unpredictability surrounding their future in publishing. There has however been an upside for those who are self-employed if their income has not been too greatly affected, due to lower expectations in terms of deadlines and less hassle. However the present situation remains one of great uncertainty, and one cannot know what one's income will be in the next couple of years.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: The contract concerned a translation that I had made. However the publisher (a major US/European-based academic press) had wanted to publish the work with an attribution of translator to two other people who had not in fact contributed in any way to my translation in the work to be published. I thus refused to sign the contract, and to release my copyright until their names were removed as translators of the work. After a brief period of stalemate, the publisher was obliged to concede that the other names would be removed so that publication could take place.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I have referred to this earlier in the questionnaire and it concerned the wrongful attribution of others as partial translators in a work that was in fact wholly translated by me. Since the publisher (a major US/European publishing firm) could not publish the book unless I signed the contract to provide a copyright release, I was able to insist on the removal of their names from the published work.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Major commissions cancelled. Theatres not commissioning new work. Productions of already existing plays and musicals cancelled.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I liked the peace and quiet and lack of pressure.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased productivity in terms of time. Had ample time to sort my work, plans and ideas.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Unable to attend the London Book Fair, which tends to lead to translation work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Fewer distractions.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I usually quote the Translators Association guidance rate.

year: I make sure I am not liable for actionable content which has been accurately translated.
I don't allow  (American) publishers to rewrite a translation without my agreement. (UK publishers don't suggest it.)

Importance_Other_Name: Short stories for Hooked on Snapchat
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was earning regularly selling online short stories to the Hooked app. During covid they were closed to submissions.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I'm self-employed and work from home. This was harder to do with a house full of husband working from home and kids doing online learning. I also regularly lost access to my laptop since the kids needed it for school. One of my kids was particularly affected by stress during the pandemic so that also took up a  lot of my time and energy.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Book advances seem to be lower than previously (even though book sales have gone up!)

year: Living costs not much affected by the pandemic (I was already working from home etc)
Thank goodness the schools are open again
Main_income: Yes, as a matter of course
Audio_RadioNonFiction: I can't think of any this year

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It has not affected my household. My wife and I are in the fortunate position of being comfortably retired. My writing keeps me usefully occupied as well as making a contribution to our incomes.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Work has completely dried up.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Work has completely dried up. For first time in my life I’m suffering from depression and am on medication.

Importance_Other_Name: copy-/content writing (I write 'sleep stories' for a meditation app)
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I've ticked 'no impact' but really it's mixed. As an introvert who finds public events extremely challenging, the switch to virtual events and other kinds of remote working has been very welcome, but the general increase in anxiety levels due to its affect on individuals and society overall has been hard.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I do a kind of (unsigned) copywriting for an American company who have very strict 'work-for-hire' contract which includes clauses about waiving moral rights and so forth, which they refuse to amend; so far because the fees are good and the work I do for them is enjoyable not hugely important to me I have accepted the terms
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Maybe not exactly a dispute but a wish for this to be changed and a refusal from them
Contract_clauses: requests to waive moral rights and rights of attribution

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of contracts as businesses not spending money or not allowing contractors on site.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have had enough free time to finish writing a novel and several short stories.
Decreased productivity, fewer opportunities for publication, publications paying less, taking longer to respond.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Magazine contracts now taking “all rights” for short fiction.
Contractual_changes: Magazines now asking for “all rights” or reverting to first rights but with much lower payments.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of book sales and royalties due to disruption to learning in further education.
More time to write and got a publishing contract during the pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety & stress (I am also a carer) - made writing more difficult even if I had more time to write and got a paid contract.
self_publishing_comments: It is a labour of love, but does give consistent revenue after a while. It takes a lot of personal investment to build a brand and body of work to get to that point however.
