Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Increased book sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Little impact. Less travel.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No. I sought my ownership rights back from a publisher who agreed immediately.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: I sought permission to list in ALCS and PLR my contribution to two volumes of collected essays by various authors: this was granted in one case, withheld in the other (therefore the latter work is not listed among my contributions).
self_publishing_comments: I published this through my own publishing house, which so far mostly publishes my own work, but there are works by other authors in the pipeline. So far this publishing house has not earned enough to cover costs.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: I was offered a tiered payment contract based on sales, which I refused.
Contractual_changes: An attempt to offer a tiered contract with payment based on sales. I refused this but ended up with £500 less due to lower sales.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My main publisher closed, scrapping multiple projects, and blamed the pandemic for their day job occupying a greater amount of their time, while another publisher severely delayed my upcoming book and appeared not to be taking on new books due to the pandemic-related reshuffling of their schedule.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My mental health has been severely impacted, and though I managed to keep writing throughout much of last year, I subsequently felt that the work I produced was unpublishable.   That and the disappointments of watching my career collapse, along with the severe financial strain the sudden loss of most of my income caused me, have led me to quit writing for the foreseeable future.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: This is too complicated to cover in detail, but a publisher supplied me with a contract that they subsequently decided was unfit for purpose and then failed to issue a replacement.  They've since quit publishing and the book is in limbo.
Contractual_changes: None that I can think of.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Despite making more money, there would have been more opportunities had the pandemic had not happened. There were significant periods of time where I had no work.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The pandemic brought about a lot of uncertainty for screenwriters - we had no idea when production wold start up again and if we would have a job when it did. This gave most writers, including myself major anxiety which made it difficult to focus or be productive.   When production did start up, due to COVID restrictions writers were asked for more rewrites (which were usually unpaid), had to accept extremely difficult deadlines for last-minute changes and were expected to just get on with it and be grateful for the work.   Face to face meeting with producers and production companies came to a halt and while meetings and story conferences could take place on Zoom, it wasn't the same and left all parties exhausted and with no real sense of connection. These type of meetings are vital to a writer's career as they the prime source of networking and can ensure the next job. Without them or having less of them means less work and also leaves writers, who already work in a very isolated profession, feeling even more alone and on the outside of the film and TV industry.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: The production company refused to adhere to WGGB guidelines for writers. I challenged this but was told this is standard for Netflix as they don't apply to WGGB guidelines.

year: Another clause I challenged was with regards to the production company being able to cut a writer off or stand them down at any given point in the process without guarantee of payment.
Books_Games: Yes - the production company having the right to stand the writer down for ano apparent reason and refusal to adhere to WGGB guidelines.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less things being made. No theatre
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Cost

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Despite the fact that I specialise as a travel journalist, and the ongoing restrictions on travel, I received a lot of commissions related to travel, as well as copywriting, audiovisual and scriptwriting  work (corporate videos, documentaries,  websites and rebranding for the hospitality and travel industries).   There have been negative impacts in terms of ability to travel, network, and plan collaborative projects, but in terms of overall earnings I enjoyed a slight upswing in revenue and commissions during the pandemic. I did not expect this at all.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Global syndication rights for magazine articles across different media outlets and platforms. Intellectual copyright.
Contract_clauses: The global right to reuse articles across all formats and media owned by the parent company, and to syndicate the work, without additional compensation.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Working from home was much more productive

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Income generating books are walking books.  Interest has increased during pandemic.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Subject of main books has become more popular
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The first year I had speaking events and in-person creative writing courses cancelled. However, the self-employed Covid grant made up for that. The second year I didn't claim the grant. There were still no speaking events or courses. And then my publisher (Lion Hudson) couldn't survive the pandemic and was taken over by SPCK. They are now 'streamlining' the adult fiction line and dropping most of their authors. Result: I don't have a book contract for this year so income down (that is this year, but will only be reflected in tax year 21/22). Income also down on royalties as my publisher struggled to get books into bricks and mortar bookshops due to shops being shut in lockdown. Lion Hudson put publication of all fiction on hold in 2020 and were not offering any new contracts. However, I had the 6th book in a series ready for contract. I felt compelled to waive my advance in order for them to agree to publish it.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I work from home. In the first year my husband and school age daughter were both working from home too. We have a small house and there was very little room for us all. I felt besieged. I struggled to write as I am so used to silence. I couldn't get away on writing retreats, research trips or even to go write in coffee shops or libraries.  My last book ended up being two months late in delivery to publisher as I couldn't get it finished in the time frame I usually do.   The second year my daughter was back in school (mostly) but husband still working from home. I had a bit more freedom to get out and about but writing at home still a problem.  Unable to do creative writing classes I used to do. No festivals, workshops, readings to meet other writers and speak to readers. I felt very isolated and cut off. Online didn't replace that for me. In fact I felt the online adding to my anxiety as I felt my home was no longer private. I had nowhere to retreat to. And nowhere to escape to.
Contractual_changes: This last year I felt compelled to agree to waive my advance completely in order to get my book published. The publisher said they would not be able to take the book on unless I waived my advance. I am now moving on from that publisher with a new series that my agent is currently trying to place. I cannot afford to waive an advance again.
Contract_clauses: Reversion of rights clause is that the book is to be 'made available.' in any form. But that means it can just be made available on Amazon POD and if my sales fall to a trickle I can't get the rights back. I would far prefer a minimum sales threshold.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of Public Lending Right payments (as public libraries were closed for a long period) and loss of speakers' fees as no public talks were held. There was a saving on travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: As libraries and archives were closed, I could not access the much of the published or any of the manuscript materials on which my writing is based. Although many older published work is available online, more recent books (e.g. published within the last 30 years) are not. Some libraries were willing & able to scan limited numbers of pages (within copyright constraints) and send them by email; others were not. Interlibrary loan was only available for items which could be scanned. This had a serious impact on the books which I was contracted to write during the period of Covid-19 restrictions. My anxiety and stress was also severely increased, so that I was less able to write coherently. In addition, as academic conferences did not take place, bookshops were closed, and university courses were not taught or reduced in scope, my usual channels of distribution were closed and my book sales reduced.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Requirement for the publisher to receive first option on future books.
self_publishing_comments: If you want to sell a self-published book for profit, you will have to spend a lot of time and money promoting it. If you only want to circulate it among already-interested persons and are not interested in the income, then no problem.
Contractual_changes: Contracts are longer and have longer legal explanation of the meaning of terms.

year: Royalties have reduced from a standard of 10% on hardback sales to 7.5% or 5%.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I no longer do much in the way of school events so Covid didn't affect my earnings much at all. It definitely had an impact on PR, book festivals, travel, speaking engagements, etc. Nearly all wiped out.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: My agent handles all contracts so I don't pay any attention to them.

year: I entirely trust my agent.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: To begin with, stress and difficulty focusing; then, a move to online teaching in my academic job which was very disruptive to writing. On the positive side, much greater online visibility for my work.
Contractual_changes: My only contractual dealing in the last year was a request from the publishers of a journal I edit to accept a one-off reduction in my fee for one year only reflecting reduced travel during COVID. I accepted this. The fee has now reverted to its former level.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Had more time to think and write
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: At a couple of stages during the pandemic I had to work from home, which meant that my energy bills rose slightly, but this did not impact in any significant way on my finances.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: COVID-19 meant that during some periods I was not allowed to work in my office (on campus) - I had to work at home. For a couple of months when I had to work at home, my neighbours started to renovate their house - the noise of the renovations significantly increased my anxiety levels (I already experience anxiety exacerbated by noise when working). The experience means that now - even after the situation is no longer an issue - I am more anxious when writing, because I am aware of how sudden writing conditions can be threatened and made nearly impossible.
Contract_clauses: No (but I probably do not pay close enough attention to clauses in contracts when I am publishing (which is mainly research articles in journals).

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: New editions of three school books (for which I was the main author) were published during CoVid. One was for overseas markets. Sales of all three were impacted by school closures during CoVid. The lost income is hard to quantify, but am putting it down as 'moderate'. Not sure that the books can ever make up lost ground.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: For one book, the work during CoVid was extremely stressful as the editors / chief graphic designer in the UK were working from home, and the detailed layout was carried out in India, presumably by people also working from home. There were communication problems throughout, and it often felt as if nobody had a handle on the project. The result was some major layout problems which did not show up until the last minute, too late to make text changes to suit. (Think of a format change at third proofs!!!!!!!!)  All very stressful, and deeply painful. As I write this, the experience still hurts!  The two other books went through the writing and production process smoothly. All the layout work was done in the UK by an excellent team that was very familiar with the course, and CoVid did not seem to have any impact.
Contractual_changes: Have not had a new contract in the past year.
Contract_clauses: Have not had a contract in past year.
Issues_Survey: Royalties for the electronic versions of printed books (ie where print leads) need to be looked at. Given the money saved on printing and warehousing, they are much too low.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased demands of other aspects of academic work

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Not significantly

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I decided to retire from academic work at Christmas 2021. My pension is not payable until I reach retirement age (66) which is in another 6 months, so my only income has really been from some occasional academic work.   royalties etc are nice but certainly are not significant income!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The stress of remote teaching was becoming too much for me. PTSD that I had recovered from was re-emerging as Stress-related illness so I chose to retire earlier than originally planned.   I am now happy to have the chance to spend my time writing and doing consultancy work but as yet, it's not bringing me any income.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Contractual_changes: it's all rather new to me. so I don't really know.   However, one of my co-authors is a very experienced author (50 years+) and is very unhappy with the way things are done these days.  On her advice, I always go to Society of Authors with a contract.
Contract_clauses: I have had a bit of dispute with an editor who felt my writing (about signs, symptoms and impact of COVID-19 on ICU patients ) was "too technical" and "too graphic" for a non-specialist audience. This was for a charity, so no contract involved, but it was problematic at the time.
Issues_Survey: Format of the questionnaire which does not allow full answers sometimes (see comments elsewhere)

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: When the COVID-19 pandemic started, I was commuting 3 days a week to London, so short-term I saved on travel costs. I then went on planned maternity leave in June 2020 and went back to work in January 2021, where again as my employer still mandated remote working, I saved on travel costs. I then changed jobs in May 2021 to work for a fully remote company, so since then the pandemic has not affected my day job earnings.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My productivity has been fine, but having a debut novel come out in the middle of a pandemic has not been ideal - I am aware that many events planned by my publisher (e.g. hand-delivery of advance readers' copies to bookshops, in-person launch event, etc.) had to be cancelled due to Covid, and I can't help wondering how that might have affected sales. Many employees at my publisher were also furloughed, meaning that the rest of the team were overworked and communication with them suffered.
Contractual_changes: As a relatively new professional writer, it's hard for me to say - I've only signed contracts for two books and haven't noticed much difference between the two contracts.
Contract_clauses: I thought the 'morality clause' of my first US contract was potentially problematic, as it seemed quite vague in wording: 'if Author’s conduct evidences a lack of due regard for public conventions and morals, or Author commits a crime or any other act that will tend to bring Author into serious contempt, and such behavior would materially damage the Work’s reputation or sales, Publisher may terminate this Agreement and, in addition to Publisher’s other legal remedies, Author will promptly repay the portion of the Advance previously paid to Author, or, if such breach occurred following publication of the Work, Author will promptly repay the portion of the Advance which has not yet been recouped by Publisher.' This clause was deleted in my second US contract - I'm not sure if this was due to pressure from my agent or my publisher's decision!
Issues_Survey: As a relatively new professional writer, I was unqualified to answer the questions about how things have changed in the past 5 years, but I look forward to reading the results!

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Most of my work comes from academic presses, so with library and university closures, authors took longer to deliver their manuscripts and for a while fewer were coming in. It also meant that they were more likely to come in incomplete or in need of more administrative checks; the budget for each project is fixed before the job comes in, which meant I would spend more hours on a project but not be paid any extra.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: - Disrupted delivery of mss at the start; later, a run of very urgent mss that were all priority jobs because funding agreements etc. stipulated a certain publication date.  - More admin and emailing with each job (again folded into a fixed budget) to address various Covid-related problems encountered by authors  - General anxiety and stress that affect concentration and productivity.
Decreased productivity, decreased opportunity for appearances/ talks, increased anxiety

Importance_Other_Name: Libretti for classical, and other, composers
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I had several major premieres of musical works (I am a librettist) set for performance in 2020, and they were cancelled. In one case, this cost a £2,000 fee as the actual project was cancelled. In another, I had already been paid the fee, but the performance was cancelled - and the performance would have led to publicity and further commissions.   A book was due to launch in April 2020, and this was delayed until 2021, when it launched online only, with no festival appearances and consequently got much less exposure than it would have done otherwise.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Like so many other activities, the literary circuit has been suspended, meaning a reduction in networking, fellowship, contacts, exchange of ideas, etc.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I mentioned this earlier in the survey.  A performer claimed to have co-written my original work. I took professional advice and after a lengthy process the claim was formally withdrawn. Though no money was involved, it was extremely distressing.      Something similar happened many years ago when a producer who had written the book for a musical project then sought to claim co-authorship in the lyrics.  In that occasion, the composer resolved it very swiftly in my favour.  It was again, distressing, though quickly resolved.  It has made me wary in future cases. I do a great deal of commissioned work for festivals, special occasions, organisations and individuals, and I am now alert to this danger, though I do not know of a way of preventing it in advance that does not feel brutally legalistic.   It has introduced an anxiety into what would naturally have been positive collaborative relationships.    I looked into legal insurance with a view to taking formal legal action in such cases, but found it prohibitively expensive. The Society of Authors provides advice, and will write on one's behalf (they have never had to do so for me, but offered to do so) but cannot enter into actual legal disputes.  Having twice been stung in this way, I confess to some anxiety over it.
Issues_Survey: Grateful to you for taking an interest

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: As an indie-author I believe I have sold more copies of both ebooks and paperbacks owing to the pandemic than I might have done otherwise - particularly in terms of the lead of up to Christmas in both 2020 and 2021, but also in the lockdowns when I think people were buying more books from Amazon because of ease of delivery.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: 2020 was one of my best writing years (in terms of creation!) - particularly during the summer where perhaps I might have previously been distracted by more social activities/holidays (it was as though the pandemic gave you permission to stay at home and not interact - brilliant for us introverts!) - and it gave me the time to self publish paperbacks for the first time (previously I'd only produced ebooks).
self_publishing_comments: I used to think getting a traditional publishing deal was my goal, but now I'm quite content with self-publishing. It's great to be in control (of timescales, cover designs, etc.) and there are no gatekeepers, only direct feedback from readers. I have created a small team to assist me (cover designer, photographer for cover images, proofreader, etc.) and am now reasonably confident with the processes involved. Yes, there is lots of work involved in typesetting, and so forth, but it gets easier the more often you do it. Yes, there is lots of marketing involved, and that's always difficult, but I understand from fellow authors who are traditionally published that there is still marketing involvement expected of them anyway, so I don't think it makes much difference.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Not having to go out and being tucked at home with my family was lovely. We all did our separate things during the day then would come together in the kitchen when I started cooking dinner. My productivity by day was greatly increased - I no longer found myself working until the early hours on deadline week.

Broadcasting: No - it's a good survey - perhaps you could ask more how much people have earnt in royalties?

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Way before COVID arrived I had become a free lance tour guide at C.S. Lewis’s house on the outskirts Oxford, based on my knowledge and writings on him and his friends. The touring was becoming more and more popular, mainly from overseas groups. A number of US visitors had read or knew about my books. The tours had to stop because of the covid dangers. It only recently that the house was able to open again for visitors. We impose safety restrictions carefully thought put. The tours are just slowly increasing. As I live fairly near to Oxford it is viable for me to continue tours.  As I travel to my small office, where most of my books are, the rise in fuel costs is a pain. This will also lessen my takings too from my tour guiding. However it is always a refreshing break from the writing. Healthy.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: The stress of covid is mainly the impact that most feel. My work actually gives a continuing structure that helps health. I do however need to plan my work more, which is a good thing, as I’m getting older now in my seventies. Zoom has opened up possibilities, as I less frequently get invited to speak on the US. Oxford is a good place to be near, for me, as a writer. I’ve had to avoid The Bodleian for over two years, but things are changing.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: One publication I regularly write features for requested submissions, and then on being asked what the fee was stated it would be unpaid "because of Covid".
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity. Fees for writing seem static or even to have decreased, even though Covid seems to have increased costs of living.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: A small increase in royalties if a book sells above a specified number of copies
Issues_Survey: Many contracts for publications like BBC or Archant do a rights grab - you have to give them copyright and they can reuse (or not be paid to write the article). They won't budge on this. And it seems unreasonable when copyright for articles used to be 'first printing rights', sometimes with a limit on how soon the work could be resold.  It seems unfair that there is no payment for articles kept online. You used to write an article, it would be printed , the publication printed it once and you were paid once. Now articles are kept online indefinitely and although you the author are only paid once the publication continues to earn income from your work via subscription fees or advertising payments. This seems really unfair.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Question is too invasive
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less time away on trips, more time on the computer = more time to write
Contractual_changes: None, as I have published nothing new for payment

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I have had a specialist research interest in pandemics since the early 2000s and held various policy roles over that period so I have been much in demand for freelance journalism, contributing to national print media and frequent (unpaid) broadcast or podcast appearances.  Major savings on travel costs.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Increased stress and reduced opportunities for networking. Distraction from various pre-existing contracts to meet immediate demands for pandemic commentary - involved a certain amount of moral injury to collaborators in those projects.
Contractual_changes: Academic publishers have reduced royalties to the point almost of non-existence, especially with the emphasis on online materials. Less willing to agree reversion rights, which I have exercised under some 1970s and 1980s contracts. In some cases, their records are so poor that they don't seem to realise that rights have been reverted.
Contract_clauses: Publishers seem to be pushing more legal liabilities onto authors in case of litigation but it is hard to pin this down and separate it from wider legal changes.
Issues_Survey: Increasingly considering self-publication - with Print On Demand services, the main reason to go with a traditional publisher for academic writing is marketing and distribution - but they no longer do much of this. If I have to do all the promotion via Twitter, etc, I might as well cut them out, apart from UKRI requirements - but I plan to retire to avoid these. Also looking at this as a way to reach the borderline trade/academic market without having to struggle to find an agent, although I would like to use them if the initial works succeed.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Reduction of team in work and consecutive reduction of published works.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: More writing for the same salary.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The SEISS grants inflated my earnings temporarily.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Having both my children at home during the pandemic actually allowed me to increase my productivity because my working day wasn't interrupted by the school run, and my husband was at home to help with the home-learning and childcare.   The SEISS grants inflated my earnings.  Publishers seemed to be using the time to get ahead commissioning wise, so I was noticeably more busy than usual.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Online advertising rates, esp. Facebook, collapsed in the early stages of the pandemic. This significantly raised the ROI on ads and this led to a significant increase on profits for my backlist.
self_publishing_comments: For a typical novel launch, say 100,000 words. I will spend 2-3 days preparing marketing material. Another 2 days on launch prep and launch activity. 1 day formatting and publishing eBooks and paperbacks and reviewing test prints. 2 days working with beta team. (although this can be much higher, depending on what they find) 3 days and about £3,000 - £5,000 on running adverts. £300 on cover art. £250 on line editing.  That's the initial launch. If a backlist title looks promising, I may put more time and money into it. For my most successful self-published title to date (about 58,000 sales) I've spent several weeks of effort in the years since its launch to promote it, rework the advertising copy, and change cover art.
Issues_Survey: I found it telling that the survey asked questions about books and then asked questions about e-books, as if e-books are not books. They are. Frankly, I found this insulting and ludicrous.  Also, I was unclear where I was to respond about audiobooks, which represents a far greater part of my writing income than printed books.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Slower work rate (stress, anxiety), fall in commissions.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Anxiety and stress, decreased productivity, slow work-rate. Reviving now, by the look of it.

Contractual_changes: Two magazines that previously took all rights to fiction content, changed their practice so that the author would continue to own the copyright.  Sadly, another publisher of three popular magazines switched in the other direction and now demand all rights for fiction content.
Contract_clauses: I have signed away all rights to short fiction content for certain publishers who demand it. I am really torn on this: the income from these magazines makes it much easier to scrape a living as a writer, but there could be a principle at stake here, too.
Issues_Survey: You do not seem to allow me to enter the region where I live as Northern Ireland. I am (not just as a result of this survey) really thinking hard about selling all rights to certain of my short stories. I had reconciled myself to a position that I was, at least some of the time, writing as an artisan, akin to a potter, and was happy to craft my work and send it out into the world  in exchange for payment, not necessarily expecting anyone to remember that I made it. But I'm really not sure if this position is OK.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I suffer from an incurable disease - Multiple Sclerosis and so isolation has been my prime target and as a 86 year old that is another reason for being careful.  Both my wife and I are retired and writing is my saviour when diagnosed with MS when I was 26 years old.  A numbness from the knees down to the feet and from the elbows to fingers and round the middle - lower stomach - this has been termed as a mild strain.  My first book was a  "A Touch of Heaven" followed by "Christmas is Coming" and "I Remember it Well"  all the books were short stories.  I started to write thrillers and that genre were "Mistaken Identity" followed by "A Joyride to Murder" and "The Steal" until I discovered Bertram Bear.  My first Children's book and I won an accolade presented the Sussex Newspaper - "The Adventures of Bertram Bear" voted book of the year 2019 Editor's choice.   "Bertram Bear and the  Rivals" also published and there will be 16 more books.  Also published "The Christmas Tree Story" The Children's books are illustrated - first book Amanda Breach B.A. and the second book by Mira Homer B.A. and M.A.  Not knowing if I have received any earnings for my books - because at first before joining ALCS - I just wrote for fun and also lose myself from the pain!
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I suppose stress has a lot to answer for in my life - whether I was going to be unlucky to catch Covid-19 or Omicron or any other variant on the market and of course I try to look at it with a comical outlook as having MS can have its funny side!  We test at home if we are going out and I still wear a mask and so does my wife who has multi medical problems as well.  We don't feel the government is going the right way and I can't say I have any confidence in their ability to protect the people of this country.  Just my own opinion being a Columnist for two online Newspapers, I am also an Editor for a National News Magazine South East - National Operatic and Dramatic Association.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I lost some freelance income, but it was matched by the HMRC SEISS grants, of which I received 3.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I suffered a lot of anxiety during the pandemic and struggled with my workload while homeschooling children, and for a long time after they returned to school. I now feel like I have recovered and found my balance again, and am more conscious of protecting my mental health and guarding against finding myself in a similar situation again.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I succeeded in postponing the due date for two contracts during the pandemic

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Speaking assignments based on publications have dried up completely.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Well, I'm still writing.
Contractual_changes: Being asked to allow publisher to exploit a range of novel digital platforms for giving readers access, from ebooks to subscription models.
Issues_Survey: Readers today seem to expect to be able to access books for free or at very low cost.  The role of authors in producing written works - print or digital - seems no longer to be recognized.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: teaching work ceased
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: no impact
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: they wanted to exclude moral rights, changing their original promise

Member_NUJ_year: but left last year when subs increased
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: The impact is not reflected in this survey as you don't have boxes for SEISS (£14000) and letting large parts of my house to gain rental income to make up for loss of earnings. I included both of these in the total income boxes but my earnings from work were very low. Most of my book contracts were cancelled at the start of first lockdown, so my income from publishers fell from £40K to £6K but I was able to make up my income with SEISS and renting out rooms
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Decreased productivity (not able to concentrate), restricted access to library facilities, museums and other research sources, reduction in publishing contracts, increased time caring (vulnerable others/covering childcare for essential-worker family)
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No. Change of moral rights waiver to be less comprehensive; addition of clause to say I could claim PLR/ALCS monies even though surrendering copyright
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Separate disputes! One about not integrity where they hacked about the text to the point that I said I wanted my name removed; they allowed me to revise the text to a point where I was happy with it. Attribution: name being missed from book and/or publicity materials; usually they add at next print run or to metadata
Contractual_changes: All contracts are now signed digitally. Moral rights waivers getting more severe - latest was 'waived to the fullest possible extent'!
Contract_clauses: God, yes, as always. I hate waiving moral rights and signing away copyright but if I don't do it, the work doesn't go ahead
Issues_Survey: It was difficult to know how to answer questions on income as it doesn't specify whether income is turnover or profit after subtracting expenses. I did it as turnover, but that's not really the money I have to live on

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I was not able to work as much due to the need to support home learning for my children.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Competing works clause - I was able to make the definition of a competing work more restrictive, so that my future writing was less likely to be affected. I also negotiated higher fees for several projects.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Have not been able to write as much and, in any case, have had to become a carer in the interim.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Unable to go out to venues where I could sell my work. Have missed two crucial selling opportunities. Because of shielding, have been unable to travel (inspiration)
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Inability to do book signings or a launch for my fifth book due to lock downs etc.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: In a way it has had both negative and positive effect. Although it has reduced marketing opportunities, the quiet of the lockdown has enabled me to adapt my five novels into screenplays.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: It was regarding the wording relating to annual re-listing of e-books.  My first three contracts did not include this ,but the fourth one I thought the wording was ambiguous.  But I was advised by the SoA to compromise, which I did.
self_publishing_comments: My fifth book incurred costs of: £4,314.69 for 500 copies. So far I have made £701.57, but that is income from all my five books.  The fifth one, my marketing has been extremely limited.
Contract_clauses: Only the e-book re-listing  annual fee which was suddenly applied for book 4.
Issues_Survey: No

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: A very substantial increase of sales on Kindle.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: My productivity increased as I was forced to stay at home where my sole interest and amusement is to write.
self_publishing_comments: I have been publishing exclusively on Kindle since 2013 and have built up a following of readers that is expanding with minimal marketing. I use Amazon's own tools perhaps four times a year.

year: I am highly prolific and the number of new books seems to keep me before my readers.
Costs are minimal - about £210 to have a cover and the book sent up to Amazon - I do none of the formatting.
I published 13 full-length novels last year and found the amount of time spent on the publishing process to be far less than that demanded of acquaintances who publish conventionally.
Books_Games: Not entirely relevant to the ebook author. The number of indies is growing and our incomes appear to be increasing. The us and them divide seems to be growing.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: It was an editorial employment contract - just amended some terms

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: It hasn't made any difference because I have only recently resumed my writing career and have as yet made no sales
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It has resulted in hugely increased productivity because (in conjunction with a cancer scare) it made me realise that at the age of 76 I might not have much time left to complete the books I want to complete
Contractual_changes: I am filling in this form because you asked me to do so, but as you can tell it is almost as if I am starting all over again and the contractual practices to which I was accustomed all date from the last century
Issues_Survey: I am afraid that at this stage of my re-launch I have been an almost entirely useless contributor to this survey.

Member_NUJ_year: I was a member of the NUJ Freelance until my earnings from novels exceeded that of my journalism.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My earning should have increased going on new contracts etc but didn't as publishers couldn't place my books into as many supermarkets. Only an ongoing advance helped the figures, although this coming year will show I won't earn out advance so will impact on royalties.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Tp being with I was fine, but the stress of having to supply books that I know would not sell as well in the coming years eventually impacted on my mental health. I let my publisher was not working as hard as it could have done and my genre (saga) was left to flounder. Bigger names had their publication dates put on hold whereas saga authors went out onetime without the promotion etc. I paid for my own PR though a public relations company in order to help readers see I had new books out. This cot me £4,200 per book.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: My agent and I haggled for a higher advance and achieved the same as previous contract but with bonuses built in. We also insisted on better PR
Contractual_changes: Refusal to increase ebook royalties at a time when digital first publishers are paying as much as 50% the trad publishers are keeping royalties low.  Offer of a bonus rather than increase in royalties,ties. My latest contract will pay an extra £1,500 if paperback sales hit 30,000. They have done in the past but not so sure since Covid affected the trade.  I accepted as there was nothing else being offered/agreed to. It it a two book contract with the first being published on 17/3/22 so we will see.
Contract_clauses: Just the refusal to increase royalties. At the moment I'm paid, £23,000 per book.
Issues_Survey: Nome at all.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Cancellation of events hitting magazine industry
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Less work - it was substantially down and only got as high as it did because of one good copywriting gig
Issues_Survey: Why conflate gender with sex? LIkely that men and women have different negotiating styles and are treated differently – no amount of identifying with get you out of that, unfortunately, so these should be separate

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Again it's evened out. I work from home most of the time but there was some pressure as a result of family members also having to work from home. One positive was that some competitors seemed to stop working. There's no evidence that pushed more work my way but with fewer people sending to the media It was easier to get my work published. Another positive was that one or two difficult clients stopped using me so I was able to drop them and concentrate on those who value my work.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Have missed outside stimulus - concentration has suffered.
self_publishing_comments: Tend t spend very little money on marketing & promo - find that steady production is best to maintain sales

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I'm disabled and clinically vulnerable so have lost more work in 2021-22 as people have attempted to 'get back to normal', but I still can't do in-person teaching or book events, which previously made up a large portion of my income. In 2020 when everyone was in lockdown there was more remote work. Now, it's increasingly rare. On the other hand, my expenses in 2020-21 were far fewer than normal, as I was not travelling all round the country regularly to do workshops and reading. Obviously the cost of living crisis is going to impact on this massively, as expenses of working at home go up too.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: There have been some negative elements and some positives. Being able to work remotely more have actually been amazing for me, as for many disabled writers - it made me realised how much I was draining myself by dashing around to do in-person events. I managed to write a whole book between July 2020 and May 2021, which I never would have been able to do if I were travelling for work too. On the other hand, it's been isolating and deeply frustrating and depressing as the literary world has celebrated being back in-person and largely forgotten about those of us who can't be yet, for whom there is no covid-safe environment still now. Disabled writers are being let down and shut out.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: advice from society of authors to amend some tiny parts of contract

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Increased savings due to a drop in travel costs. Government self employed grants helped massively.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Fees per article have dropped - halved in some cases.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Loss of earnings from giving readings & teaching workshops in person. Savings on travel costs for my main job.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Greatly decreased productivity; stress

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: They dipped as I was homeschooling but have gone back up again
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: It was not easy working and homeschooling 3 children but I feel it is over now and I can seize opportunities again, and I feel invigorated to try new things

Amending non compete clauses

Removing indemnity clauses
Books_Educational: Edu publishers driving down fees and grabbing more rights

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Freelancing work has moved from predominantly in-person teaching (not writing-related) to predominantly academic editing work - it's not more lucrative by the hour, but I've been able to do a lot more of it. Employed work (also not writing-related) has stayed largely the same. Plus, since 2020, I've been able to query and sell my first novel - the injection of time really helped.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Harder and more stressful to work, access to research much reduced, access to networking opportunities much reduced - but while my productivity got worse, the time available during lockdown was much more, and a few solid months of furlough income were really good for editing creative work. I enjoyed it much less - very hard to concentrate or be creative during lockdown/the pandemic in general - but I did manage to use the time to finish a big project, which I then sold, so since the pandemic things have definitely taken an upturn for me professionally.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Royalties, extent of rights
Contractual_changes: I have only signed one contract (and one agent's agreement) to date.
Issues_Survey: I'm estimating household salary - don't have access to exact numbers for other household member.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress through non writing work has impacted ability to concentrate on writing. Family working from home has meant less time to be alone to write.
Contractual_changes: I mainly write stories for woman's magazines, and there are now very few who do not take all rights.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: (1) I self-publish short print runs of the books my traditional publishers produce in ebook and POD and sell them at talks, festivals, etc. I was doing talks at the rate of 40 - 50 p.a. and all the speaking fees and the sales generated thereby disappeared overnight. I moved into Zoom talks where possible, but far fewer and with no chance of post-talk sales.   (2) Because bookshops were closed, bigger publishing houses moved significantly into Amazon sales. They drove up the price of advertising to such an extent that the smaller publishers, like mine, could no longer compete. Their marketing per author dropped as a result, and with it, my profile and sales.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: I am an ex-barrister. I more or less re-wrote the contract I was offered with my agent. I negotiated a retention of the audiobook and film rights to my crime thriller series with the publishers.
Contractual_changes: I understand from other authors in the same stable that they have been offered contracts with lower percentages of profits.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: There was a speaking contract which said that they would own all the IP in my talk.  I made them take that clause out.
Issues_Survey: no

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: A tiny amount of travel savings
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Because I'm growing older I can't travel even short distances so zoom online workshops have allowed me to go on working and in fact expanded the number of workshops and the students and colleagues are now often from across the UK and the world.  So my world has expanded and I've managed to keep teaching and keep writing.
Issues_Survey: Some of the questions are irrelevant for a poet.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Too many ways to just list here. As a freelancer, a small business owner, and a writer, COVID has been a nightmare to deal with. I wasn't eligible for furlough for my company, but I could access the SEISS grant however I have now found out that taking that grant has impacted my ability to get a mortgage as it's seen as a negative thing. This is another blow that I didn't need - I would rather have gone hungry than take the grants had I realised it would impact my future affordability on my home. Things went quiet in 2021 freelance wise, and whilst things are now beginning to pick up, the increase in household costs is making things very difficult again. I left full time work to write part time and do marketing consultancy part time, and at this stage, I'm considering going back into full time work as this just doesn't feel sustainable anymore. It's very upsetting though because writing is my passion.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I am the most stressed I've ever been - I am hardly writing at all as I am having to spend almost all my time looking for paid work. The cost of living is going up in an alarming way compared to the money on offer for freelance work in my sector. All of this has a huge impact on my writing as it feels now more than ever a luxury that I can't afford. Writing itself (my books) earns a pitifully small amount of annual revenue for me and so whilst it's my passion, I'm having to think of putting it aside for the moment so I can afford my home.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I recognized that there is a global marketplace to sell work... I'd been working on a novel for four years, so really feel like I missed a lot... now, there are editors tweeting opps, and honestly, I spend hours sending work, pitching, and pushing or repurposing work to the point there are 2 or 3 writers here... it doesn't necessarily pay, but I'm continuing to grow and meet new editors, or opps, and you just keep at it... always harder to do the long novel work, but you just rise up and do it. Finding ACLS was amazing and I was surprised to see with just a few things how much was earned. I took the time to add more for next time.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Stress is just a busy mind, a person who can't allocate peace/stillness, so I don't believe in it or subscribe to any language of 'it's too much.' What's too much is a person's attention to it. I don't, so I honestly did not really notice there was a pandemic, nor war... I honor my time and space and get the work done. I'm thriving, but then I was even before, and I will never find accomplishment in the success of money but in doing honest work with love and enthusiasm.
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Not sure... I'm almost always negotiating the perpetual clause...
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: I have asked publishers to include a clause that I can leave the contract if there is an issue of integrity on their part and most seem clueless. So I've declined to work with them. I decline more contracts than I accept.
Contractual_changes: There are an amazing amount of new people agenting with little to no experience; they are branching off to their own companies, but do not have legal in place, or a legit contract. As a business writer, I can tell if they've had a legal rep craft it... more often, I find that they contain very old/antiquated language--even easy things like, 'he or she' will... and I ask for it to be corrected. I still find hidden fees. I find contracts that are taking percentages of rights that don't exist... for instance, I anticipate that with Brandon Sanderson's 15.5 million dollar GoFundMe, agents, publishers, will contract for a share of this... or they contract for tech that hasn't been created... I find in some cases that in film, there is a non-union agenda of paying less than even .5 or 1% of budget and as low as $5K for a script, where it used to be 20-25K. I find most places, in short fiction, etc., will ask to keep the piece stored when we are colonizing Mars... and I won't do this. But that said, most of these places are junk and disappear in a year.
Contract_clauses: Perpetual clause; keeping the work online archived forever; not being able to see accounting records. I have an agent contract to review and they are passing fees on, legit ones, like money transfer rate fees, but can't abide. I find there is a lot of unclear language in the way you are able to change the work and the publisher is... there is this fine line that they can alter the work or if you don't agree, you are unable to do anything... covers remain an issue... a publisher will market your book as (say) a gift book and it's scholarly, or you end up with a naked woman when you would be appauled to have such a cover assoc with your work. The point of no return clause, basically, when you can't change the work, but they can, or they can publish without your say-so.
Issues_Survey: I would welcome classes/workshops on reading contracts.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Redundancy. Now unable to find work in an academic role.

Contractual_changes: Life is less secure. Two book deals are not a given as they once were. Covid delayed publication so I had a year with no income. I have completed book 2 but  my contract has not yet been renewed.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Lack of promotional opportunities, book launches, author events, networking opportunities

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I've lost a lot of the ad hoc tutoring work I did, or work with the military and in schools. What I saved on travel and childcare, I spent on home learning resources and extra food
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Caring responsbilities, increased workload to deal with remote teaching, catching Covid twice
Contractual_changes: I have had a problem with work being taken and published online without my permission. It was an American site, so I used the DMCA laws to issue a takedown notice with the help of a University Press legal team who were being kind to me,

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My income has declined, but I cannot directly relate it to Covid.  A number of projects reached their inevitable conclusions, but the reason they were not replaced by others is that I am a full-time carer for my elderly mother.  Our regular income is from her State Pension, Attendance Allowance and Carer’s Allowance.  The pandemic meant that other people’s lives became more like mine, working from home, unable to travel.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: I have been anxious and stressed during the relevant period, but that was due to the discovery that my co-author had been deceiving me for two decades.  It is impossible to say whether he could have got away with it for longer if the pandemic had not swept over us.  My plan is to get an autobiography out of it, so I have been writing that … and gaining no income from it.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: COVID-19 has led to considerable increases in cost of heat and light (it's very hard to write in the dark). It has also resulted in a need to financially support other members of our family. It has resulted in some savings - we no longer go to a local café for a morning coffee break. It has also meant that my contact with my union can take place only by Zoom in the case of meetings.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: A difficulty in promoting my self-published books. Some anxiety - but then when you're 83 anxiety may well be the normality.
self_publishing_comments: Self-publishing can be a smooth and happy experience, but it can also be a nightmare. Outfits that allegedly say that will do the work for you (at a price - beware of villains) can be slow on the uptake as to what is required of them (and paid for by the writer). Self-publishing one book took weeks and weeks because the typesetting of the online publisher had to be re-set six times.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: It's so long ago that I can't remember, and anyway the publisher went dramatically bankrupt before the problem had been resolved
Contractual_changes: Much harder ability to discover to whom I should send my work - without having an agent. This applies to book publishers and also such outfits as the BBC.
Issues_Survey: It's made me more aware of the mistakes I have made in the past, and the mistakes that I'm in danger of making now

Member_Other_year: Various years, not continuous. I am a member this year.
Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: Low paid / unpaid zoom events instead of proper paid in person events, teaching hours and workshops and author copy sales. Increased costs of heating home office etc. Increased rent and cost of living. Reduced hours in publishing.

Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: A general malaise that drags at productivity.
Issues_Survey: Your questions mostly include an unstated assumption that I am published by someone else rather than actually having a blend of work I have done for other publishers and work I have published using my own small press, making it impossible for me to accurate reflect the majority of my income, contracts, &c.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: My writing earnings have decreased but my self-employment earnings have increased because of the pandemic as I moved all my services online.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: COVID-19 has totally reduced my social life so my energies went into my work. I spent a lot of my time 'at work'. At the start of 2020 I was incredibly concerned about getting COVID and stopped seeing ANY clients face-to-face and in person. I doubt that will ever be resolved and I will continue to work 100% online. My publisher, even though they are truly lovely, also probs reduced their input/output as production and distribution were affected considerably by the pandemic. COVID-19 did/does increase my stress levels as there is a constant worry I could get COVID-19 and die. Also my husband is vulnerable with a heart issue and I have 2 long-term chronic conditions. The pandemic did produce a need to think of other ways of doing things and that 'challenge' gave me something else to focus on, rather than continually worrying I could catch a fatal virus. I did write a book and self-publish it during the pandemic.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
self_publishing_comments: I love self-publishing, even though it takes time, energy and drives me bonkers. I like the fact that the final product is mine and mine only. I don't have to abide by any publisher's input. I suppose I enjoy the creative freedom of it. The £ costs aren't that high. I do pay for cover designs. I do have subscribers do read-throughs. The platform I use (NOT Amazon) does take a cut of the profits but doesn't ask for upfront fees. Self-publishing an audio-book was equally bonkers-driving but was also a wonderfully creative experience. I host a weekly podcast and it seemed a natural extension of that. I'm planning on my next book also being an audio-book. I wouldn't use Amazon again. I've used them in the past and it's like using a robot. The platforms I use now have real people in charge that reply to queries and are helpful. Amazon almost put me off self-publishing, but my replacement rekindled the fire. Fab. I've self-published enough times now to not be flummoxed and I enjoy it. It's the creative part I love the most:) xx

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I wrote several novels I couldn't place during the pandemic due to publisher caution. One I self-published and have earned almost nothing from; the other I 'sold' to a digital-first publisher with no advance (I have yet to see any royalties from its recent publication). Thankfully, I also changed genres and that saved me financially as the new genre has been more successful and I've sold 4 books in that genre since late 2019, with small advances. I used to write on retreats several times a year and put all those expenses down against income; having to write at home constantly has lowered my allowable expenses, so I've paid more tax! In general, publisher unwillingness to acquire or pay for acquisition has hugely impacted my earnings. During the pandemic my income more than halved. This current tax year my income has almost halved again, so I now earn a quarter of what I did pre-pandemic. I have not seen a big uptick in ebook sales as others did, unfortunately, but that may be down to genre/author name.
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Mainly stress from money issues.
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: Mainly clauses to do with being forced to offer my next book to that publisher. They tend to want all books to be offered to them, regardless, and I always insist on it being specific to one genre or author name. Other clause issues - royalties/rights - tend to be dealt with by my agent and I leave that to them.
self_publishing_comments: I find digital books relatively easy and simple to produce via Amazon and have about 150 digital titles on Amazon. I do not use other platforms as they seem to be a waste of time. Paperback self-pub is rather harder, due to formatting issues that can be time-consuming and frustrating, and they are always more expensive to sell and earn lower royalties, so I don't sell many.   There are no particular costs incurred by self-pub on Amazon, apart from one's own time spent on getting it right/promoting it. (I have never been PAID to promote by a publisher, so not being paid to promote my own books is hardly a point of contention. I have also never really had a lot of marketing input from publishers in general and I've been doing this over two decades with many different (mainly big) publishers, so again, new writers who expect publishers to promote their books for them beyond a few tweets and maybe a blog tour at publication are living in a fantasy. I'd be ecstatic if they did, but I have never seen it happen to me. They save their big money campaigns for Big New Things and already bestselling authors.)
Issues_Survey: We need to force publishers to stop offering no-advance contracts which is killing the ability of writers to be professional, i.e. to earn a living from their work, and also encourage them to promote books and support authors in general more than they do.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: I couldn't tour schools and royalties decreased substantially by 30%, and continue to decrease year on year over the Covid period
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: Mental health struggles, including depression and anxiety about future earnings Creative block lasting months, resulting in a 6-9 months delay in delaying next project
legal_advise: Yes, as a matter of course
Changed_contract_Negotiations: No
Contractual_changes: Boilerplate contracts that offer no negotiation as they say this is company policy  Significant impact: A change from paying advance a third on signing, a third on delivery and a third on publication to no more than 50% before publication. This dramatically and negatively affects cash flow for an author (who uses an advance to survive while writing) while this change of policy solely benefits the publisher by reducing their risk and keeping their money. This also changes the whole principle of an advance which is to allow a 'liveable' (!) wage while writing into a fee at the end. A very unfair practice for authors.

Covid_Impact_Earnings_Info: book sales have reduced but travel costs have also reduced
Covid_Impact_Profession_Info: increased productivity due to less travelling time and face-to-face meetings. Zoom and Teams use has increased work time dramatically.

self_publishing_comments: For me blogging is a way of opening up your process and talking about what you're doing; it's a way of marketing yourself. In my blog I talk about all of my activities including: the festival I organise the teaching I do and the events I've appeared at. It was very valuable when I started out but it does take up a lot of time. Writing a good blog post can take a few hours and that's not work I get "paid" for as such. I do like doing it because I like being open about what an author's life is like. That said its primary purpose is to market myself & my activities. If I had a publicist or agent to "market" me and publicise my books I'm not sure that I would continue doing it.

Changed_contract_Negotiations: With the advice of SoA many changes were made to one contract as follows: The contract was unclear not differentiating between editors and contributors; I think they asked for an exclusive licence indefinitely. We changed this to for 3 years and thereafter non-exclusive. The time for settling payments was reduced from 6 months to 3 months. The definition of competing work which my co-editor and I agreed not to take on was tightened making it less vague.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: You might not call this a dispute but on a book I was editing the publishers failed to attribute properly the work of contributors and artists. I had to insist on it being done properly even though the contributors and artists had contracts in which publishers had agreed to do it.
Contract_clauses: The time given for proofreading was too short (10 days).  I feel concerned about the clause to do with inspecting the publishers' accounts at the cost of Â£30 per hour. I am not sure how this would play out in reality if I ever needed to do it.

self_publishing_comments: Costs related to purchase of ISBN blocks having co-authors and branding organisations agree to market the product to its intended audience and providing what was agreed post hoc even with a contract have proven fraught. Seem to want non-involvement other than one-off payment for production only and to take all credit once produced despite their being the primary pre-agreed 'agent' in terms of advertising and making the work known.
MR_dispute_grounds_addition: Produced the idea for an edited collaborative volume and the organisation put in their own named editor from a different organisation reducing my right to that of producing just a single chapter under my own name. The named editor status is a requirement for next grade promotion in the area of work I was in therefore the named editor benefits instead. Since that person had formally attracted me into the organisation there was little I could do to rectify apart from creating a further volume with someone else under my own control by then an edited volume in my own name was no longer useful to the alternative career pathway I had ended up on.
Contractual_changes: Downloading has replaced any income received from photocopying payment and is part of the purchase contract for journals. So essentially I have lost any publishing income that is not part of the initial production contract for a work. All writing is now for status or to help me complete an existing job more effectively.
Contract_clauses: Having to pass on work at cost only after production and not being allowed to make an income beyond the initial production payment on the basis that the 'audience' for the work is already paying subscriptions to the funding organisation and thus work is considered part of the funders output to their contributors.

self_publishing_comments: Not my ideal choice to self-pub but I have to say I like being able to choose my own illustrator discuss with him what should be on the cover etc etc. The creative input in seeing the whole thing through is fantastic and very satisfying and I'm chuffed with the response the book gets from those who do come across it. Huge amounts of unpaid time spent marketing of course (tho conventionally-published writers do that too and many complain their publishers don't market enough/at all). No actual costs to do it except my illustrator (I edited/proofed myself; again time-consuming but again I hear from some writers who have editors of mistakes and oversights). I have invested in things like Giveaways (Amazon is reasonable - just the cost of the books; Goodreads is expensive). A downside is that many libraries are sniffy about taking self-pub books even as a donation - and it's hard logistically for bookshops to stock Print On Demand even if they want to.

self_publishing_comments: I suspect it costs approximately Â£1000 to self publish a full length novel if one is paying for professional cover design and editing. Some of these professional skills I swap with friends; some such a developmental editing I pay for. There is a thriving and relatively cheap cover market so my covers have costs between $30 for cheap giveaway ebooks and Â£200. Marketing can suck up enormous time. Some things like Instafreebie and mailchimp lists are relatively cheap and effective. Paid promotion sites are of limited value particularly for YA and children's work - often writers see no return on paid promotions except for perhaps Bookbub which is very expensive and hard to secure.
Contractual_changes: I can only compare to the agented deals friends had been offered shortly before my offer and my agent's comments on the market. That said the advance I was offered by an independent print publisher was dismal - Â£1000 for three books with a 7.5% cut of net receipts. I said no and instead sold the digital and audio rights to an Amazon imprint which paid $1500 and a 50% royalty rate on actual price and self published the paperback. This kind of hybrid contract is not without difficulties - for most competitions libraries and magazine sites you are neither self published nor traditionally published and so your book usually is eligible.   The other difference my agent and I saw was a rights grab in trad publishers' offers - they typically wanted global rights in perpetuity. Amazon has also bought global rights for ebook and audio including translation rights but it is pretty good at reverting them if they decide not to use them. Audio rights can be reverted within 90 days of contract for example if Kindle Press decides not to exercise them.

self_publishing_comments: The only publicity I have is through a local writing group. Have not really acquired readership locally. My novels are mystery adventure romantic thriller science fiction and a poetry anthology. I post on social media but again I don't believe I target my readership. Social media occupants do not necessarily read novels and poetry. I receive positive responses on American e-book sites but this does not translate to sales. Bit suspicious about how much is known about my works without anyone making a purchase overseas? I have not "launched" any of my four novels. My wife does not want the celebrity tag.  However interest has been shown recently because a sequel to my first novel a mystery sea adventure is with. Organizations that received copes three year previously are now getting back to ask for another copy. It is factual that I've given away more copies  than I've sold.  With the sequel I hope to sell more than I give away. My novels have been loaned from the local library.  On each publication I contact a range of appropriate bookshops but have never received a reply. The local bookshop reluctantly accepted two copies of Dancing on the Beach by Sam Grant and of my Poems with themed notes respectively. These include my give away copies listing. It was said that self-published authors are not liked  by bookshops.  I've appeared three times on local radio and each time was asked for free copies. I have kept positive and realize that I lack any meaningful  publicity medium  to promote my works.  My publisher is keen on my latest novel and there is interest for a sequel. I enjoy writing novels short stories and poetry. My poems have been regularly published in anthologies for seven years. Best wishes Colin.

self_publishing_comments: I have over 100 fiction titles available electronically on Amazon in a variety of lengths and genres. The longer titles (40-100K words) are often also available in Amazon-created ppb. I incur no particular costs except cover copyright which is usually about Â£10 each. As someone with previous editorial/publishing experience myself I do all my own formatting editing and design work for both e-books and ppbs. I never use paid advertising for self-published books just publicise on my own Twitter account(s) a few hours weekly.
Contractual_changes: The only obvious thing I can think of is the advent of emailed contracts where no PHYSICAL copy exists and you electronically sign a contract via Docusign or whatever it's called. I find that tricky as I like to see things on paper.
Contract_clauses: Competition clauses as always: restricting me from publishing other works in the same genre within 12 months of a title's publication date. Not very helpful when you are prolific and want to move on to a different publisher but have to wait a year or publish under a different (i.e. new) name. There was also an audio contract I negotiated separately from my agent which kept rights for 8 years which I felt was an excessively long time. But it was for a self-published novella so I shrugged it off as insignificant.

Contractual_changes: Publishers are simply hoovering up more and more rights. Magazines in particular want 'all rights'. Some are open to negotiation but many aren't. It's getting harder to make money from exploiting different rights in your won work because more publishers are taking a greater realm of rights from us. Gone are the days when you could sell the same short story to magazines in the UK Australia Ireland South Africa. They all want World rights or to be the first in the world to publish it in the English language.
